   8-91 through 8-108 reserved
§ 8-77. PURPOSE.
   A need exists to establish a policy whereby users of the municipal airport
may be afforded a fair and reasonable opportunity, without discrimination, to
use the airport facilities for chemical application and further be afforded the
opportunity to qualify or otherwise compete for airport space and the
furnishing of selected aeronautical services.
(Prior Code, § 8-77) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-78. AUTHORITY OF CITY AND AIRPORT COMMISSION TO SET FEES.
   The airport shall be open for the use of chemical applicators, subject to
such fees and charges as may be established from time to time by the city and
Airport Commission without discrimination toward this class of users.
(Prior Code, § 8-78) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-79. USE IMPLIES CONSENT TO REGULATIONS.
   The use of the airport or its facilities, in any manner, shall create the
obligation and the implied consent of the user to obey all of the regulations
herein as well as local, state, and federal regulations regarding chemical
applicators and abide by the minimum standards hereinafter stated.
(Prior Code, § 8-79) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-80. CITY AND AIRPORT COMMISSION NOT LIABLE.
   The privilege of using the airport and facilities shall be conditioned on
the assumption of full indemnity and hold absolutely harmless the city, its
officers and employees, and the Airport Commission from any liability or loss
resulting from such use as well as against claims of third persons using the
airport. The exercise of the privilege of use shall constitute an
acknowledgment that the city and the Airport Commission maintain the airport in
a governmental capacity.
(Prior Code, § 8-80) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-81. PROVISIONS FOR USE.
   Any person using the airport for agricultural aerial application which
involves the loading, unloading, and storage of chemicals must maintain a base
of operations at the airport and must have entered into a written agreement
with the city and the Airport Commission. Such persons must be licensed by the
proper agencies, show evidence of carrying required insurance, city permit, and
work performance bond to cover the cost of any cleanup resulting from any
spillage or accident.
(Prior Code, § 8-81) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-82. ANNUAL PERMIT; FEE.
   An annual permit shall be issued to each applicator from the city, at the
cost of $100. The permit will include the name of the aircraft, with N numbers,
pilots, and pilot certificate number. Changes are permissible when the permit
is amended in writing.
(Prior Code, § 8-82) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-83. INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Insurance required (provide a copy from insurer):
      (1)   Aircraft liability.
         (a)   Bodily injury:
            1.   Each person: $100,000; and
            2.   Each accident: $300,000.
         (b)   Property damage, each accident: $100,000.
      (2)   Comprehensive public liability and property damage.
         (a)   Bodily injury:
            1.   Each person: $100,000; and
            2.   Each accident: $300,000.
         (b)   Property damage, each accident: $100,000.
   (B)   Performance bond required: $100,000 each applicator, for chemical
damage and cleanup.
(Prior Code, § 8-83) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-84. ACCIDENTS OR SPILLS.
   Any accident or incident involving the spill of chemicals shall immediately
be brought to the attention of the airport manager. Cleanup of any chemical
spills shall be immediately performed by the applicator at his or her expense.
Any cleanup resulting from any spillage shall be performed in accordance with
all federal, state, and local laws, rules, and regulations pertaining to the
same.
(Prior Code, § 8-84) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-85. UNCONTAINED SPILLS.
   An UNCONTAINED SPILL is defined as more than ten gallons or 25 pounds of dry
weight or pesticide concentrate, or 50 gallons of an application mixture (tank
mix), shall constitute a spill for chemical damage and cleanup. Such a spill
must be reported within 24 hours to the airport manager and all other local,
state, and federal agencies required by law.
(Prior Code, § 8-85) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-86. SEGREGATED CHEMICAL STORAGE AREA.
   A segregated chemical storage protected from public access will be provided
by the applicator and approved by the airport. The washdown of agricultural
spraying aircraft and the flushing of agricultural aircraft spray tanks will be
accomplished only in areas so designated by the applicator and approved by the
airport. Empty containers shall be disposed of in accordance with applicable
federal and state laws.
(Prior Code, § 8-86) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-87. QUALIFIED PILOTS.
   Aircraft shall not be left running without a qualified pilot at the
controls. Agricultural aircraft shall not be refueled, loaded, or unloaded with
chemicals, or otherwise serviced while the engine is running, unless a
qualified pilot is at the controls.
(Prior Code, § 8-87) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-88. PERFORMANCE BOND.
   The applicator shall be required to provide the city and the Airport
Commission with a performance bond or other proper security, either cash or
from a reputable company licensed to do business in the state, in the sum of
$10,000, to cover the cost of any cleanup resulting from any spillage or
accident. The bond shall cover any incidents either on the leased premises, on
the airport grounds, or away from the airport grounds. The applicator shall not
commence any business until such bond requirement has been satisfied. Leaking
spray nozzles, hoppers, or tanks will constitute such incidents of spillage, as
described in “spills,” defined under performance bond above.
(Prior Code, § 8-88) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-89. REQUIRED LIST OF TYPES AND QUANTITIES OF CHEMICALS.
   (A)   The applicator shall provide the city and Airport Commission a
complete list of the types and quantities of chemicals stored by him or her, by
location, at the initial onset of his or her operation.
   (B)   A civil defense hazard warning sign will be installed on each storage
building or tank to inform all the emergency-type personnel of contents. These
signs will be obtained from civil defense or the Fire Chief. Applicators shall
notify the city and the Airport Commission of any significant change in the
types or quantities of chemicals used. The city and the Airport Commission
shall make the list available to the Chief, Fire Department, and other
emergency-type personnel.
   (C)   All chemicals, pesticides, and substances used by the applicator shall
be stored in a hanger, other building, or tanks capable of being locked and
secured. Under no circumstances shall any chemical, substance, empty container,
or pesticide be outside a building in an unsecured situation at the close of
any business day or at the time the applicator’s business is unattended.
(Prior Code, § 8-89) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§ 8-90. ISSUANCE OF A PERMIT.
   No permit shall be issued until the applicator is in compliance with all of
the provisions of this article. If a permit is issued and one of the provisions
of this article is breached, said permit can be revoked on proper notice and
hearing.
(Prior Code, § 8-90) (Ord. 790, passed 2-9-1989)
§§ 8-91 THROUGH 8-108. RESERVED.
ARTICLE V: AIRPORT ZONING REGULATIONS

   Airports and aircraft, see 3 O.S. §§ 61 et seq.
   Authority to adopt airport zoning regulations, see 3 O.S. § 103
§ 8-109. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AIRPORT. Alva Regional Airport, Alva, Oklahoma.
   AIRPORT ELEVATION. The established elevation of the highest point on the
usable landing area, which is 1,474 feet MSL.
   AIRPORT HAZARD. Any structure, tree, or use of land which obstructs the
airspace required for or is otherwise hazardous to the flight of aircraft in
landing or taking off at the airport.
   AIRPORT REFERENCE POINT. The point established as the approximate geographic
center of the airport landing area and is established at a location described
as follows: 1,140 feet west and 2,890 feet south of the NE corner of the NE
quarter of Section 35, T-26-N, R-14-W; Woods County, Oklahoma. Latitude: 36°
46' 23.41" Longitude: 98° 40' 11.81".
   BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT. An airport commission consisting of five members
appointed by the Mayor.
   HEIGHT. For the purpose of determining the height limits in all zones set
forth in this article and shown on the zoning map, the datum shall be mean sea
level elevation unless otherwise specified.
   INSTRUMENT RUNWAY. A runway equipped or to be equipped with electronic or
visual air navigation aids adequate to permit the landing of aircraft under
restricted visibility conditions.
   LANDING AREA. The area of the airport used for the landing, takeoff, or
taxiing of aircraft.
   NONCONFORMING USE. Any structure, tree, or use of land which is lawfully in
existence at the time the regulation is prescribed in this article or an
amendment thereto becomes effective and does not then meet the requirements of
said regulation.
   NONINSTRUMENT RUNWAY. A runway other than instrument runway.
   PERSON. An individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company, association,
joint stock association, or body politic, and includes a trustee, receiver,
assignee, administrator, executor, guardian, or other representative.
   RUNWAY. The paved surface of an airport landing strip.
   STRUCTURE. An object constructed or installed by humans, including, but
without limitation, buildings, towers, smokestacks, and overhead transmission
lines.
   TREE. Any object of natural growth.
(Prior Code, § 8-109) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970; Ord. 2001-843, passed 9-3-
2001)
§ 8-110. ZONES ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   In order to carry out the provisions of this article, there are hereby
created and established certain zones, which include all of the land lying
within the instrument approach zones, noninstrument approach zones, transition
zones, horizontal zone, and conical zone. Such areas and zones are shown on the
Alva Regional Airport Zoning Map consisting of one sheet, prepared by Myers
Engineering, and dated November 8, 1995, which is attached to the ordinance
from which this article is derived and made a part hereof.
   (B)   The various zones are hereby established and defined as follows.
      (1)    Noninstrument approach zone. A noninstrument approach zone is
established at each end of all noninstrument runways on Alva Regional Airport
for noninstrument landings and takeoffs. The noninstrument approach zone shall
have a width of 500 feet at a distance of 200 feet beyond each end of the
runway, widening thereafter uniformly to a width of 3,500 feet at a distance of
10,000 feet beyond each end of the runway, its centerline being the
continuation of the centerline of the runway.
      (2)   Transition zones. Transition zones are hereby established adjacent
to each instrument and noninstrument runway and approach zone as indicated on
the zoning map. Transition zones symmetrically located on either side of
runways have variable widths as shown on the zoning map. Transition zones
extend outward from a line 125 feet on either side of the centerline of the
noninstrument runways for the length of such runway plus 200 feet on each end;
and are parallel and level with such runway centerlines. The transition zones
along such runways slope upward and outward one foot vertically for each seven
feet horizontally to the point where they intersect the surface of the
horizontal zone. Further, transition zones are established adjacent to
noninstrument zones for the entire length of the approach zones. These
transition zones have variable widths, as shown on the zoning map. Such
transition zones flare symmetrically with either side of the runway approach
zones from the base of such zones and slope upward and outward at the rate of
one foot vertically for each seven feet horizontally to the points where they
intersect the surfaces of the horizontal and conical zones.
      (3)   Horizontal zone. A horizontal zone is hereby established as the
area within a circle with its center at the airport reference point and having
a radius of 10,000 feet. The horizontal zone does not include the noninstrument
approach zones and the transition zones.
      (4)   Conical zone. A conical zone is hereby established commencing at
the periphery of the horizontal zone and extends outward therefrom a distance
of 4,000 feet. The conical zone does not include the noninstrument approach
zones and transition zones.
(Prior Code, § 8-110) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970; Ord. 2001-843, passed 9-3-
2001)
§ 8-111. HEIGHT LIMITATIONS.
   (A)   Except as otherwise provided in this article, no structure or tree
shall be erected, altered, allowed to grow, or maintained in any zone created
by this article to a height in excess of the height limit herein established
for such zone. Such height limitations are computed from the established
airport elevation and are hereby established for each of the zones in question
as follows:
      (1)   Noninstrument approach zones. One foot in height for each 20 feet
in horizontal distance beginning at a point 200 feet from and at the elevation
of the end of the noninstrument runway and extending to a point 10,000 feet
from the end of the runway;
      (2)   Transition zones. One foot in height for each seven feet in
horizontal distance beginning at any point 125 feet normal to and at the
elevation of the centerline of noninstrument runways extending 200 feet beyond
each end thereof, extending to a height 150 feet above the airport elevation or
1,624 feet above mean sea level. In addition to the foregoing, there are
established height limits of one foot vertical height for each seven feet
horizontal distance measured from the edges of all approach zones for the
entire length of the approach zones and extending upward and outward to the
points where they intersect the horizontal or conical surfaces;
      (3)   Horizontal zone. One hundred fifty feet above the airport elevation
or a height of 1,624 feet above mean sea level; and
      (4)   Conical zone. One foot in height for each 20 feet of horizontal
distance beginning at the periphery of the horizontal zone, extending to a
height of 1,824 feet mean sea level.
   (B)   Where an area is covered by more than one height limitation, the more
restrictive limitation shall prevail.
   (C)   Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the growth,
construction, or maintenance of any tree or structure to a height up to 50 feet
above the surface of the land.
(Prior Code, § 8-111) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970; Ord. 2001-843, passed 9-3-
2001)
§ 8-112. USE RESTRICTIONS.
   Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no use may be made of
land within any zone established by this article in such a manner as to create
electrical interference with radio communication between the airport and
aircraft, make it difficult for flyers to distinguish between airport lights
and others, result in glare in the eyes of flyers using the airport, impair
visibility in the vicinity of the airport, or otherwise endanger the landing,
taking off, or maneuvering of aircraft.
(Prior Code, § 8-112) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970)
§ 8-113. NONCONFORMING USES.
   (A)   Regulations not retroactive. The regulations prescribed by this
article shall not be construed to require the removal, lowering, or other
changes or alteration of any structure or tree not conforming to the
regulations as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article
is derived, or otherwise interfere with the continuance of any nonconforming
use. Nothing herein contained shall require any change in the construction,
alteration, or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of
which was begun prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this
article is derived, and is diligently prosecuted.
   (B)   Marking and lighting. Notwithstanding subsection (A) above of this
section, the owner of any nonconforming structure or tree is hereby required to
permit the installation, operation, and maintenance thereon of such markers and
lights as shall be deemed necessary by the administrative agency to indicate to
the operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport the presence of such
airport hazards. Such markers and lights shall be installed, operated, and
maintained at the expense of the city.
(Prior Code, § 8-113) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970)
§ 8-114. PERMITS.
   (A)   Future uses. Except as specifically provided in subsections (A)(1),
(A)(2), and (A)(3) below of this section, no material change shall be made in
the use of the land, and no structure or tree shall be erected, altered,
planted, or otherwise established in any zone hereby created unless a permit
therefor shall have been applied for and granted. Each application for a permit
shall indicate the purpose for which the permit is desired, with sufficient
particularity to permit it to be determined whether the resulting use,
structure, or tree would conform to the regulations herein prescribed. If such
determination is in the affirmative, the permit shall be granted. Nothing
contained in any of the exceptions in subsections (A)(1), (A)(2), and (A)(3)
below of this section shall be construed as permitting or intending to permit
any construction, alteration, or growth of any structure or tree in excess of
any of the height limits established by this article, except as set forth in §
8-111.
      (1)   In the area lying within the limits of the horizontal zone and the
conical zone but not within the limits of a noninstrument approach zone or
transition zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less
than 75 feet of vertical height above the ground, except when, because of
terrain, land contour, or topographic features, such tree or structure would
extend above the height limits prescribed for such zone.
      (2)   In the areas lying within the limits of the noninstrument approach
zones but at a horizontal distance of not less than 2,500 feet from each end of
the runways, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than 75
feet of vertical height above the established airport elevation, except when
such tree or structure would extend above the height limit prescribed for such
noninstrument approach zone.
      (3)   In the areas lying within the limits of the transition zones beyond
the perimeter of the horizontal zone, no permit shall be required for any tree
or structure less than 50 feet of vertical height above the ground except when
such tree or structure, because of terrain, land contour, or topographic
feature, would extend above the height limit prescribed for such transition
zones.
   (B)   Existing uses. No permit shall be granted that would allow the
establishment or creation of an airport hazard or permit a nonconforming use,
structure, or tree to be made or become higher, or become a greater hazard to
air navigation, than it was on the effective date of the ordinance from which
this article is derived or any amendments thereto or than it is when the
application for a permit is made. Except as indicated, all applications for
such a permit shall be granted.
   (C)   Nonconforming uses abandoned or destroyed. Whenever the administrative
agency determines that a nonconforming structure or tree has been abandoned or
more than 80% torn down, physically deteriorated, or decayed, no permit shall
be granted that would allow such structure or tree to exceed the applicable
height limit or otherwise deviate from the zoning regulations.
   (D)   Variances. Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any
structure, or permit the growth of any tree, or use his or her property, not in
accordance with the regulations prescribed in this article, may apply to the
Board of Adjustment for a variance from such regulations. Such variances shall
be allowed where it is duly found that a literal application or enforcement of
the regulations would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship
and the relief granted would not be contrary to the public interest but will do
substantial justice and be in accordance with the spirit of this article.
   (E)   Hazard marking and lighting. Any permit or variance granted may, if
such action is deemed advisable to effectuate the purpose of this article and
be reasonable in the circumstances, be so conditioned as to require the owner
of the structure or tree in question to permit the city at its own expense to
install, operate, and maintain thereon such markers and lights as may be
necessary to indicate to flyers the presence of an airport hazard.
(Prior Code, § 8-114) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970)
§ 8-115. ENFORCEMENT.
   The manager of the Alva Municipal Airport is hereby designated the
administrative officer. It shall be the duty of the administrative officer to
administer and enforce the regulations prescribed herein. Applications for
permits and variances shall be made to the administrative agency upon a form
furnished by him or her. Applications required by this article to be submitted
to the administrative agency shall be promptly considered and granted or denied
by him or her. Applications for action by the Board of Adjustment shall be
forthwith transmitted by the administrative agency.
(Prior Code, § 8-115) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970)
§ 8-116. BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT.
   (A)   There is hereby created a Board of Adjustment to have and exercise the
following powers:
      (1)   To hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision,
or determination made by the administrative agency or officer in enforcement of
this article;
      (2)   To hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of this article
upon which such Board of Adjustment, under such regulations, may be required to
pass; and
      (3)   To hear and decide specific variances.
   (B)   The Board of Adjustment shall consist of five members appointed by the
City Council, and each shall serve for a term of three years and until his or
her successor is duly appointed and qualified. Of the members first appointed,
one shall be appointed for a term of one year, two for terms of two years, and
two for terms of three years. Members shall be removable by the appointing
authority for cause, upon written charges, after a public hearing.
   (C)   The Board of Adjustment shall adopt rules for its governance and
procedure in harmony with the provisions of this article. Meetings of the Board
of Adjustment shall be held at the call of the Chair and at such other times as
the Board of Adjustment may determine. The Chair, or in his or her absence, the
Acting Chair, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All
hearings of the Board of Adjustment shall be public. The Board of Adjustment
shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon each
question, or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall
keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall
immediately be filed in the office of the administrative agency and shall be a
public record.
   (D)   The Board of Adjustment shall make written findings of fact and
conclusions of law giving the facts upon which it acted and its legal
conclusions from such facts in reversing, affirming, or modifying any order,
requirement, decision, or determination which comes before it under the
provisions of this article.
   (E)   The concurring vote of a majority of the members of the Board of
Adjustment shall be sufficient to reverse any order, requirement, decision, or
determination of the administrative agency or decide in favor of the applicant
on any matter upon which it is required to pass under this article, or to
effect any variation in this article.
(Prior Code, § 8-116) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970)
§ 8-117. APPEALS.
   (A)   Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected, by any decision of the
administrative agency or officer made in his or her administration of this
article, if of the opinion that a decision of the administrative agency is an
improper application of these regulations, may appeal to the Board of
Adjustment.
   (B)   All appeals hereunder must be taken within a reasonable time as
provided by the rules of the Board of Adjustment, by filing with the
administrative agency a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The
administrative agency shall forthwith transmit to the Board of Adjustment all
the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was
taken.
   (C)   An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action
appealed from, unless the administrative agency certifies to the Board of
Adjustment, after the notice of appeal has been filed with it, that by reason
of the facts stated in the certificate a stay would, in his or her opinion,
cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case, proceedings shall not
be stayed except by order of the Board of Adjustment on notice to the agency
from which the appeal is taken and on due cause shown.
   (D)   The Board of Adjustment shall fix a reasonable time for hearing
appeals, give public notice and due notice to the parties in interest, and
decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing, any party may
appear in person, or by agent, or by attorney.
   (E)   The Board of Adjustment may, in conformity with the provisions of this
article, reverse or affirm, in whole or in part, or modify the order,
requirement, decision, or determination appealed from and may make such order,
requirement, decision, or determination as may be appropriate under the
circumstances.
(Prior Code, § 8-117) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970)
§ 8-118. JUDICIAL REVIEW.
   Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected, by any decision of the Board
of Adjustment, may appeal to the district court as provided in 3 O.S. § 111.
(Prior Code, § 8-118) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970)
§ 8-119. PENALTIES.
   Each violation of this article or of any regulation, order, or ruling
promulgated hereunder shall constitute a misdemeanor and be punishable by a
fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than one year or both
such fine and imprisonment, and each day a violation continues to exist shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Prior Code, § 8-119) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970)
§ 8-120. CONFLICTING REGULATIONS.
   Where there exists a conflict between any of the regulations or limitations
prescribed in this article and any other regulations applicable to the same
area, whether the conflict be with respect to the height of structures or
trees, the use of land, or any other matter, the more stringent limitation or
requirement shall govern and prevail.
(Prior Code, § 8-120) (Ord. 690, passed 1-5-1970)

§ 10-1. PENALTY.
   Any person who shall engage in any business, trade, or vocation for which a
license, permit, certificate, or registration is required by this chapter,
without having a valid license, permit, certificate, or certificate of
registration as required, or who shall fail to do anything required by this
chapter or by any code adopted by this chapter, or who shall otherwise violate
any provision of this chapter, or who shall violate any lawful regulation or
order made by any of the officers provided for in this chapter, shall be guilty
of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined as provided in §
1-14.
(Prior Code, § 10-1)
§ 10-2. RELIEF IN THE COURTS.
   No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this chapter shall interfere with the
right of the city also to apply to the proper courts of the state for a
mandamus, an injunction, or other appropriate action against such person.
(Prior Code, § 10-2)
§§ 10-3 THROUGH 10-24. RESERVED.

§ 10-25. INTERNATIONAL BUILDING CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE.
   (A)   There is hereby adopted by reference the International Building Code,
2006 edition, with Appendices C, D, E, F, H, I, issued by the International
Code Council, Inc., as the building code for the city. The building code shall
be fully applicable and enforceable in controlling the construction and repair
of all buildings and other structures in the city, save and except such
portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified, or amended, as fully as if set
out at length herein.
   (B)   If any provision of current ordinances of the city are in conflict
with the provisions of the building code, except as provided in this article,
the provisions of the building code shall prevail.
(Prior Code, § 10-25) (Ord. 2004-546, passed 11-1-2004)
Statutory reference:
   Building code, adoption by cities, see 11 O.S. § 14-107 and 74 O.S. § 324.8
§ 10-26. CITY INSPECTOR.
   Whenever reference is made to the duties of the building official or
inspector in the building code, it shall mean the City Inspector. The City
Inspector shall be the responsible official for enforcing the provisions of the
building code.
(Prior Code, § 10-26)
§ 10-27. OTHER CITY OFFICIALS’ CODE RESPONSIBILITIES.
   When reference is made to the duties of certain officials named in any of
the codes adopted by this chapter, the designated officials of the city who
have duties corresponding to those of the named official in the code shall be
deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of
the code is concerned.
(Prior Code, § 10-27)
§ 10-28. CODE APPEALS.
   (A)   Appeal of any decisions of the City Inspector or other appropriate
officials concerning any of the codes in this chapter may go before a Code
Appeals Board, consisting of five members as follows:
      (1)   Builder;
      (2)   Licensed electrician;
      (3)   Licensed plumber; and
      (4)   Two members at large.
   (B)   The Mayor shall appoint the members, with the approval of the City
Council. The Code Appeals Board shall select a Chair by majority vote of the
members. A quorum shall consist of a majority of the Code Appeals Board. Any
individual affected by the codes adopted in this chapter, or the decision of
the Board, or a member of the Code Appeals Board, may appeal any decisions of
the Board to the City Council for a final determination.
(Prior Code, § 10-28)
§ 10-29. PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Before proceeding with the excavation for the erection of, or the repair,
enlargement, or removal of any building or structure within the city, a permit
must first be obtained from the Building Department. If the operations allowed
under such permit are not begun within three months thereafter, such permit
shall become null and void. If such work is to be resumed, a new permit must be
obtained and the regular fee incident thereto shall be collected. The
responsibility for obtaining such permit shall be shared jointly with the owner
of the premises, his or her agent, and the builder or contractor erecting the
improvement, and either or both are subject to the penalty imposed upon the
failure to obtain such permit.
(Prior Code, § 10-29)
§ 10-30. APPLICATION FOR PERMITS.
   All applications for permits shall be in writing upon an official blank form
supplied by the City Inspector.
(Prior Code, § 10-30)
§ 10-31. STREET NUMBER REQUIRED.
   Permits shall not be granted or issued until proper street numbers are
assigned as required by ordinance. Assigned numbers shall be written and
included in the permit application under the section “Remarks.”
(Prior Code, § 10-31)
§ 10-32. PERMITS OUTSIDE OF CITY; WHEN REQUIRED.
   It is required and is the responsibility of the homeowner or contractor to
obtain permits from the city for new home construction or remodeling, and for
electrical, mechanical, and plumbing on the dwelling, and to request regular
inspections in the construction of new homes and the remodeling of homes, if
such property is so located, to be furnished water or sewer service by the
city.
(Prior Code, § 10-32)
§ 10-33. WHEN PERMIT SECURED.
   All building permits will be purchased before new construction is started.
Such building permits will not be issued until arrangements have been made for
the new water meter set or the City Inspector approves such meter on the
construction location.
(Prior Code, § 10-33)
§ 10-34. NUMBER OF HOMES TO A WATER LINE.
   In areas where water is furnished by the city, there shall be a maximum of
ten homes connected to a two-inch water line.
(Prior Code, § 10-34)
§ 10-35. BUILDING PERMIT FEES.
   (A)   The fees which apply for building and alterations are on file in the
City Clerk’s office.
   (B)   The fees are doubled when work that requires a permit by code is
started prior to obtaining the permit.
(Prior Code, § 10-35) (Ord. 768-1/2, passed 2-4-1986; Ord. 2004-852, passed 3-
1-2004; Ord. 2010-26, passed 4-5-2010)
§ 10-36. MANUFACTURED HOME PERMITS REQUIRED OUTSIDE PARKS; REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL
MANUFACTURED HOMES.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to park, use, or occupy any manufactured
home within the city limits except, in a manufactured home park or area
designated by the city zoning ordinance, set out in Appendix B to this code
pertaining to zoning, without first having obtained a permit to do so.
   (B)   A permit must be obtained by the manufactured home occupant for any
location outside a manufactured home park by making application to the City
Clerk for such permit.
   (C)   No permit shall be issued unless the following provisions are met.
      (1)   No permit for parking a manufactured home outside of a manufactured
home park or designated zoned area within the city shall be issued, except upon
written consent of 70% of the owners of property within a radius of 300 feet of
the location of such manufactured home.
      (2)   The owner must produce proof in writing that the particular area in
which the manufactured home is to be located does not have plat restrictions
prohibiting the moving in of the structure, or would violate other plat
restrictions which provide for minimum size, type of construction, cost of
construction, or other related matters.
      (3)   The applicant must produce proof in writing that he or she is the
owner of record of either the particular lot on which the manufactured home is
to be located or the owner of the manufactured home structure.
      (4)   The particular lot on which the manufactured home is to be located
must be a lot of record, free of other dwellings or principal structures, and
of sufficient size to comply with the provisions of the city zoning regulations
set out in Appendix B to this code.
      (5)   Every manufactured home within the corporate limits of the city,
whether in a manufactured home park or without, shall be skirted or enclosed
from the floor to the ground within 60 days of placement so that the area
thereunder cannot be used for the occupancy of animals, and in such a manner
that the underside of the manufactured home cannot be observed from the street.
Skirting material shall be of a durable, waterproof, and fire-resistant nature.
      (6)   All electrical, water, sewer, and gas connections shall conform to
the present requirements set forth by ordinances of the city.
      (7)   (a)   Every manufactured home within the corporate limits of the
city, whether in a manufactured home park or without, must have anchors of
sufficient quantity and strength to resist a wind velocity of 90 mph imposed on
the structure. The minimum number of tie-downs is as follows.
 
                                 No. Frame Ties Each Side No. Over the Top Side
Ten-Foot and 12-Foot Wide Units:
30 to 50 feet long               Five                     Four
51 to 60 feet long               Six                      Four
12-Foot and 14-Foot Wide Units:
60 to 70 feet long               Seven                    Four
Above 70 feet long               One tie-down every ten feet
 
         (b)   The anchors shall be placed and secured within 60 days after
placement of the manufactured home. Tie straps or cables, ground anchors, and
all included hardware of the system must be designated for a holding capacity
of not less than 4,800 pounds per point.
      (8)   The manufactured home shall be supported by foundation piers under
at least the two widest spread structure under carriage beams of the
manufactured home. Each foundation pier shall have a solid masonry block
footing with area bearing on the ground of not less than two blocks in width,
with each block eight inches by 16 inches by four inches thick. Distance
between piers shall be not more than ten feet center to center, and end piers
shall be within five feet of the end of the manufactured home. In no case
should there be fewer piers than the number of anchor points of over the top
tie-downs. Pier construction above the solid masonry block footing shall be of
termite-resistant material. The bearing area of the pier shaft resting on the
footing shall be not less than nine-tenths of a square foot in area.
      (9)   Upon meeting provisions of subsections (C)(1), (C)(2), (C)(3), and
(C)(4) above of this section, the manufactured home may be placed on the
particular lot, and the owner will be given 60 days to meet the balance of the
provisions of this section. Upon completion of all of the provisions contained
herein and inspected by the City Inspector, the permit shall be issued.
   (D)   At any time a manufactured home located on a lot is removed from that
particular lot and not replaced with another manufactured home within one year,
the provisions of this section shall be met before a new permit is issued.
   (E)   The cost of the permit is on file in the City Clerk’s office and shall
be payable at the time of its issuance.
(Prior Code, § 10-36)
§ 10-37. INTERNATIONAL EXISTING BUILDING CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE.
   A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the
City Clerk, being marked and designated as the International Existing Building
Code, 2015 edition, including Appendix Chapters B and C (see International
Existing Building Code § 101.6, 2015 edition), as the existing building code of
the city for regulating and governing the repair, alteration, change of
occupancy, addition, and relocation of existing buildings, including historic
buildings, as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and
collections of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions,
penalties, conditions, and terms of said Existing Building Code on file in the
office of the City Clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part
hereof, as if fully set out in this legislation.
(Ord. 2021-001, passed 6-21-2021)

§ 10-61. INTERNATIONAL PLUMBING CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE.
   There is hereby adopted by reference the International Plumbing Code, 2006
edition, with Appendices E, F, G, issued by the International Code Council,
Inc., as the plumbing code for the city. The plumbing code shall be fully
applicable and enforceable in governing plumbing and sewers in the city, save
and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified, or amended, as
fully as if set out at length herein. If any provision of the ordinances of the
city are in conflict with any provision of the plumbing code, except as
provided in this article, the provisions of the plumbing code shall prevail.
(Prior Code, § 10-61) (Ord. 2004-546, passed 11-1-2004)

§ 10-63. PERMITS, FEES.
   (A)   The fees applicable to plumbing inspections and permits are on file in
the City Clerk’s office.
   (B)   The fees are doubled when work that requires a permit by code is
started prior to obtaining the permit.
(Prior Code, § 10-63) (Ord. 768-1/2, passed 2-4-1986; Ord. 2004-852, passed 3-

§ 10-64. PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   The Plumbing Inspector shall collect from the contracting plumber, for
whom he or she performs the work coming within the duties of the office at the
time application is made to him or her for the performance of such service, the
applicable fees. The fee shall be paid before the permit shall be issued.
   (B)   It is unlawful for any person to make or cause to be made any
connections with any main or lateral sewer system of the city without first
having obtained a permit from the City Plumbing Inspector for the particular
job to be installed.
(Prior Code, § 10-64)
§ 10-65. PLUMBING CONTRACTOR CITY REGISTRATION.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to engage in installing plumbing as
described below within the city, unless it is a home in which he or she is
residing, and of which he or she is the legal owner of said property, or is
registered with the city and has a current and valid certificate of
registration issued by the city for a plumbing contractor.
   (B)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      GAS PIPING. All natural gas piping within or adjacent to any building,
structure, or conveyance on the premises up to the connection with a natural
gas meter, regulator, or other source of supply.
      PLUMBING.
         (a)   All piping, fixtures, appurtenances, and appliances for, and in
connection with, a supply of water within or adjacent to any building,
structure, or conveyance on the premises and to the connection with a water
main or other source of supply;
         (b)   All piping, fixtures, appurtenances, and appliances for sanitary
drainage or storm drainage facilities, including venting systems for such
facilities, within or adjacent to any building, structure, or conveyance on the
premises and to the connection with a public disposal system or other
acceptable terminal; and
         (c)   The installation, repair, maintenance, and renovation of all
piping, fixtures, appurtenances, and appliances for a supply of water, or for
the disposal of waste water, liquid waste, or sewage within or adjacent to any
building, structure, or conveyance on the premises and to the source of supply
of water or point of disposal of wastes.
   (C)   Only a person who has a current and valid license as a plumbing
contractor issued by the state’s Construction Industries Board may register as
such with the city.
   (D)   Upon application to the city, the applicant shall give full name,
residence address, and place of business address. and in case of removal from
one place to another, shall make a corresponding change in the register
accordingly and the payment of the required fee to the City Clerk’s office. The
city shall register such applicants and issue to them certificates of
registration.
   (E)   City certificates shall not be valid after the termination or
expiration of state licenses of certificates. Registration certificates of
plumbing contractors issued as provided herein shall expire one year from date
of issuance.
   (F)   For all certificates or registration authorized by this section there
will be charged and collected the following fees: Plumbing contractor: $100 for
the initial year and a $50 per year renewal fee thereafter (if not renewed
within one year, renewal will be $100).
   (G)   A plumbing contractor must provide the name and license number of each
worker employed by contractor as a plumbing journeyman or a plumbing
apprentice.
   (H)   Any violation of any provision contained in this section is an offense
against the city; upon conviction of any such offense, the violator shall be
punished by a fine as follows:
      (1)   First offense: $200; and
      (2)   Second and subsequent offenses: $300.
(Prior Code, § 10-65) (Ord. 2008-16, passed 3-3-2008)

§ 10-91. MECHANICAL CONTRACTOR CITY REGISTRATION.
   (A)   (1)   It is unlawful for any person to engage in mechanical work as
defined in subsections (A)(1) through (A)(4) below of this section, within the
city limits unless he or she is registered with the city office and has a
current and valid certificate of registration.
      (2)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
         GAS PIPING. All natural gas piping within or adjacent to any building,
structure, or conveyance on the premises up to the connection with a natural
gas meter, regulator, or other source of supply.
         GROUND SOURCE PIPING. Piping buried below the earth’s surface or
submerged in a water well, lake, or pond and used in conjunction with a heat
pump to provide heating, ventilation, and/or air conditioning to a structure.
         HVAC or HEATING, VENTILATION, AND AIR CONDITION. The process of
treating air by controlling its temperature, humidity, and cleanliness and of
supplying such air to spaces for human occupancy by means of an integrated
system or air conditioning and ventilation equipment, accessories, and control
devices.
         MECHANICAL WORK. The installation, maintenance, repair, or renovation,
in whole or in part, of any heating system, cooling system, mechanical
refrigeration system, or ventilation system, or any equipment or piping
carrying chilled water, air for ventilation purposes, or natural gas, or the
installation, maintenance, repair, or renovation of process piping used to
carry any liquid, substance, or material, including steam and hot water used
for space heating purposes not under the jurisdiction of the Department of
Labor, provided that minor maintenance and repairs are excluded.
         REFRIGERATION SYSTEM. A system employing fluid which normally is
vaporized and liquified in an air conditioning system, food preservation
measure, or manufacturing process.
         SHEET METAL. The ferrous and non-ferrous ductwork and components which
house and ventilate air conditioning systems, both assembled and custom
fabricated.
   (B)   Only a person who has a current and valid license as a mechanical
contractor issued by the state’s Construction Industries Board may register as
such with the city.
   (C)   Upon application to the city, the applicant shall give full name,
residence address, and place of business address, and in case of removal from
one place to another, shall make a corresponding change in the register
accordingly and the payment of the required fee to the City Clerk’s office. The
city shall register such applicants and issue to them certificates of
registration.
   (D)   City certificates shall not be valid after the termination or
expiration of state licenses or certificates. Registration certificates of
mechanical contractors issued as provided herein shall expire after one year
from date of issuance.
   (E)   For all certificates of registration authorized by this section there
shall be charged and collected the following fees: Mechanical contractor: $100
for the initial year and a $50 per year renewal fee thereafter (if not renewed
within one year, renewal will be $100).
   (F)   A mechanical contractor must provide the name and license number of
each worker employed by contractor as a mechanical journeyman or a mechanical
apprentice.
   (G)   Any violation of any provision contained in this section is an offense
against the city; upon conviction of any such offense, the violator shall be
punished by a fine as follows:
      (1)   First offense: $200; and
      (2)   Second and subsequent offenses: $300.
(Prior Code, § 10-91) (Ord. 2008-17, passed 3-3-2008)

§ 10-115. ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; RENEWAL; REVOCATION.
   Upon the making and approval of the aforesaid bond, a gas fitter’s license,
valid for a period of one year, shall be issued by the City Clerk upon the
payment of the fee hereinbefore provided. The license may be renewed from year
to year upon compliance with all the terms and conditions of this article, upon
the payment of a sum of $1 to cover the expense of such renewal; provided
further, that at any time, the Gas Inspector, with the approval and consent of
the City Council, may revoke and annul the gas fitter license, and the holder
of the license shall be prohibited by this article from doing further gas
fitting within the city corporate limits.
(Prior Code, § 10-115)

LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS
§ 10-144. PERSON WHO MUST COMPLY WITH STATE LAW AND POSSESS ANY STATE LICENSE
OR PERMIT REQUIRED BY LAW.
   It is unlawful for any person to manufacture, fabricate, assemble, install,
or repair any system, container, apparatus, or appliance to be used for the
transportation, storage, dispensing, or utilization of liquefied petroleum gas,
or to transport, handle, or store such gas, unless such person has complied
with and complies with all provisions of the law and ordinances relating
thereto, and has any license or permit which may be required by state law. The
National Fire Protection Association Pamphlet No. 58, Storage and Handling of
Liquefied Petroleum Gases Rules and Regulations, also adopted by the State
Liquefied Petroleum Gas Board, shall have full force and effect within this
city. Any violation of these rules and regulations shall be deemed a violation
of the ordinances of the city and shall be punished accordingly.
(Prior Code, § 10-144)
Statutory reference:
   State rules, liquefied petroleum gas, see 52 O.S. §§ 420.1 et seq.
§ 10-145. INSPECTION; FEE.
   All liquefied petroleum installations within the city, upon completion,
shall be inspected by the Plumbing Inspector, or by the Gas Inspector if a Gas
Inspector is appointed, and shall not be used by the occupants until approved
by the Inspector as complying with §
10-144 and the rules and regulations adopted thereby. The fee for such
inspection is on file in the City Clerk’s office.
(Prior Code, § 10-145)

the Gas Inspector before the gas is turned on or into such extension.
   (B)   All manufactured homes must be inspected by the Gas Inspector prior to
turning on the gas or hooking up to a meter. A licensed plumber or gas fitter
must obtain a permit before this inspection.

§ 10-202. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR. Any person engaged in the business of installing or
servicing or repairing, or contracting to install, repair, or service any
electrical wiring, conduits, devices, fixtures, overhead or underground wiring
systems, or any other electrical energy.
   ELECTRICAL WIRING. All wiring, fixtures, conduits, appliances, devices,
equipment, overhead or underground wiring system, generating or any other
equipment in connection with the general distribution or utilization of
electrical emergency.
   JOURNEYMAN ELECTRICIAN. Every person doing any work of installing,
repairing, servicing, or maintaining any electrical wiring, conduits, devices,
fixtures, overhead or underground wiring systems, or any other electrical
energy.
(Prior Code, § 10-202)
§ 10-203. BUILDING INSPECTOR TO SERVE AS ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR; DUTIES.
   (A)   For the purposes of carrying out the provisions of this article and
for the better protection of the city’s electrical wiring and electrical
installations, the Building Inspector shall serve as the Electrical Inspector.
   (B)   The Electrical Inspector shall have the right to designate any
qualified person to make the actual inspections and report to him or her; and
acting on such report, he or she may carry out the provisions of this article.
The Inspector shall have the inspection and testing of all electrical wiring
and electrical installations done within the city. He or she shall inspect all
work coming within his or her jurisdiction or cause such inspection to be done
and shall cause all electrical wiring and installations work to be done and
performed in accordance with the terms and provisions of this article.
(Prior Code, § 10-203)
Statutory reference:
   State electrical requirements, licensing, see 59 O.S. §§ 1680 to 1696
§ 10-204. ELECTRICAL PERMIT FEES.
   (A)   The fees for all permit applications and inspections are on file in
the City Clerk’s office.
   (B)   The fees are doubled when work that requires a permit by code is
started prior to obtaining the permit.
   (C)   It is unlawful for any person to make or cause to be made any
electrical connections, wiring, or electrical installations within the city
without first obtaining such permit from the Inspector for the particular job
to be installed.
(Prior Code, § 10-204) (Ord. 768-1/2, passed 2-4-1986; Ord. 2004-852, passed 3-
1-2004; Ord. 2010-26, passed 4-5-2010)
§ 10-205. ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR; LICENSES; FEES.
   (A)   All electrical contractors, before being granted any permit by the
Inspector to work or make any connection, must first present a current state
license issued by the State Department of Health, then pay to the City Clerk a
license fee which is on file in the City Clerk’s office to engage in the work
of an electrical contractor before commencing or doing any electrical work or
making any electrical connections in the city. The contractor shall execute to
the city a bond in the amount which is on file in the City Clerk’s office
conditioned upon the good and faithful performance of all work to be done by
him or her in the city and hold the city harmless to all damages arising from
any work done or caused to be done by such electrical contractor in the city.
   (B)   No registration shall be granted for less than one year; such
registration may be renewed each year within a 30-day period before expiration
of the payment of the required fee.
(Prior Code, § 10-205) (Ord. 781, passed 6-20-1988)
§ 10-206. PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No permit shall be issued to any electrical contractor or any other person
to make connection or do any other work of any kind whatever in the city until
a written application signed by the contractor or person, together with a
statement of the work to be performed, shall be filed with the Inspector. No
part of such work shall be executed until the Inspector shall have authorized
the same to be done. Each application shall bear the owner’s name together with
the lot and block number of the property on which the work is to be done.
(Prior Code, § 10-206)
§ 10-207. NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE.
   No permit shall be issued for electrical wiring and electrical installations
and the methods of installation thereof unless and until the same shall conform
to the approved standards provided for in the National Electrical Code, 2005
edition, the electrical code and all of the provisions thereof being made a
part hereof and incorporated herein and adopted by the city, as its standards,
the same as though set out in full herein.
(Prior Code, § 10-207)
§ 10-208. ONE HUNDRED-AMPERE PANEL REQUIRED.
   In any new construction in the city and any remodeling of any existing
structure which necessitates the alteration of any panel, there shall be
installed, as a minimum requirement, a 100-ampere panel.
(Prior Code, § 10-208)
§ 10-209. REQUIREMENTS TO BE NOTED ON PERMIT.
   Any wiring required to be done shall be noted on the building permit secured
therefor, and it is hereby made the duty of the Building Inspector to enforce
this article.
(Prior Code, § 10-209)

   (B)   Only a person who has a current and valid license as an electrical
contractor issued by the State Construction Industries Board may register as
such with the city.
   (C)   Upon application to the city, the applicant shall give full name,
residence address, and place of business address, and in case of removal from
one place to another, shall make a corresponding change in the register
accordingly and the payment of the required fee to the City Clerk’s office. The
city shall register such applicants and issue to them certificates of
registration.
   (D)   City certificates shall not be valid after the termination or
expiration of state licenses or certificates. Registration certificates of
electrical contractors issued as provided herein shall expire after one year
from date of issuance.
   (E)   For all certificates of registration authorized by this section, there
will be charged and collected the following fees: Electrical contractor: $100
for the initial year and a $50 per year renewal fee thereafter (if not renewed
within one year, renewal will be $100).
   (F)   An electrical contractor must provide the name and license number of

apprentice.
   (G)   Any violation of any provision contained in this section is an offense
against the city; upon conviction of any such offense, the violator shall be
punished by a fine as follows:
      (1)   First offense: $200; and
      (2)   Second and subsequent offenses: $300.
(Prior Code, § 10-210) (Ord. 2008-15, passed 3-3-2008)
§ 10-211. LICENSE REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION.
   Any license issued in accordance with this article may be suspended or
revoked by the City Council for reasons of incompetency or for failure to
comply with the provisions of this article or any applicable ordinance or
regulation; but no license shall be revoked unless the licensee shall have been
notified in writing of the charges against him or her and has been given an
opportunity for hearing, except that failure to maintain the surety bond
required herein in full force and effect shall be grounds for the summary
suspension of such license. Any licensee whose license has been revoked shall
not again be licensed within a period of six weeks from date of such action.
(Prior Code, § 10-211)
§ 10-212. INSTALLATIONS TO WHICH THIS ARTICLE APPLIES.
   The provisions of this article shall apply to all installations of
electrical conductors, wiring, conduits, fixtures, devices, appliances, or
other electrical equipment or materials, hereinafter defined as electrical
wiring, within or on public or private buildings, structures, or premises,
except as follows.
   (A)   The provisions of this article shall not apply to the installation,
alteration, or repair of electrical wiring for the generation and distribution
of electrical current up to and including the meters, where such work is an
integral part of the system owned and operated by an electrical public service
corporation, or the light and power department of any city or town in the
state, in rendering its duly authorized service as such.
   (B)   The provisions of this article shall not apply to the installation,
alteration, or repair of electrical equipment and devices for the operation of
signals for the transmission of intelligence (where such work is an integral
part of the communications system owned and operated by a privately or publicly
owned telephone or telegraph company in rendering its duly authorized service
as such) or to the signal communication systems railroad and pipe line
companies not used by the public or for hire.
   (C)   The provisions of this article shall not apply to the installation,
alteration, or repair of electrical equipment used for radio transmission in
broadcasting or transmitting station.
   (D)   The provisions of this article shall not apply to emergency minor
repair work.
   (E)   The provisions of this article shall not apply to the installation,
alteration, or repair of the fire and police signaling communication systems or
central station electric protection service companies.
(Prior Code, § 10-212)
§ 10-213. ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR TO ORDER DANGEROUS INSTALLATIONS CORRECTED.
   The Electrical Inspector shall at all times have access to any building or
structure under construction to properly examine the same as to the electrical
wiring and installations. Any defective work in connection therewith the
Inspector may find that, in the opinion of the Inspector, is a nuisance or
detriment to the public safety of the occupants of the building or adjoining
buildings, then he or she shall order the defects corrected and put in a safe
condition.
(Prior Code, § 10-213)
§§ 10-214 THROUGH 10-234. RESERVED.

§ 10-235. INTERNATIONAL RESIDENTIAL CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE.
   There is hereby adopted by reference the International Residential Code,
2006 edition with Appendices A, B, C, E, G, H, issued by the International Code
Council, Inc., as the dwelling code for the city. The residential code shall be
fully applicable and enforceable in governing housing in the city, as fully as
if set out at length herein, save and except such portions as are hereinafter
deleted, modified, or amended. If any provision of the ordinances of the city
are in conflict with the provisions of the one-family and two-family dwelling
code, except as provided in this article, the provisions of the dwelling code
shall prevail.
(Prior Code, § 10-235) (Ord. 744, passed 2-4-1980; Ord. 2004-546, passed 11-1-
2004)

§ 10-264. INTERNATIONAL MECHANICAL CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE.
   There is hereby adopted by reference the International Mechanical Code, 2006
edition, with Appendix A, issued by the International Code Council, Inc, as the
mechanical code for the city. The mechanical code shall be fully applicable and

(Prior Code, § 10-264) (Ord. 2004-546, passed 11-1-2004)
§ 10-265. MECHANICAL PERMIT FEES.
   (A)   The fees which shall apply for one-family and two-family dwellings are
on file in the City Clerk’s office.
   (B)   The fees which apply for other than one-family and two-family
dwellings are on file in the City Clerk’s office.
   (C)   The fees are doubled when work that requires a permit by code is
started prior to obtaining the permit.
(Prior Code, § 10-265) (Ord. 768-1/2, passed 2-4-1986; Ord. 2004-852, passed 3-
1-2004; Ord. 2010-26, passed 4-5-2010)

ARTICLE IX: MOVING BUILDINGS
Section
   
10-322.   Permit required
   
10-323.   Application; fee
   
10-324.   Bond
   
10-325.   Passageway for traffic
   
10-326.   Red lights; notification of Fire Chief
   
10-327.   Trees; utilities
   
10-328.   Injury to streets
   
10-329.   Time limit for moving
   
10-330.   Sundays and holidays
   
10-331.   Fire Chief to be informed
   
10-332.   Liability
   
10-333.   Violations
§ 10-322. PERMIT REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person, as principal, agent, laborer, servant, or
employee, to use or occupy any of the streets, avenues, or alleys, or other
public places within the limits of the city for the purpose of moving any
building, structure, or edifice, or any other object or thing, of any kind or
character, impossible to be moved and transported by ordinary vehicle
conveyances, or to so use and occupy any portions of the streets, avenues,
public ways, places, or alleys within the limits of this city with any
equipment of any kind or character to be used or placed thereon for the purpose
of effecting the transportation of such structures, buildings, edifices, or
other things as described in this section without having first obtained a
permit from the City Clerk for that purpose.
(Prior Code, § 10-322)
§ 10-323. APPLICATION; FEE.
   A moving permit shall be obtained by making an application for the same in
writing, reciting therein the character of the thing or object to be moved or
transported along, over, or through any street or alley. It shall further
recite the proposed route of such transportation and the place where any
equipment used in effecting such moving shall be placed and secured. Such
permit shall be issued upon compliance with all the required conditions and the
payment of a fee which is on file in the City Clerk’s office. If work is
started prior to receiving the required permit, the fee is doubled.
(Prior Code, § 10-323) (Ord. 2004-852, passed 3-1-2004)
§ 10-324. BOND.
   No permit shall be issued, as provided for in this article, until the
applicant shall have deposited with the City Clerk a cash bond in the sum which
is on file in the City Clerk’s office to protect the city and cover loss or
damage accruing to it or its citizens by reason of any negligence in connection
with such moving or transportation or prohibited occupancy of the streets,
sidewalks, and any and all property therein.
(Prior Code, § 10-324)
§ 10-325. PASSAGEWAY FOR TRAFFIC.
   It shall be the duty of any person to whom a permit has been issued to move
any building across any street, alley, or avenue to provide sufficient
passageway on one side of the building while the same is being moved, to the
end that traffic will not be unduly interrupted and so that vehicles may effect
a passage by the side of such building and over such street. Where it is
necessary to allow a building to remain overnight on the street, it shall be
the duty of the person moving same to so plan the work that a suitable place
can be reached before night where a passageway can be provided.
(Prior Code, § 10-325)
§ 10-326. RED LIGHTS; NOTIFICATION OF FIRE CHIEF.
   It shall be the duty of the permit holder to place red lights in plainly
visible positions for not less than 200 feet on each side of the building or
structure which is being moved at the close of day and to keep the lights
burning throughout the entire night and until one hour after sunrise on the
following morning. Such lights shall be so placed and maintained that the view
of the lights will not be in any sense obstructed. Provided, that if necessary,
as many additional lights as will enable any person of reasonable and ordinary
prudence to take notice of the obstruction shall be placed at such other points
on the building or structure. It shall be the further duty of the house mover,
or his or her agent, to station a sufficient number of persons on guard and to
establish such notices by placard or boards in the immediate vicinity of the
moving activities as will be necessary to apprize any reasonable person of
potential danger that might be incurred by coming any closer to the moving
operations or buildings being moved or to any of the instruments or agencies
used in the moving of the same. The moving contractor shall also notify the
Fire Chief of the location of such building.
(Prior Code, § 10-326)
§ 10-327. TREES; UTILITIES.
   The person who may have a permit to move a building or structure over any
street within the city shall, by virtue of such permit, derive no right to
injure or impair the condition or usefulness of any shade tree or electric
light, telephone, or telegraph lines or poles. No tree of any kind shall be
cut, trimmed, bruised, or scarred under any circumstances, without the
expressed permission, in writing, of the owner of the tree. In all cases where
it is necessary to remove any electric light, telephone, or telegraph equipment
or construction, it shall be the duty of the person moving such building or
structure to give not less than 24 hours’ notice to the public utility company
or person owning or operating the equipment or construction. The notice shall
state the location of the equipment or construction which is necessary to be
moved, or temporarily changed or altered, and the day on which it is desired to
have such clearance made as well as the amount of time which it will be
necessary to keep such space clear. It shall further be the duty of the person
moving the building or structure to deposit, with the City Clerk, an amount of
money estimated necessary to cover the cost of such changing or moving of
public utility overhead equipment or construction and replacing it in its
former condition, not exceeding the sum which is on file in the City Clerk’s
office. Upon such deposit being made with the City Clerk and such notice
delivered to the owner or operator of the electric light, telephone, or
telegraph poles and line construction, it shall be the duty of the person
owning or operating the light, telephone, or telegraph overhead construction to
make such temporary changes as are reasonably necessary to comply with the
representations set forth in the notice made and delivered to him or her.
(Prior Code, § 10-327)
§ 10-328. INJURY TO STREETS.
   No permit shall be issued to move any building which, in the judgment of the
City Engineer or City Business Manager, might by any chance result in any
injury to the pavements, bridges, conduits, or other street improvements within
the city.
(Prior Code, § 10-328)
§ 10-329. TIME LIMIT FOR MOVING.
   At the time of application for a permit, it shall be the duty of the mover
of any building or structure to estimate the reasonable time required for the
moving of the building from its present location to its proposed location and
shall state in his or her application for a permit what he or she deems to be
such reasonable time. The permit shall especially provide that the building
shall be, from the time any part of the street is used for the moving of same,
cleared from any and all of the streets of the city within a number of days
specified therein, Sundays and holidays excepted. The mover shall pay the sum
which is on file in the City Clerk’s office for each and every day all or any
part of which the building or structure remains on the street in excess of the
number of days allowed in the permit, and his or her cash deposit, in addition
to his or her bond, shall be made liable for the payment of the amount. Nothing
but an act of God shall be a defense against the payment of the sums.
(Prior Code, § 10-329)
§ 10-330. SUNDAYS AND HOLIDAYS.
   The City Clerk shall not issue any permit on any day which, according to the
estimated number of days required to move the building or structure, when
counted for the date of the permit, includes a Sunday or legal holiday,
provided that this shall apply where the permit provides that the persons
moving such house shall begin on the day of the permit. Provided that, when a
day is set on which the person moving the building shall begin to move the
building or structure and the day is different from the date of issuing the
permit, then no permit shall be issued in such way as to include a Sunday or
holiday within the time allowed for moving the building. Provided that, where
the number of days shall exceed five, the provisions of this section shall not
apply.
(Prior Code, § 10-330)
§ 10-331. FIRE CHIEF TO BE INFORMED.
   In each and every case where any person desiring to move any building shall
have a permit issued for the move, he or she shall show his or her permit to
the Chief of the Fire Department. If, for any reason, any delay is occasioned
by any unforeseen contingency, it shall be his or her further duty to inform
the Fire Chief of such delay and disclose information on the true condition of
the streets and alleys for fire prevention purposes.
(Prior Code, § 10-331)
§ 10-332. LIABILITY.
   No provisions or conditions of this section shall be construed so as to
limit the civil liability of any person moving any house on or over the city
streets, avenues, and alleys from any and all damages which may result as the
proximate cause of such acts to any person or his or her property or to the
city.
(Prior Code, § 10-332)
§ 10-333. VIOLATIONS.
   Any person who shall move any building or structure onto, on, over, or
across any street or alley without having complied with the provisions of this
article shall be guilty of an offense. The failure to comply with any provision
mentioned within this article shall be a separate offense and, upon conviction,
shall be punished accordingly.
(Prior Code, § 10-333)

§ 12-1. SHORT WEIGHTS AND MEASURES PROHIBITED.
   It is unlawful for any person to sell, or offer for sale, any food, fuel,
clothing, or any other commodity which does not weigh or measure fully as much,
according to standard weights and measures of the state, as the weight or
measure for which it is sold or offered for sale.
(Prior Code, § 12-1)
§§ 12-2 THROUGH 12-20. RESERVED.

§ 12-21. LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful for any person, either as principal or agent, or his, her, or
their servants or employees, to conduct or carry on from door-to-door any
trade, occupation, or business hereinafter enumerated without first having
procured a license from the City Clerk, as provided in this article.
(Prior Code, § 12-21)
Statutory reference:
   Municipal authority to tax and regulate businesses, professions, and
occupations, see 11 O.S. §§ 22-106 and 22-107
§ 12-22. APPLICATION, FEE, ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   Every person desiring to engage in any trade, occupation, or business on a
door-to-door basis, as hereinafter enumerated, shall first make application for
a license to the City Clerk on application forms furnished by the City Clerk
and shall pay to the City Clerk a license examination and investigation fee
which is on file in the City Clerk’s office. It is the duty of the City Clerk,
upon receipt of such application, and where required, such license examination
and investigation fee, and if same is deemed satisfactory and acceptable, and
upon fulfillment of any other requirements of the ordinances of the city, if
any, to issue a license to the applicant.
(Prior Code, § 12-22)
§ 12-23. EXPIRATION DATE.
   All annual licenses shall expire on June 30, following their issuance.
(Prior Code, § 12-23)
§ 12-24. EXAMINATION AND INVESTIGATION FEE.
   Every person desiring to engage in any trade, occupation, or business, as
set forth below, must first secure a license from the City Clerk for the
designated occupations or businesses, and in addition thereto, a license
examination and investigation fee for all persons from outside the city shall
be paid. The fee for all hawkers, solicitors, and peddlers of goods, wares, or
merchandise, on a door-to-door basis, including the sale of books, maps, or
magazines, and for the repair, alteration, or renovation of any article shall
be on file in the City Clerk’s office.
(Prior Code, § 12-24)
§ 12-25. LICENSE NOT TO BE USED BY OTHERS.
   No license issued under the provisions of this article shall be used at any
time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued.
(Prior Code, § 12-25)
§ 12-26. HOURS OF SOLICITATION.
   All solicitations made under license provisions shall not be earlier than 9:
00 a.m. or later than 9:00 p.m.
(Prior Code, § 12-26)
§ 12-27. PERSONS UNDER 16 YEARS OF AGE.
   No license shall be issued to any person under the age of 16 years, and it
is unlawful for any licensee to employ or allow any person under the age of 16
years to be employed as a huckster, peddler, hawker, helper, or solicitor in
connection with the business licensed thereunder.
(Prior Code, § 12-27)
§ 12-28. EXEMPTIONS.
   All churches, civic organizations, charitable campaign fund drives, and
youth organizations are first required to notify the City Police Department of
any house-to-house drive for funds to be undertaken within the city.
(Prior Code, § 12-28)
§ 12-29. UNLAWFUL TO SELL FROM VEHICLE; WHOLESALERS EXEMPT.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale, at retail,
any commodity from any truck, trailer, or other vehicle while such vehicle is
parked on any street or alley of the city.
   (B)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to wholesalers or
wholesale distributors supplying their customers for resale at retail, nor to
the transportation and distribution, at wholesale or retail, of milk and dairy
products, nor to the sale, in any zoned residential area, of vegetables and
fruit by the producer or grower thereof.
(Prior Code, § 12-29)
§§ 12-30 THROUGH 12-46. RESERVED.

their servants or employees, to conduct or carry any trade, occupation, or
business hereinafter enumerated without first having procured a license from
the City Clerk of the city, as provided in this article.
(Prior Code, § 12-47)
§ 12-48. APPLICATION, FEE, ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   Every person desiring to engage in any trade, occupation, or business as
hereinafter enumerated shall first make application to the City Clerk on an
application form furnished by the City Clerk for a license and shall pay to the
City Clerk any license examination and investigation fee herein prescribed. It
is the duty of the City Clerk, upon receipt of such application, and where
required, such license examination and investigation fee, and if same is deemed
satisfactory and acceptable, and upon fulfillment of any other requirements of
the ordinances of the city, if any, to issue a license to the applicant.
(Prior Code, § 12-48)
§ 12-49. EXPIRATION DATE.

(Prior Code, § 12-49)
§ 12-50. EXAMINATION AND INVESTIGATION FEE.
   Every person desiring to engage in any trade, occupation, or business, as
set forth in this section, must first secure a license from the City Clerk for
the following designated occupations or businesses, and in addition thereto, a
license examination and investigation fee for all persons from outside the city
shall be paid in amounts which are on file in the City Clerk’s office:
   (A)   Circuses, carnivals, shows, or exhibitions of any kind, whether
admission is charged or not;
   (B)   Transient amusements not otherwise provided for in this article; or
   (C)   Itinerant skating rinks or shooting galleries operated for profit,
even though maintained and operated on private property.
(Prior Code, § 12-50)
§ 12-51. LICENSE NOT TO BE USED BY OTHERS.
   No license issued under the provisions of this article shall be used at any
time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued.
(Prior Code, § 12-51)
§ 12-52. PERSONS UNDER 16 YEARS OF AGE.
   No license shall be issued to any person under the age of 16 years, and it
is unlawful for any licensee to employ or allow any person under the age of 16
years to be employed in connection with the business licensed thereunder.
(Prior Code, § 12-52)

Section

   12-78 through 12-97 reserved
