§ 34-1. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CHIEF OF POLICE. The peace officer in charge of the police force of the
municipality.
   CITY CLERK. The Clerk of this municipality, including any deputy or member
of the office staff of the Clerk while performing duties of the Clerk’s office.
   GOVERNING BODY. The City Council.
   MUNICIPAL COURT. The Municipal Court of the city.
   MUNICIPAL JUDGE. The Judge of the Municipal Court, including any acting
judge or alternate judge thereof as provided for by the statutes of this state
and this article.
   MUNICIPALITY or THIS MUNICIPALITY. The city.
   THIS JUDICIAL DISTRICT. The district court judicial district of the state
wherein the government of this municipality is situated.
(Prior Code, § 34-1)
§ 34-2. ORGANIZATION AND OPERATION.
   This article shall govern the organization and operation of the Municipal
Court of the city, as put into operation by resolution duly passed on January
7, 1969, and filed in accordance with law as authorized by 11 O.S. §§ 27-101
and 27-102. To the extent of conflict between any provisions of this article
and the provisions of any ordinance of this city, the provisions of this
article shall control. The Municipal Court shall be operative on and after
January 13, 1969.
(Prior Code, § 34-2)
Statutory reference:
   Municipal courts not of record, organization, rules, and procedures, see 11
O.S. §§ 27-101 to 27-131
§ 34-3. JURISDICTION OF COURT.
   The Municipal Court shall exercise original jurisdiction to hear and
determine all prosecutions wherein a violation of any ordinance of this
municipality is charged, including any such prosecutions transferred to the
Municipal Court in accordance with applicable law.
(Prior Code, § 34-3)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 27-103
§ 34-4. MUNICIPAL JUDGE; QUALIFICATIONS.
   There shall be one Municipal Judge of the Municipal Court appointed by the
Mayor with the consent of the City Council. The Municipal Judge need not be a
licensed attorney-at-law, but if not, he or she must be a resident of this
municipality, of the age of 25 years or older, and of good moral character. The
Municipal Judge who is a licensed attorney may engage in the practice of law in
other courts, but he or she shall not accept employment inconsistent with his
or her duties as Municipal Judge or arising out of facts which give rise to or
are connected with cases within the jurisdiction of the Court, pending therein,
or which might become the subject of proceedings therein.
(Prior Code, § 34-4)
Statutory reference:
   Judge of the Municipal Court, see 11 O.S. § 27-104
§ 34-5. TERM OF MUNICIPAL JUDGE.
   The official term of the Municipal Judge shall be two years, expiring on
June 1 in each odd-numbered year. Each Municipal Judge shall serve until his or
her successor is appointed and qualified unless removed by the vote of a
majority of all members of the governing body for such cause as is provided for
by law for the removal of public officers.
(Prior Code, § 34-5)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 27-104
§ 34-6. ALTERNATE MUNICIPAL JUDGE.
   (A)   There shall be appointed for each Municipal Judge of the Municipal
Court an alternate judge with the same qualifications as the Municipal Judge.
The appointment shall be for the same term and made in the same manner as the
Municipal Judge.
   (B)   The alternate Municipal Judge shall sit as acting Municipal Judge of
the Municipal Court in any case if the Municipal Judge is:
      (1)   Absent from the Court;
      (2)   Unable to act as Municipal Judge; or
      (3)   Disqualified from acting as Municipal Judge in the case.
(Prior Code, § 34-6)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 27-106
§ 34-7. ACTING MUNICIPAL JUDGE.
   If, at any time, there is no Municipal Judge or alternate Municipal Judge,
duly appointed and qualified, available to sit as Municipal Judge, the Mayor
shall appoint some person, possessing the qualifications required by this
article, for the Municipal Judge, who shall preside as acting Municipal Judge
over the Municipal Court in the disposition of pending matters until such time
as a Municipal Judge or alternate Municipal Judge shall be available.
(Prior Code, § 34-7)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 27-106
§ 34-8. APPOINTMENT OF MUNICIPAL JUDGE AND ALTERNATE MUNICIPAL JUDGE.
   Municipal Judges and alternate Municipal Judges shall be appointed by the
Mayor with the consent of the governing body. A proposed appointment shall be
submitted in writing to the governing body at the next to last regularly
scheduled meeting prior to the day upon which the appointment is to take
effect, and shall be acted upon at the next regularly scheduled meeting. The
governing body may decide upon the proposed appointment by a majority vote of
all members. Failure of decision upon a proposed appointment shall not prevent
action thereon at a later regularly scheduled meeting of the governing body
unless the Mayor, in writing, withdraws the proposed appointment.
(Prior Code, § 34-8)
Statutory reference:
   Appointment of alternate or acting Municipal Judge, see 11 O.S. § 27-106
§ 34-9. COMPENSATION.
   (A)   A Municipal Judge, other than an alternate Municipal Judge or an
acting Municipal Judge, shall receive a salary as set by the governing body by
motion or resolution, paid in the same manner as the salaries of other
officials of this municipality.
   (B)   An alternate Municipal Judge or an acting Municipal Judge shall be
paid an amount as set by the governing body for each day devoted to the
performance of his or her duties, except that the total payments so calculated
during any month shall not exceed the salary of the Municipal Judge. An
alternate or acting Municipal Judge who sits for an entire month shall receive
the amount specified in this article as the salary of the Municipal Judge.
(Prior Code, § 34-9)
Statutory reference:
   Compensation, see 11 O.S. § 27-104
§ 34-10. REMOVAL OF MUNICIPAL JUDGE.
   (A)   Municipal Judges shall be subject to removal from office by the
governing body for the causes prescribed by the Constitution and laws of this
state for the removal of public officers. Proceedings for removal shall be
instituted by the filing of a verified written petition setting forth facts
sufficient to constitute one or more legal grounds for removal. Petitions may
be signed and filed by:
      (1)   The Mayor; or
      (2)   Twenty-five or more qualified electors of this municipality.
Verification of the number or qualifications of electors shall be executed by
one or more of the petitioners.
   (B)   The governing body shall set a date for hearing the matter and shall
cause notice thereof, together with a copy of the petition, to be served
personally upon the Municipal Judge at least ten days before the hearing. At
the hearing, the Municipal Judge shall be entitled to:
      (1)   Representation by counsel;
      (2)   Present testimony and cross-examine the witnesses against him or
her; and
      (3)   Have all evidence against him or her presented in open hearing.
   (C)   So far as they can be applicable, the provisions of the State
Administrative Procedures Act governing individual proceedings, 75 O.S. §§ 309
through 317 shall govern removal proceedings hereunder. Judgment of removal
shall be entered only upon individual votes, by a majority of all members of
the governing body, in favor of such removal.
(Prior Code, § 34-10)
Editor’s note:
   For removal of judges from office, see Oklahoma Constitution Art. II, § 11
and Art. VII, § A-1
Statutory reference:
   Removal of judge, see 11 O.S. § 27-104
§ 34-11. VACANCY IN OFFICE OF MUNICIPAL JUDGE.
   (A)   A vacancy in the office of Municipal Judge shall occur if the
incumbent:
      (1)   Dies;
      (2)   Resigns;
      (3)   Ceases to possess the qualifications for the office; or
      (4)   Is removed, and the removal proceedings have been affirmed finally
in judicial proceedings or are no longer subject to judicial review.
   (B)   Upon the occurrence of a vacancy in the office of Municipal Judge, the
Mayor shall appoint a successor to complete the unexpired term in the same
manner as an original appointment is made.
(Prior Code, § 34-11)
Statutory reference:
   Filling vacancies, see 11 O.S. § 27-107
§ 34-12. DISQUALIFICATION OF MUNICIPAL JUDGE.
   In prosecutions before the Municipal Court, no change of venue shall be
allowed, but the Municipal Judge before whom the case is pending may certify
his or her disqualification, or he or she may be disqualified from sitting
under the terms, conditions, and procedure provided by law for Municipal Courts
of record. If a Municipal Judge is disqualified, the matter shall be heard by
an alternate or acting judge appointed as provided in this article.
(Prior Code, § 34-12)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 27-105
§ 34-13. COURT MARSHAL.
   All writs or process of the Municipal Court shall be directed to the Chief
of Police of this municipality, in his or her official title, who shall be the
principal officer of the Municipal Court.
(Prior Code, § 34-13)
Statutory reference:
   Court Marshal, see 11 O.S. § 27-110
§ 34-14. CLERK OF THE MUNICIPAL COURT; DUTIES.
   The City Clerk, or a deputy designated by him or her, shall be the Clerk of
the Municipal Court. He or she shall assist the Municipal Judge in recording
the proceedings of the Municipal Court and in preparing writs, processes, and
other papers. He or she shall administer oaths required in proceedings before
the Municipal Court. He or she shall enter all pleadings, processes, and
proceedings in the dockets of the Municipal Court. He or she shall perform such
other clerical duties relating to the proceedings of the Municipal Court as the
Municipal Judge shall direct. He or she shall receive and receipt for
forfeitures, fines, deposits, and sums of money payable to the Municipal Court.
He or she shall pay to the Treasurer of this municipality at least twice
monthly all money so received by him or her, except such special deposits or
fees as shall be received to be disbursed by him or her for special purposes.
All money paid to the Treasurer shall be placed in the General Fund of the
municipality, or in such other funds as the governing body may direct, and it
shall be used in the operation of the municipal government in accordance with
budgetary arrangements governing the fund in which it is placed.
(Prior Code, § 34-14)
Statutory reference:
   Duties of Clerk, see 11 O.S. § 27-109
§ 34-15. PROSECUTING ATTORNEY; DUTIES; CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
   The Attorney for this municipality, or his or her duly designated assistant,
shall be the prosecuting officer of the Municipal Court. He or she shall also
prosecute all alleged violations of the ordinances of the city. He or she shall
be authorized, in his or her discretion, to prosecute and resist appeal,
proceedings in error, and review from this Municipal Court to any other court
of the state, and to represent this municipality in all proceedings arising out
of matters in this Municipal Court.
(Prior Code, § 34-15)
Statutory reference:
   Duties of City Attorney, see 11 O.S. § 27-108
§ 34-16. BOND OF MUNICIPAL JUDGE AND COURT CLERK.
   The Court Clerk of the Municipal Court shall give bond, in the form provided
by 11 O.S. § 27-111, in the sum which is on file in the City Clerk’s office.
When executed, the bond shall be submitted to the governing body for approval.
When approved, it shall be filed with the Clerk of this municipality and
retained in the municipal archives.
(Prior Code, § 34-16)
Statutory reference:
   Bond of Clerk, see 11 O.S. § 27-111
§ 34-17. RULES OF COURT.
   The Municipal Judge may prescribe rules, consistent with the laws of the
state and with the ordinances of this city, for the proper conduct of the
business of the Municipal Court.
(Prior Code, § 34-17)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 27-114
§ 34-18. ENFORCEMENT OF RULES.
   Obedience to the orders, rules, and judgments made by the Municipal Judge or
by the Municipal Court may be enforced by the Municipal Judge, who may fine or
imprison for contempt committed as to him or her while holding court, or
committed against process issued by him or her, in the same manner and to the
same extent as the district courts of this state.
(Prior Code, § 34-18)
§ 34-19. WRITTEN COMPLAINTS TO PROSECUTE ORDINANCE VIOLATIONS.
   All prosecutions for violations of ordinances of this municipality shall be
styled “The City of Alva vs. (naming defendant or defendants).” Except as
provided hereinafter, prosecution shall be initiated by the filing of a written
complaint, subscribed and verified by the person making complaint, and setting
forth concisely the offense charged and approved for filing by the City
Attorney.
(Prior Code, § 34-19)
Statutory reference:
   Similar provisions, see 11 O.S. § 27-115
§ 34-20. TRAFFIC ORDINANCE VIOLATIONS; PROCEDURES FOR ISSUING CITATION;
CUSTODY, ARREST.
   (A)   If a police officer observes facts which he or she believes constitute
a violation of the traffic ordinances of this municipality, committed by a
resident thereof, in lieu of arresting such a person, he or she may take his or
her name, address, operator’s license number, and registered license number of
the motor vehicle involved and any other pertinent and necessary information
and may issue him or her, in writing in the form prescribed by the Mayor or his
or her duly designated delegate, a traffic citation embracing the above
information and also stating the traffic violation alleged to have occurred,
and notifying him or her to answer to the charge against him or her at a time,
not later than ten days thereafter, specified in the citation. The officer,
upon receiving the written promise of the alleged violator, endorsed on the
citation to answer as specified, may then release the person from custody. If
the person to whom a citation is issued fails to answer as prescribed in the
citation, a complaint shall be filed and the case shall be prosecuted as
otherwise provided in this article.
   (B)   If the alleged traffic violation is committed by a nonresident or
resident of this municipality, the police officer may:
      (1)   Release the person after obtaining sufficient information as set
out in subsection (A) above of this section, pending his or her appearance on a
day certain in Municipal Court, as specified in the citation after the person:
         (a)   Posts cash bail;
         (b)   Deposits with the arresting officer a guaranteed arrest bond
certificate; or
         (c)   Deposits with the arresting officer a valid license to operate
motor vehicle in exchange for a receipt therefor issued by the arresting
officer as provided in § 34-25.
      (2)   Take the person in custody and demand that bond for the offense
charged be posted according to the provisions of this article; or
      (3)   Take the person into custody under arrest. The arrested person
either shall be taken immediately before the Municipal Judge for further
proceedings according to law or shall have bail fixed for his or her release in
accordance with the provisions of this article. Upon providing bail as fixed,
and upon giving his or her written promise to appear upon a day certain, as
provided in subsection (A) above of this section, the person shall be released
from custody.
   (C)   If the alleged offense be a violation of an ordinance restricting or
regulating the parking of vehicles, including any regulations issued under such
an ordinance, and the operator be not present, the police officer shall place
on the vehicle, at a place reasonably likely to come to the notice of the
operator, a citation conforming substantially to that prescribed in subsection
(A) or (B) above of this section, with such variation as the circumstances
require; the operator of this vehicle shall be under the same obligation to
respond to the citation as if it had been issued to him or her personally under
subsection (A) or (B) above of this section.
(Prior Code, § 34-20) (Ord. 738, passed 7-17-1978)
Statutory reference:
   Traffic procedures generally, see 22 O.S. §§ 1115.1 et seq.
§ 34-21. CREATION OF TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS BUREAU.
   (A)   A Traffic Violations Bureau hereby is established as a division of the
office of the Clerk of the Municipal Court, to be administered by the Clerk, or
by subordinates designated by him or her for that purpose. Persons who are
cited for violation of one of the traffic regulatory ordinances of this
municipality which are listed in the schedule of fines adopted by the City
Council, may elect to pay a fine in the Traffic Violations Bureau according to
the schedule of fines to be determined by the governing body.
   (B)   The Municipal Court may adopt rules to carry into effect this section.
Payment of a fine under this section shall constitute a final determination of
cause against the defendant. If a defendant who has elected to pay a fine under
this section fails to do so, prosecution shall proceed under the provisions of
this article.
(Prior Code, § 34-21) (Ord. 737, passed 7-17-1978)
§ 34-22. SUMMONS FOR ARREST.
   (A)   Upon the filing of a complaint charging violation of any ordinance,
the Municipal Judge, unless he or she determines to issue a warrant of arrest,
or unless the defendant previously has been issued a citation or has been
arrested and has given bond for appearance, he or she shall issue a summons,
naming the person charged, specifying his or her address or place of residence,
if known, stating the offense with which he or she is charged and giving him or
her notice to answer the charge in the Municipal Court on a certain day, ten
days (Sundays and holidays excepted) after the summons is served upon him or
her, and including such other pertinent information as may be necessary.
   (B)   The summons shall be served by delivering a copy to the defendant
personally. If he or she fails to appear and to answer the summons within the
prescribed period, a warrant shall be issued for his or her arrest, as provided
by this article.
(Prior Code, § 34-22)
§ 34-23. FORM OF ARREST WARRANT.
   (A)   Except as otherwise provided in the ordinances of this municipality,
upon the filing of a complaint approved by the endorsement of the Attorney of
this municipality or by the Municipal Judge, there shall be issued a warrant of
arrest, in substantially the following form:
Before ____________, Municipal Judge of the City of Alva, Oklahoma.
CITY OF ALVA, PLAINTIFF
VS.
____________DEFENDANT
The City of Alva, Oklahoma, to the Police Chief of the City
GREETINGS:
Whereas, ____________ has made complaint in writing under oath before me, the
undersigned Municipal Judge of the City of Alva, Oklahoma, that ____________
did on the ____________ day of ____________/____________/____________,
20____________ at and within the corporate limits of the City of Alva,
Oklahoma, then and there willfully and unlawfully ____________/____________/
____________ ____________ ____________
____________ ____________ in violation of Section ____________ of Ordinance
Number ____________, of said City in such case made and provided:
Now, therefore, you are hereby commanded to forthwith arrest the said
____________/____________/____________ ____________ and bring him before me to
answer to said charge, and hereof fail not.
Witness my hand at my office in Alva, Oklahoma, this ____________ day of
____________/____________/____________, 20____________.
____________ ____________ ____________
Municipal Judge of the City of Alva,
Oklahoma.
 
   (B)   It is the duty of a duly constituted member of the police force of
this municipality, or through any other person lawfully authorized so to act,
to execute the warrant as promptly as possible.
(Prior Code, § 34-23)
§ 34-24. PROCEDURES FOR BAIL OR BOND.
   Upon arrest, or upon appearance without arrest in response to citation or
summons, or at any time before trial, before or after arraignment, the
defendant shall be eligible to be released upon giving bail for his or her
appearance in an amount and upon conditions fixed by this article or the
Municipal Judge, who shall prescribe appropriate rules of the Municipal Court
for the receipt of bail. In case of arrests made at night or under other
conditions or emergency or when the Municipal Judge is not available, the rules
shall authorize the Chief of Police, or his or her designated representative,
to accept a temporary cash bond of not less than $10 nor more than the maximum
monetary penalty provided by ordinance for the offense charged.
(Prior Code, § 34-24)
Statutory reference:
   Acceptable methods of bail (cash, guaranteed arrest bond certificate), see
11 O.S. § 27-117
§ 34-25. DEPOSIT OF DRIVER’S LICENSE AS BAIL FOR TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   In addition to the other methods for providing or posting of bail
authorized in this article upon arrest for traffic violations, the defendant
may deposit with the police officer a valid license to operate a motor vehicle
in exchange for a receipt therefor issued by the police officer. The receipt
issued by the police officer shall be recognized as an operator’s license and
shall authorize the operation of a motor vehicle until the time and date of the
hearing indicated on the receipt or traffic citation, but not to exceed 20
days. The operator’s license and traffic citation shall be delivered by the
police officer to the Clerk of the Municipal Court.
   (B)   Any person who applies for a duplicate license to operate a motor
vehicle while his or her license is deposited in accordance with subsection (A)
above of this section shall be fined $20 and court costs. Each such application
shall constitute a separate violation. In order for the fine to be applicable
to a violator applying for a duplicate license, notice of the provisions of
subsection (B) of this section shall be included in receipt issued pursuant to
this section. The receipt for deposit of the driver’s license shall contain
essentially the following notice:
 
“NOTICE”
“This receipt for deposit of a valid license to operate a motor vehicle
constitutes a temporary operator’s license until your hearing date on
____________, but in no case shall this temporary license remain in effect more
than 20 days. Keep this receipt in your possession at all times while operating
a motor vehicle.”
“Application for a duplicate license to operate a motor vehicle while your
license is deposited as bail is a crime punishable by a fine of $20 and court
costs. Each such application constitutes a separate offense.”
 
(Prior Code, § 34-25) (Ord. 738, passed 7-17-1978)
§ 34-26. ARRAIGNMENT AND PLEADINGS BY DEFENDANT.
   Upon making his or her appearance before the Municipal Court, the defendant
shall be arraigned. The Municipal Judge, or the Attorney of the municipality,
shall read the complaint to the defendant, inform him or her of his or her
legal rights, including the right of trial by jury, if available, and of the
consequences of conviction, and ask him or her whether he or she pleads guilty
or not guilty. If the defendant pleads guilty, the Municipal Court may proceed
to judgment and sentence or may continue the matter for subsequent disposition.
If the plea is not guilty, and the case is not for jury trial, the Municipal
Court may proceed to try the case, or may set it for hearing at a later date.
(Prior Code, § 34-26)
Statutory reference:
   Arraignment, see 11 O.S. § 27-116
§ 34-27. TRIALS AND JUDGMENTS.
   (A)   Before trial commences, either party, upon good cause shown, may
obtain a reasonable postponement thereof.
   (B)   The defendant must be present in person at the trial.
   (C)   In all trials, as to matters not covered in this article, or by the
statutes relating to municipal criminal courts, or by rules duly promulgated by
the Supreme Court of the state, the procedure applicable in trials of
misdemeanors in the district courts shall apply to the extent that they can be
made effective.
   (D)   If the defendant pleads guilty or is convicted after the trial, the
Municipal Court must render judgment thereon, fixing the penalty within the
limits prescribed by the applicable ordinance, and imposing sentence
accordingly.
   (E)   At the close of trial, judgment must be rendered immediately by the
Municipal Judge, who shall cause it to be entered in his or her docket.
   (F)   If judgment is of acquittal, and the defendant is not to be detained
for any other legal cause, he or she must be discharged at once.
   (G)   A judgment that the defendant pay a fine may also direct that he or
she be imprisoned until the fine is satisfied at the rate of one day
imprisonment for each $5 of fine. If the defendant is without means to pay the
fine or costs, the Municipal Judge may direct the total amount due to be
entered upon the court minutes and to be certified to the district court of the
county wherein the situs of government is situated where it shall be entered
upon the district court judgment docket and shall have the full force and
effect of a district court judgment. Thereupon, the same remedies shall be
available for the enforcement of the judgment as are available to any other
judgment creditor.
(Prior Code, § 34-27)
§ 34-28. SUSPENSION OF SENTENCE.
   After conviction and sentence, the Municipal Judge may suspend sentence, in
accordance with the provisions of, and subject to the conditions and procedures
imposed by 11 O.S. §§ 27-123 and 27-124.
(Prior Code, § 34-28)
Statutory reference:
   Power to modify, reduce, suspend, or defer sentence, see 11 O.S. § 27-122.1
(B) and (C)
§ 34-29. IMPRISONMENT, COMMUNITY SERVICE.
   (A)   If, after conviction, judgment of imprisonment is entered, a copy
thereof, certified by the City Clerk, shall be delivered to the Chief of
Police, the Sheriff of the county, or other appropriate police officer. Such
copy shall be sufficient warrant for execution of the sentence.
   (B)   Any person fined for violation of a municipal ordinance who is
financially able but refuses or neglects to pay the fine or costs may be
compelled to satisfy the amount owed by working on the streets, alleys,
avenues, areas, and public grounds of the municipality, subject to the
direction of the Street Commissioner or other proper officer, at a rate per day
as the governing body may prescribe by ordinance, but not less than $25 per day
for useful labor, until the fine or costs are satisfied.
   (C)   Whenever any person is convicted in Municipal Court for violation of a
municipal ordinance, the Municipal Court may order the defendant to a term of
community service or remedial action in lieu of fine or in conjunction with
imprisonment. If the defendant fails to perform the required community service
or if the conditions of community service are violated, the Municipal Judge may
impose a sentence of imprisonment, not to exceed the maximum sentence allowable
for the violation for which the defendant was convicted.
(Prior Code, § 34-29)
Statutory reference:
   Community service in lieu of fine or in conjunction with imprisonment, see
11 O.S. § 27-122.2
   Execution of sentence, see 11 O.S. § 27-122.1
§ 34-30. FINES AND COSTS.
   If judgment of conviction is entered, the City Clerk of the Municipal Court
shall tax the costs to the defendant, but the total amount of fine and costs
may not exceed $70, plus the fees and mileage of jurors and witnesses.
(Prior Code, § 34-30)
Statutory reference:
   Costs, see 11 O.S. § 27-126
§ 34-31. CONDUCT OF SESSIONS OF COURT; NOTICE.
   The Municipal Judge of the Municipal Court shall conduct regular sessions of
the Municipal Court. Notice of the sessions shall be given as prescribed in the
state’s Open Meetings Law, 25 O.S. §§ 301 through 314.
(Prior Code, § 34-31)
Statutory reference:
   Oklahoma Open Meetings Law, see 25 O.S. §§ 301 et seq.

GENERALLY
§§ 36-19 THROUGH 36-39. RESERVED.
PLANNING COMMISSION
§ 36-40. CREATED.
   There is hereby created within and for the city a Planning Commission, which
shall consist of six members, all of whom shall be residents of the city,
nominated by the Mayor and confirmed by the City Council. The appointed members
of the Commission shall be nominated and appointed solely with reference to
their fitness and without reference to party affiliation, and shall serve
without compensation, except as hereinafter provided. Members may be removed by
the Mayor or the City Council.
(Prior Code, § 36-40)
Statutory reference:
   Planning Commission authorized, see 11 O.S. § 45-101
§ 36-41. TERM OF OFFICE; PROVISION FOR VACANCIES.
   Each appointed member of the City Planning Commission shall hold office for
a term of three years, or until his or her successor takes office. When a
vacancy occurs, the appointment shall be made to fill the unexpired term.
(Prior Code, § 36-41)
§ 36-42. EX OFFICIO MEMBERS.
   The Mayor and the City Engineer shall be ex officio members of the City
Planning Commission, but shall receive no compensation other than their affixed
salary of their office.
(Prior Code, § 36-42)
§ 36-43. QUORUM.
   Four members of the City Planning Commission shall constitute a quorum for
the transaction of business. However, no action shall be taken and be binding
upon the City Planning Commission unless concurred in by not less than a
majority of all members comprising the City Planning Commission.
(Prior Code, § 36-43)
§ 36-44. MEETINGS; ORGANIZATION AND RULES.
   The members of the City Planning Commission shall elect from their members a
Chair, Vice-Chair, and Secretary, and shall adopt rules for the transaction of
business. The terms of the Chair, Vice-Chair, and Secretary shall be one year
with eligibility for reelection. The Commission shall keep a record of its
regulations, transactions, findings, and determinations, which record shall be
a public record.
(Prior Code, § 36-44)
§ 36-45. POWER TO EMPLOY STAFF; DUTIES.
   The members of the City Planning Commission shall serve without pay, and it
shall be the duty of such Commission to prepare from time to time plans for the
systematic development and betterment of the municipality as a place of
residence or for business. It shall have the power and authority to employ
planners, engineers, attorneys, clerks, or other help deemed necessary, subject
to the approval of the City Council. The salary and compensation of such
employees shall be fixed by the City Council and shall be paid out of the City
Treasury as other officers and employees, and the necessary expenses incurred
by the Council shall be paid out of the City Treasury as other legal expense of
the city government. The Commission may incur necessary expenses within the
limits of its appropriation to carry out its purposes and responsibility.
(Prior Code, § 36-45)
§ 36-46. POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The Planning Commission shall have the power and the duty to prepare
and recommend to the City Council for adoption a Comprehensive Plan for the
physical development of the city. In conducting its work, the Planning
Commission may consider and investigate any subject matter tending to the
development and betterment of such municipality and may make recommendations as
it may deem advisable concerning the adoption thereof to the City Council. The
Planning Commission may make or cause to be made surveys, studies, maps, and
plans in the conduct of its activities.
   (B)   Before final action is taken by the City Council on the location or
design of any public building, statue, memorial, park, boulevard, street and
alley, playground, public grounds, bridge, or change in any location of any
street or alley, such question shall be submitted to the Planning Commission
for investigation and report.
   (C)   In the preparation of the Comprehensive Plan, the Planning Commission
may from time to time prepare and recommend to the City Council for adoption
parts thereof, which parts shall cover one or more major geographical divisions
of the city or one or more major elements of the Comprehensive Plan. The
Planning Commission may from time to time recommend extending, amending, or
changing any portion of the Comprehensive Plan.
(Prior Code, § 36-46)
§ 36-47. PURPOSES OF PLAN.
   In the preparation of the city’s Comprehensive Plan, the Planning Commission
shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of present conditions
and future growth of the city and with due regard to its relation to
neighboring territory. The Plan shall be made with the general purpose of
guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted, and harmonious development
of the city and its environs which will, in accordance with present and future
needs, best promote health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity, and
general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of
development; including, among other things, adequate provisions for traffic,
the promotion of safety from fire and other dangers, adequate provision for
light and air, the promotion of healthful and convenient distribution of
population, the promotion of good civic design and arrangement, and wise and
efficient expenditure of public funds.
(Prior Code, § 36-47)
§ 36-48. SUBDIVISION OF LAND.
   (A)   The Planning Commission may prepare and recommend to the City Council
for adoption rules and regulations governing the subdivision of land within the
corporate limits of the city.
   (B)   All plans, plats, or replats of land laid out in two or more lots,
plats, or parcels, or streets, alleys, or other ways intended to be dedicated
to public use within the corporate limits of the city shall first be submitted
to the Planning Commission for its recommendation. The Planning Commission
shall, with the help of appropriate city officials, check the proposed
dedications or subdivision of land to ensure compliance with the rules and
regulations governing subdivisions of land and with other elements of the
Comprehensive Plan for the city.
   (C)   The disapproval of any such plan, plat, or replat by the City Council
shall be deemed a refusal of the dedications shown thereon.
   (D)   No plat or replat of subdivision of land, or dedication of street or
alley or other easement shall be entitled to record unless it bears the
signature of the Mayor, attested by the City Clerk, certifying the approval and
acceptance thereof by the City Council.
(Prior Code, § 36-48)
§ 36-49. ZONING.
   The Planning Commission shall have the power to prepare and to recommend to
the City Council for adoption a zoning plan to regulate and restrict the
height, number of stories, and size of buildings and other structures, the
percentage of lot that may be occupied, the size of yards, courts, and other
open spaces, the density of population, the location and use of buildings,
structures, and land for trade, industry, residences, and other purposes.
(Prior Code, § 36-49)
§ 36-50. UNIFORMITY OF REGULATIONS.
   The Planning Commission may recommend the division of the city into
districts of such number, size, and area as may be deemed best suited to carry
out the zoning plan. All such regulations shall be uniform for each class or
kind of buildings throughout each district, but the regulations in one district
may differ from those in other districts.
(Prior Code, § 36-50)
§ 36-51. COMPREHENSIVE PLAN; PURPOSE OF ZONING REGULATIONS.
   Zoning regulations shall be made in accordance with a Comprehensive Plan and
designed to lessen congestion in the streets; to secure safety from fire,
panic, and other dangers; to promote health and the general welfare; to provide
adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue
concentration of population; and to facilitate the adequate provisions of
transportation, water, sewage, schools, parks, and other public requirements.
Such regulations shall be made with reasonable consideration, among other
things, as to the character of the district and its peculiar suitability for
particular uses, and with a view of conserving the value of buildings and
encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout the city.
(Prior Code, § 36-51)
§§ 36-52 THROUGH 36-77. RESERVED.
DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
§ 36-78. CREATED; MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION.
   There is created a City Development Commission, composed of five members,
appointed by the Mayor, with each member to serve a term of five years, and
until their successors shall be appointed and qualified. Vacancies shall be
filled for the unexpired portion of the term by the Mayor. Members shall serve
without compensation.
(Prior Code, § 36-78)
§ 36-79. MEMBERS; QUORUM.
   Members may be removed by the Mayor only for inefficiency, neglect of duty,
or malefaction in office. The Commission shall select one member to act as
Chair and one member to act as Secretary. Three members of the Commission shall
constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. However, no action shall
be taken which is binding upon the Commission unless concurred in by not less
than a majority of all members comprising the City Development Commission.
(Prior Code, § 36-79)
§ 36-80. POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The duties of the Development Commission shall be to explore, investigate,
and encourage future commercial and industrial development in the city,
advising the City Council and the Mayor of any requirements created by
development of any commercial or industrial expansion and probable costs
thereof, and to perform any other duties assigned to such Commission by the
City Council and Mayor.
(Prior Code, § 36-80)
§ 36-81. EXPENSES; BUDGET.
   The Development Commission shall have the power to incur costs for travel
expense, keeping of records, and any secretarial and clerical expenses
necessary to carry out its duties, insofar as there are funds available from a
budget account set up by the City Council, with the Commission prohibited from
incurring any expenses in excess of its allowed budget.
(Prior Code, § 36-81)
§ 36-82. TO MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS.
   The Development Commission shall make recommendations to the City Council
and Mayor concerning commercial and industrial development in the city.
(Prior Code, § 36-82)
§§ 36-83 THROUGH 36-107. RESERVED.
ARTICLE III: ZONING REGULATIONS
Section
   
36-108.   Zoning ordinances
   
36-109.   Provisions of zoning ordinances in force

   36-111 through 36-133 reserved
§ 36-108. ZONING ORDINANCES.
   The zoning ordinances of the city printed as Appendix B to this code is the
official zoning ordinance of the city and may be cited as such.
(Prior Code, § 36-108)
Statutory reference:
   State laws applicable to zoning, see 11 O.S. §§ 43-101 et seq., 44-101 et
seq., and 45-101 et seq.
§ 36-109. PROVISIONS OF ZONING ORDINANCES IN FORCE.
   All of the provisions included in the zoning ordinance, Appendix B to this
code, are hereby continued in full force and effect whether such provisions are
included therein in the forms as originally adopted, or are included therein in
amended form, or composed wholly or partially of new material as provided by
law.
(Prior Code, § 36-109)
§ 36-110. COPIES OF ZONING ORDINANCES ON FILE.
   Not less than one copy of the zoning ordinances as amended is on file in the
City Clerk’s office and is available for inspection by the public during normal
working hours.
(Prior Code, § 36-110)
§§ 36-111 THROUGH 36-133. RESERVED.
ARTICLE IV: SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS
Section
   
36-134.   Subdivision regulations adopted
   
36-135.   Provisions of subdivision regulations continued in force
   
36-136.   Copies on file
   36-137 through 36-157 reserved
§ 36-134. SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS ADOPTED.

City Council is the official subdivision regulations of the city, and may be
cited as such.
(Prior Code, § 36-134) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)

partially of new material as provided by law.

   Not less than one copy of the city’s subdivision regulations as amended is

§ 36-158. AUTHORIZATION.
   In order to develop the eligible project area, the city elects to utilize
Article X, § 6C of the Constitution of the state and the state’s Local
Development Act, being 62 O.S. §§ 850 through 869, which authorize the use of
local taxes for specific public investments, assistance in development
financing, and as a revenue source for other public entities in the area, and
which provide for the direction of apportionment of local taxes to plan,
finance, and carry out development of unproductive, undeveloped,
underdeveloped, or blighted areas as determined by the governing body of a
city, town, or county.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-159. PROJECT PLAN DESCRIBED.
   As used herein, PROJECT PLAN shall mean the document dated June 25, 2018,
and comprised of one cover sheet, six pages of text, five exhibits labeled
Exhibits A, B, C, D, and E, and titled “Alva Arena Economic Development Project
Plan.”
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-160. REVIEW COMMITTEE ACTION CONFIRMED.
   The membership of the Review Committee and all actions taken and all
recommendations and findings made in connection with the project plan and with
regard to the Increment District by the Review Committee and the Planning
Commission are hereby ratified and confirmed.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-161. CITY ACTION CONFIRMED.
   The action of the city in enacting Ordinance No. 2018-003 that approved and
adopted the project plan, established the project area, and established the
Increment District, is hereby ratified and confirmed.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-162. COUNTY ACTION CONFIRMED.
   The action of the County Commissioners in enacting Resolution # 20-21-34
that approved and adopted the project plan, established the project area, and
established the Increment District, is hereby ratified and confirmed.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-163. INCREMENT DISTRICT DESCRIBED.
   For identification purposes, the Increment Distinct is described on Exhibit
B and shown on Exhibit C of the project plan.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-164. NAME OF DISTRICT.
   For identification purposes, the name of the Increment District, an ad
valorem and sales tax increment district as set forth in the project plan,
shall be Joint Increment District Number One, City of Alva and Woods County
(“Increment District”).
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-165. CREATION.
   The Increment District is hereby created as of the date the ordinance from
which this article is derived is adopted.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-166. EFFECTIVE DATE.
   The date of creation, official designation, naming of the Increment District
and, accordingly, the commencement of the respective period of apportionment,
is within ten years of the effective date of the project plan.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-167. BOUNDARIES OF PROJECT AREA.
   The boundaries of the project area of the project plan are described on
Exhibit A of the project plan, and shown on Exhibit C of the project plan, and
are hereby designated and adopted as described in § 6 of Ordinance No. 2018-003
and § 6 of Resolution #20-21-34.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-168. BOUNDARIES OF INCREMENT DISTRICT.
   The boundaries of the Increment District are described on Exhibit B and
shown on Exhibit C, of the project plan, and are hereby designated and adopted
as described in § 7 of Ordinance No. 2018-003 and § 7 of Resolution # 20-21-34.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-169. CITY FINDINGS.
   The city hereby finds, determines, and reaffirms:
   (A)   The project area, including the Increment District, is an enterprise
area as defined by the Act;
   (B)   The financial impacts of the proposed project plan and project on the
affected taxing jurisdictions and business activities within the Increment
District are positive and that the economic benefits for the community as a
whole offset any adverse impacts;
   (C)   The improvement of the project area is likely to enhance the value of
other real property in the area and to promote the general public interest;
   (D)   The project plan complies with the guidelines of 62 O.S. § 852,
including specifically divisions (1) and (2);
   (E)   The aggregate net assessed value of the taxable property in all
increment districts within the city, as determined pursuant to the Act, does
not exceed 35% of the total net assessed value of the taxable property within
the city;
   (F)   The aggregate net assessed value of the taxable property in all
increment districts within the city, as determined pursuant to the Act, does
not exceed 25% of the total net assessed value of any affected school districts
located within the city;
   (G)   The land within all increment districts within the city does not
exceed 25% of the total land area of the city; and
   (H)   The project plan is feasible and conforms to the city’s Comprehensive
Plan.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-170. PROJECT AND INCREMENT DISTRICTS AUTHORIZED.
   The following project and Increment District authorizations are hereby
ratified:
   (A)   The Alva Arena Authority, a public trust, shall be the principal
entity responsible for implementation and is authorized to carry out and
administer the provisions of the project plan and to exercise all powers
necessary or appropriate thereto pursuant to 62 O.S. § 854, although the city
and county including the power to make minor amendments to the project plan in
accordance with 62 O.S. § 858(D);
   (B)   Both the city and county shall have the authority to assist in
carrying out the provisions of the project plan and to incur project costs with
respect to improvements and operations within their responsibilities, in
accordance with budgetary allocations for such activities approved in
accordance with the project plan;
   (C)   The Alva Arena Authority, a public trust, shall also have the
authority to carry out certain provisions of the project plan, including the
authority to:
      (1)   Issue tax apportionment bonds or notes, or both;
      (2)   Pledge revenues from current and future fiscal years to repayment;
      (3)   Incur project costs pursuant to § VIII of the project plan;
      (4)   Provide funds to or reimburse the city or county for the payment of
project costs or other costs incurred in support of the implementation of the
project; and
      (5)   Incur the cost of issuance of bonds for payment of such costs and
to accumulate appropriate reserves, if any, in connection with them.
   (D)   The Chair of the Alva Arena Authority, or his or her designee, shall
be the person in charge of implementation of the project plan in accordance
with the provisions, authorizations, and respective delegations of
responsibilities contained in the project plan. The Chair or his or her
designee is authorized to empower one or more designees to exercise
responsibilities in connection with project implementation.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-171. SALES TAX INCREMENT.
   The sales tax increment from the Increment District shall be 50% of the
City’s 2% undedicated sales and use taxes generated by events hosted at the new
Alva Arena, as measured by the attendance at events hosted by the arena. The
annual sales tax increment shall be calculated as the sum of:
   (A)   One percent of the product of the total number of non-local arena
event attendee days and an original daily expenditure amount of $100 subject to
city sales and use taxes (which daily expenditure amount shall be increased
annually by a percentage equal to the lesser of 2% or the then-applicable
percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (CPI-U)
published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of
Labor); and
   (B)   One percent of the product of the total number of local Arena event
attendee days and an original daily expenditure amount of $40 subject to city
sales and use taxes (which daily expenditure amount shall be increased annually
by a percentage equal to the lesser of 2% or the then-applicable percentage
increase in the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) published
by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor).
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-172. AD VALOREM INCREMENT.
   The ad valorem increment shall be the portion of ad valorem taxes collected
on taxable property within the Increment District attributed to the valuation
of such property, in aggregate, that is in excess of the base assessed value of
taxable property within the Increment District. The base assessed value of
taxable property within the Increment District shall be determined by the
County Assessor within 90 days of the date the ordinance from which this
article is derived is adopted.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-173. INCREMENTS TO BE APPORTIONED.
   The sales tax increment and ad valorem increment from the Increment District
shall be apportioned and paid into an apportionment fund and may be pledged in
accordance with Oklahoma Constitution, Article X, § 6C(B), for a period not to
exceed 25 fiscal years from the date of the ordinance from which this article
is derived is adopted, as provided by law, or the period required for payment
of the project costs authorized by § VIII of the project plan, whichever is
less.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-174. TAX APPORTIONMENT.
   During each respective period of apportionment, the Tax Apportionment Fund:
   (A)   Shall be available to pay project costs under § VIII of the project
plan;
   (B)   Shall constitute special funds of the Alva Arena Authority; and
   (C)   Shall not be subject to annual appropriation as a part of the General
Fund of the city.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)
§ 36-175. DIRECTION OF APPORTIONMENT.
   Pursuant to Oklahoma Constitution, Article X, § 6C, the direction of
apportionment shall continue beyond the current fiscal year for the duration of
the Increment District, or the period required for the payment of project costs
authorized by the project plan, whichever is less.
(Ord. 2021-002, passed 8-16-2021)

§ 38-19. CEMETERY ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby created and established a municipal cemetery of the city to
be known as the Alva Municipal Cemetery, which cemetery shall be owned and
operated by the city as hereinafter set forth.
(Prior Code, § 38-19)
Statutory reference:
   Municipal operation of cemeteries, see 11 O.S. §§ 26-101 et seq.
§ 38-20. BOARD OF TRUSTEES CREATED.
   There is hereby created a Board of Trustees of the city cemetery consisting
of three members, to be appointed by the Mayor of the city, with approval of
the City Council, who shall serve a term of six years each and until their
successors shall be appointed and qualified.
(Prior Code, § 38-20)
§ 38-21. CEMETERY CARE FUND.
   There is hereby created a fund to be known as the Cemetery Care Fund, which
fund shall be invested under the direction of the Board of Trustees with the
approval of the Council, the interest and income therefrom to be used in the
improving, caring for, and embellishing the lots, walks, drives, parks, and
other necessary improvements of the cemetery. Of all moneys received from the
sale of lots and interments, not less than 25% thereof shall be placed in the
Fund.
(Prior Code, § 38-21)
Statutory reference:
   Cemetery Care Fund, establishment and use, see 11 O.S. § 26-109
§ 38-22. CONVEYANCES.
   It shall be the duty of the Mayor to sign all certificates of conveyance of
lots sold in the cemetery, and it shall be the duty of the City Clerk to
countersign all such certificates of conveyance under the seal of the city,
showing the price for which the lots are sold, specifying the names of the
persons to whom the lots are sold, and describing the lots by number.
(Prior Code, § 38-22)
§ 38-23. VIOLATIONS.
   Trespassing upon the grounds of the cemetery or desecration thereof or other
violation, or any willful violation of any of the rules and regulations made by
the City Council or this article shall be deemed a misdemeanor. Any person,
upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine as provided in §
1-14.
(Prior Code, § 38-23)

ARTICLE III: PARKS
Section
   
38-50.   Autos prohibited in parks off roadways
   
38-51.   City parks shall be subject to limited hours of operation; extension
of hours; exceptions

   38-53 through 38-73 reserved
§ 38-50. AUTOS PROHIBITED IN PARKS OFF ROADWAYS.
   All types of self-propelled motor vehicles, including automobiles, trucks,
motorcycles, and any type of motor scooter are hereby prohibited from being
operated in the city park, except on and over regular established roadways in
the park. City and other authorized maintenance vehicles are excluded from the
provisions of this section.
(Prior Code, § 38-50) (Ord. 715, passed 6-3-1974)
§ 38-51. CITY PARKS SHALL BE SUBJECT TO LIMITED HOURS OF OPERATION; EXTENSION
OF HOURS; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   All city parks owned or operated by the city, within or without the
city limits, except the Alva Recreation Complex (ARC), shall be open to the
general public from 6:00 a.m. until 11:00 p.m., daily.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, other than city personnel
conducting city business therein, to occupy or be present in any such city park
during any hours the parks are not open to the public.
   (C)   The Chief of Police or the City Council shall have the authority to
determine earlier or later opening and closing time of the city parks to
accommodate special events and activities occurring therein. Any such request
to extend the hours of usage shall be made in writing to the Chief of Police,
with the reasons for such request set forth specifically therein, and must be
approved in advance by the Chief of Police or the City Council.
   (D)   Any member of the City Police Department may issue a citation to any
person who has violated this section of the law, and require such person to
immediately vacate the park premises, or may arrest any person who has violated
this section, or refuses to vacate the park premises as ordered, without
warrant, and the Municipal Court shall have jurisdiction of all such
violations.
   (E)   Violation of this section of the code shall be a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction, punishable by a fine of not more than $97, and costs.
   (F)   The following shall be exempted from the scheduled hours of operation
set forth herein:
      (1)   Baseball fields, softball fields, football fields, and soccer
fields within the city parks, including the spectator and parking areas, while
such fields are being used for organized sporting events, provided, any
organization hosting any such organized sporting event shall file with the City
Clerk a schedule of dates and proposed usage of such fields. Such schedule
shall be approved by the Chief of Police or the City Council prior to any such
events;
      (2)   Any municipal swimming pool lying within a city park shall be
excluded while the pool is being used for organized and scheduled swimming
activities or events; and
      (3)   The Alva Recreation Complex (ARC) is excluded from compliance
herein.
(Prior Code, § 38-51) (Ord. 2012-31, passed 3-19-2012)
§ 38-52. FISHING REGULATIONS, REQUIREMENTS, RESTRICTIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS AT
HATFIELD PARK POND AND OTHER LAKES OR PONDS OWNED OR OPERATED BY THE CITY.
   (A)   Except as modified herein, all state fishing regulations, including,
but not limited to, permit and license requirements, shall be in effect at the
Hatfield Park Pond and other lakes or ponds owned or operated by the city.
   (B)   All persons fishing at the Hatfield Park Pond, or other lakes or ponds
owned or operated by the city, shall have a valid state fishing license, unless
exempt, and shall obey all state fishing regulations.
   (C)   Fishing is limited to not more than two rods and reels, per person,
with no more than three hooks per line (treble hooks are considered one hook).
All other fishing methods are prohibited.
   (D)   No trotlines, throwlines, limblines, juglines, or yo-yos shall be
permitted.
   (E)   No snagging, seining, netting, cast netting, trawl nets, hand nets,
spearing, gigging, grabhooking, or noodling (hand fishing) shall be permitted.
Bow fishing is prohibited.
   (F)   There shall be no introduction of fish to any pond or lake owned or
operated by the city, by the public, or any source other than those approved by
the State Department of Wildlife Conservation and the city.
   (G)   No person shall deposit unused bait of any character, including, but
not limited to, minnows, small fish, worms, flesh of animals, or any other
deleterious matter which might decay in the waters of any city owned or
operated pond or lake, or upon the lands adjacent thereto.
   (H)   Fishing shall be from the banks and fishing piers only. The use of
flotation devices, including float tubes, canoes, row boats, and other similar
flotation devices powered by electric motor, oars, paddles, or other human
powered means are specifically prohibited.
   (I)   Swimming is prohibited at any city owned or operated pond or lake.
   (J)   Until April 30, 2013, all fish caught must be returned to the water
immediately (catch and release). Effective May 1, 2013, the following daily
fishing limits shall apply.
 
Bass                             3
Channel catfish and blue catfish 7
Crappie                          3
Flathead catfish                 7
Trout                            6
 
   (K)   All fish caught must be returned to the water immediately or they will
count as part of the daily limits.
   (L)   Any member of the Alva Police Department may issue a citation to any
person who has violated this section of the law, and may require such person to
immediately vacate the premises, or may arrest any person who has violated this
section, or refuses to vacate the premises as ordered, without warrant, and the
Municipal Court shall have jurisdiction of all such violations.
   (M)   State game rangers and other representatives of the State Department
of Wildlife Conservation with enforcement powers are authorized to enforce any
regulations contained herein, and all other applicable state fishing
regulations.
   (N)   Violation of this section of the code shall be a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction, punishable by a fine of not more than $100, and costs.
(Prior Code, § 38-52) (Ord. 2012-33, passed 6-18-2012)
§§ 38-53 THROUGH 38-73. RESERVED.

§ 38-74. PURPOSE.
   It is the desire and intent of the City Council to provide free public
library service to the residents of the city, the state, and the nation.
(Prior Code, § 38-74) (Ord. 817, passed 6-3-1996)
§ 38-75. LIBRARY ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established a Library Department of the city.
(Prior Code, § 38-75) (Ord. 817, passed 6-3-1996)
§ 38-76. BOARD OF DIRECTORS; TERM; REMOVAL.
   (A)   The public library shall be governed by a Board of Directors
consisting of seven members selected with reference to their fitness for such
office by the Mayor and City Council. All Library Board Directors shall serve
thereon without compensation.
   (B)   The Board members shall hold office for a term of three years from
July 1 following their appointment. Terms expire on June 30. Vacancies in the
Library Board of Directors shall be filled in the same manner as original
appointment for the unexpired term.
   (C)   Any member of the Board of Directors may be removed by the appointing
authority for misconduct or neglect of duty.
(Prior Code, § 38-76) (Ord. 817, passed 6-3-1996)
§ 38-77. OFFICERS; RULES.
   Immediately after the initial appointment, and after July 1 thereafter, the
Board of Directors shall meet and organize by electing one Director as
President, one Director as Secretary, and by electing such other officers as
the Board may deem necessary. The Secretary need not be a member of the Board.
They shall adopt such rules and regulations for their own guidance and for the
governance and operation of the library as may be expedient and not
inconsistent with the ordinances of the city and laws of the state, subject to
approval of the Mayor and Council of the city.
(Prior Code, § 38-77) (Ord. 817, passed 6-3-1996)
§ 38-78. LIBRARY PERSONNEL, BUDGET, AND DUTIES; COMPENSATION.
   The Board may recommend suitable applicants, subject to appointment by the
Business Manager, for the position of librarian, assistants, and other
personnel. Compensation for these positions shall be set and approved by the
Business Manager, as with other city agencies. The librarian shall be the
administrative officer of the library. The Board shall recommend an annual
budget to the Business Manager. The Board shall set the policy of the library,
supervise, and care for the grounds, rooms, or buildings constructed, leased,
or set aside for the library subject to approval of the Business Manager.
(Prior Code, § 38-78) (Ord. 817, passed 6-3-1996)
§ 38-79. FINANCES.
   All moneys received by the Board on account of the library, including, but
not limited to, moneys paid as a result of fines accrued, shall be paid to the
City Treasurer, who shall deposit the same in the Municipal Treasury in an
account designated the “Library Fund” of the general funds of the city. Such
moneys shall be paid out only upon a claims request submitted to the City
Council for approval with warrants to be disbursed per policies as set for all
city funds.
(Prior Code, § 38-79) (Ord. 817, passed 6-3-1996)
§ 38-80. ANNUAL REPORT.
   (A)   The Library Board of Directors shall make, on or before August 15 in
each year, an annual report to the Mayor and the City Council. Such report
shall include:
      (1)   The condition of its trust on June 30;
      (2)   The various sums of money and property received by the library and
how such moneys have been expended;
      (3)   Statistics on the general character and number of books and
periodicals which are on hand, are lost, have been added, by purchase, gift, or
otherwise, and have been loaned out; and
      (4)   The number of persons making use of the library during the year.
   (B)   A similar report shall be filed at the time with the State Department
of Libraries on forms supplied by the Department.
(Prior Code, § 38-80) (Ord. 817, passed 6-3-1996)
§ 38-81. ANNUAL APPROPRIATIONS.
   The Mayor and City Council shall annually appropriate to the library from
funds available to the city such moneys as are deemed necessary to operate and
maintain the public library for the education and cultural enrichment of the
citizens of the city.
(Prior Code, § 38-81) (Ord. 817, passed 6-3-1996)
§§ 38-82 THROUGH 38-105. RESERVED.

GENERALLY
§§ 38-106 THROUGH 38-123. RESERVED.
ALVA PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD
§ 38-124. CREATION.
   There is hereby created the Alva Parks and Recreation Board. The Board shall
consist of seven members to be appointed by the Mayor, with approval of the
City Council. One Board member shall be a member of the City Council. The
initial Board shall consist of the current members of the Alva Recreational
Complex Board, whose terms shall be staggered in compliance with the schedule
set forth in §
38-125. The Mayor shall be responsible for initially setting the terms of each
member in accordance with the schedule, except the City Councilmember.
(Ord. 2022-003, passed 6-21-2022)
§ 38-125. MEMBERS.
   Two members shall serve an initial term of one year; two members will serve
an initial term of two years; and two members will serve an initial term of
three years. Thereafter, each member shall serve a term of three years and
until his or her successor shall be appointed and qualified, except the member
of the City Council, who shall serve only for a period concurrent with his or
her council term at the time of appointment. Board members shall serve at the
pleasure of the Mayor and the City Council and may be removed at the discretion
of the Mayor, subject to the approval of the City Council. Vacancies shall be
filled for the unexpired portion of the term by the Mayor of the city. Members
shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 2022-003, passed 6-21-2022)
§ 38-126. SELECTION OF CHAIR AND SECRETARY; MEETINGS; QUORUM.
   The Board shall choose one of its members as its Chair and one member as its
Secretary. Minutes of all meetings of the Board shall be maintained by the
Secretary in written form. Copies of the minutes of each meeting shall be filed
with the Business Officer of the city. The Board may adopt and from time to
time amend rules of procedure. The Board shall be required to meet at least
quarterly, and shall comply with all requirements of the state’s Open Meeting
Act, 25 O.S. §§ 301 et seq. Four members shall constitute a legal quorum
thereof.
(Ord. 2022-003, passed 6-21-2022)
§ 38-127. BOARD DUTIES.
   The Board, as created in § 38-124, shall have charge of and control of the
municipally acquired or developed parks and recreation venues, including, but
not limited to, the Alva Recreation Complex, the municipal pool, Hatfield Park,
and Bud Rose Park, except employees thereof, who shall be subject to the
supervision and control of the city, and subject to the rules of conduct and
regulations pertaining to other city employees. The Board shall be authorized
to make rules and regulations governing the management, improvement,
maintenance, operation, and regulation of said parks and recreation venues. No
real property shall be disposed of by the Board by sale, lease, or otherwise,
except by the authority of the City Council; however, the Board may lease
space, area, or improvements, and grant concessions on the grounds proper, for
purposes incidental to the operation of the parks and recreation venues.
(Ord. 2022-003, passed 6-21-2022)
§ 38-128. PREPARATION OF BUDGET.
   (A)   Prior to June 1 each year, the Board shall prepare a budget for
finances for the ensuing fiscal year. The budget shall include the following:
      (1)   Estimated revenues, divided as follows:
         (a)   Federal and state grants;
         (b)   Sales tax revenues;
         (c)   Miscellaneous revenues;
         (d)   Fund from the city;
         (e)   Contributions from third parties or other entities; and
         (f)   Carryover of any funds from the prior fiscal year.
      (2)   Estimated expenditures, divided as follows:
         (a)   Personal services;
         (b)   Services other than personal;
         (c)   Supplies and materials;
         (d)   Equipment;
         (e)   Real estate and improvement; and
         (f)   Miscellaneous expenditures.
   (B)   Such budget shall be submitted not later than June 1 to the City
Council for action of approval or disapproval. The Board shall not approve any
claims or incur any obligations for expenditure unless there is unencumbered
cash in the Commission Fund to the credit of the Board with which to pay the
same.
(Ord. 2022-003, passed 6-21-2022)
§ 38-129. FUNDING.
   Funding for the Board and the management, improvement, maintenance,
operation, and regulation of said parks and recreation venues shall be provided
through the one-half cent sales tax designated for that purpose by Ordinance
No. 99-827, funds received from the city, federal, and state grants, and
contributions received from third parties or other entities. For the purpose of
financing the necessary expenditures in carrying out the purpose of this
division, there is hereby created in the city accounts and Treasury a special
fund to be designated as the “Alva Parks and Recreation Fund,” wherein the
aforesaid revenues shall be deposited, appropriated, and used in conformity
herewith, including funds previously designated as the “Alva Recreation Complex
Fund.”
(Ord. 2022-003, passed 6-21-2022)
§ 38-130. ANNUAL REPORT.
   The Board shall, as soon as reasonably possible after the end of each fiscal
year, prepare and present to the City Council a comprehensive annual report of
its activities and finances.
(Ord. 2022-003, passed 6-21-2022)

§§ 40-1 THROUGH 40-40. RESERVED.
NAMING STREETS AND NUMBERING HOUSES
§ 40-41. CERTAIN STREETS NAMED.
   The name of each and every street running east and west known and designated
before 1954, as “A,” “B,” “C,” “D,” “E,” “F,” “G,” “H,” and “I” streets
consecutively, in the city shall be and the same are hereby renamed to be
hereafter known and designated as follows:
   (A)   “A” Street shall be Mill Street;
   (B)   “B” Street shall be Santa Fe Street;
   (C)   “C” Street shall be Choctaw Street;
   (D)   “D” Street shall be Flynn Avenue;
   (E)   “E” Street shall be Barnes Avenue;
   (F)   “F” Street shall be Center Street;
   (G)   “G” Street shall be Church Street;
   (H)   “H” Street shall be Locust Street;
   (I)   “I” Street shall be Maple Street; and
   (J)   The street running east and west, south of “I” Street and north of
Northwestern State College, shall be Oklahoma Boulevard.
(Prior Code, § 40-41)
§ 40-42. MAYOR AND CITY CLERK TO CERTIFY NAMES.
   It is hereby made the duty of the Mayor and the City Clerk to cause all
proper and legal certificates of the change of the names of the streets of the
city as provided in this section to be certified under seal of the city and
filed and made a part of the recorded plat of the city, and of the additions
thereto.
(Prior Code, § 40-42)
§ 40-43. HOUSES TO BE NUMBERED.
   All residences and business houses fronting upon public streets in the city
shall be numbered, and the same are numbered in conformity with the following
provisions.
   (A)   Odd numbers shall be given to residences and business houses on the
west side of streets running north and south, and even numbers to those on the
east side thereof; and odd numbers on the south side of streets running east
and west, and even numbers to those houses on the north side thereof.
   (B)   On the streets running north and south in the city, numbering shall
commence with number 100, on the east side thereof and on the northwest corner
of the block on the east side of each of such streets at its intersection with
“A” Street or Mill Street, as the same is by this division named, and with the
number 101 on the west side of such streets opposite the point designated for
numbers 100 in each of such streets of the city, and the numbering shall
increase north and south from the points on each street at the rate of 100
numbers for each block distance or space between two streets.
   (C)   On streets running east and west in the city, numbering shall commence
with number two on the north side of each such street, on the southeast corner
of block on the north side of each and every such street at its intersection
with Noble Street in the city, and with number one on the south side of such
streets and opposite to number two at the point of intersection aforesaid, and
shall increase west at the rate of 100 numbers for each distance of one block
or space between two streets.
   (D)   On east and west running streets east of Noble Street, numbering shall
commence with 100 on the north side of each such street, on the southwest
corner of the block of each and every such street at its intersection with
Noble Street in the city, and with 101 on the south side of such streets
opposite the point designated for numbers 100 in each of such streets of the
city, and the numbering shall increase east from such points at the rate of 100
numbers for each distance of one block or space between two streets.
(Prior Code, § 40-43)
§ 40-44. STREETS RUNNING NORTH AND SOUTH.
   All streets running north from “A” Street (by §
40-41 named and designated as Mill Street) shall bear the prefix “North,” and
all streets running east from Noble Street shall bear the prefix “East.”
(Prior Code, § 40-44)
§ 40-45. MILL STREET AND NOBLE STREET UNCHANGED.
   Mill Street and Noble Street named as such shall not be changed within the
city limits, because of their use as base lines for the naming and numbering of
streets for the entire city.
(Prior Code, § 40-45)
§ 40-46. TO RETAIN IDENTITY.
   The future extension of Mill Street or Noble Street within or outside the
city limits, upon the future extension of the streets, shall retain their
identity as such named streets.
(Prior Code, § 40-46)
§ 40-47. EVERY 25 FEET OF FRONT TO BE NUMBERED.
   Every 25 feet of street front or building line on each and every block,
within the city, shall be numbered and bear its respective numbers as provided
for in this division.
(Prior Code, § 40-47)
§ 40-48. HOUSES TO BE NUMBERED.
   The owner or occupant of each and every residence or business house in the
city shall, within 90 days from the first publication of this division, place
on his or her building in a conspicuous place, in accordance with the
provisions of this division, the proper number in figures no less than three
inches in height.
(Prior Code, § 40-48)
§ 40-49. NUMBER TO BE USED.
   The number used shall be that which the main door or entryway is placed upon
the 25-foot section of the street. In case the entryway covers the 25-foot
line, then the smaller number shall be used. This shall apply in all cases to
all occupants.
(Prior Code, § 40-49)
§ 40-50. FAILURE TO NUMBER HOUSES; MAYOR MAY ACT.
   If any owner or occupant of any building within the city shall fail or
refuse to number his or her building within the time herein provided, then it
shall be the duty of the Mayor of the city to have the building numbered and
the number thereof placed conspicuously in the front thereof, and report the
costs of the same in all such instances to the City Clerk, who shall certify
the costs as a tax upon the lot occupied by the building, to the County Clerk,
to be placed upon the tax roll of the county and collected according to law.
Nothing in this section shall preclude the Mayor and City Council from
withholding the certification of such costs to the County Clerk, and at the
time of general tax levy, making other provisions for the payment of such costs
so reported by the Mayor of the city.
(Prior Code, § 40-50)
§§ 40-51 THROUGH 40-73. RESERVED.
ARTICLE III: SIDEWALKS, DRIVEWAYS, AND CURBINGS

40-74.   Construction of sidewalks, driveways, and curbings; permits

   40-78 through 40-97 reserved
§ 40-74. CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS, DRIVEWAYS, AND CURBINGS; PERMITS.
   For the purpose of securing a uniform system of sidewalks, driveways, and
curbings in the city with respect to location and grade of sidewalks,
driveways, and curbings hereafter constructed in the city, it shall be unlawful
for any person to construct or build any sidewalks, driveways, or curbings on
the streets in the city without first filing an application with the City
Clerk, setting forth the location and grade of the proposed sidewalks,
driveways, or curbings, and obtaining a permit to make the improvements from
the City Clerk.
(Prior Code, § 40-74)
§ 40-75. APPLICATION TO BE SUBMITTED TO CITY ENGINEER.
   It shall be the duty of the City Clerk, upon receiving the application, to
immediately submit the same to the City Engineer for approval or corrections.
(Prior Code, § 40-75)
§ 40-76. CITY ENGINEER TO CHECK APPLICATION AND REPORT.
   Upon receiving an application from the City Clerk, it shall be the duty of
the City Engineer to immediately check the application as to the proper
location and grade, and report thereon to the City Clerk.
(Prior Code, § 40-76)
§ 40-77. CITY CLERK TO ISSUE PERMIT.
   The City Clerk shall, upon receiving approval or corrections from the City
Engineer, issue a permit to the applicant, authorizing the improvements upon
the grade and location as approved and fixed by the City Engineer.
(Prior Code, § 40-77)

ARTICLE IV: USE AND OBSTRUCTION OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
Section
   
40-98.   Unlawful to store merchandise on streets
   
40-99.   Unlawful to use streets as a place to store or park
   
40-100.   Property owners may grow grass on parking
   
40-101.   Unlawful to deposit refuse on streets and alleys

40-103.   City personnel exempted from § 40-102
