§ 44-116. DECLARATION OF PUBLIC UTILITY.
   The sanitary sewage system of the city is hereby declared to be a public
utility, and a proper source of revenue for the upkeep and maintenance of the
system, and for other purposes.
(Prior Code, § 44-116) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-117. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   APPROVING AUTHORITY. The Business Manager, the Mayor, or his or her duly
authorized representative.
   BOD (BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND). The quantity of oxygen by weight, expressed
in milligrams per liter (mg/l), utilized in the biochemical oxidation of
organic matter under standard laboratory conditions for five days at a
temperature of 20°C.
   BUILDING SEWER. The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or
other place of disposal (also called house lateral and house connection).
   COD (CHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND). Measure of the oxygen consuming capacity of
inorganic and organic matter present in the water or wastewater expressed in
mg/l as the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical oxidant in a specific
test, but not differentiating between stable and unstable organic matter and
thus not necessarily correlating with biochemical oxygen demand.
   COMMERCIAL USE. All use not for a dwelling or public building, and includes
all roominghouses and hotels having for rent more than four rooms.
   CONTROL MANHOLE. A manhole giving access to a building sewer at some point
before the building sewer discharge mixes with other discharges in the public
sewer.
   CONTROL POINT. A point of access to a course of discharge before the
discharge mixes with other discharges in the public sewer.
   DWELLING. Any housing unit occupied by a single family, and in the case of
multiple units, each is a DWELLING.
   GARBAGE. Animal and vegetable wastes and residue from preparation, cooking,
and dispensing of food; and from the handling, processing, storage, and sale of
food products and produce.
   INDUSTRIAL WASTE. Waste resulting from any process of industry,
manufacturing, trade, or business from the development of any natural resource,
or any mixture of the waste with water or normal wastewater, or distinct from
normal wastewater.
   INDUSTRIAL WASTE CHARGE. The charge made on those persons who discharge
industrial wastes into the city’s sewerage system.
   MILLIGRAMS PER LITER (MG/L). The same as parts per million and is a weight-
to-volume ratio; the milligram-per-liter value multiplied by the factor 8.34
shall be equivalent to pounds per million gallons of water.
   NATURAL OUTLET. Any outlet into a watercourse, ditch, lake, or other body of
surface water or groundwater.
   NORMAL DOMESTIC WASTEWATER. Wastewater excluding industrial wastewater
discharged by a person into sanitary sewers and in which the average
concentration of total suspended solids is not more than 225 mg/l and BOD is
not more than 225 mg/l.
   OVERLOAD. The imposition of organic or hydraulic loading on a treatment
facility in excess of its engineered design capacity.
   pH. The logarithm (base ten) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion
concentration.
   PUBLIC BUILDINGS. The buildings of the state, the county, the city, and
school buildings.
   PUBLIC SEWER. Pipe or conduit carrying wastewater in which owners of
abutting properties shall have the use, subject to control by the city.
   SANITARY SEWER. A public sewer that conveys domestic wastewater or
industrial wastes, or a combination of both, and into which stormwater, surface
water, groundwater, and other unpolluted wastes are not intentionally passed.
   SEWAGE. All matter and material placed in the sanitary sewers of the city.
   SLUG. Any discharge of water, wastewater, or industrial waste which, in
concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any
period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-
hour concentration or flows during normal operation.
   STANDARD MEASURE. The examination and analytical procedures set forth in the
latest edition, at the time of analysis, of Standard Methods for the
Examination of Water and Wastewater as prepared, approved, and published
jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works
Association, and the Water Pollution Control Federation.
   STORM SEWER. A public sewer which carries stormwater and surface water and
drainage and into which domestic wastewater or industrial wastes are not
intentionally passed.
   STORMWATER. Rainfall or any other forms of precipitation.
   SUPERINTENDENT. The Water and Wastewater Superintendent of the city, or his
or her duly authorized deputy, agent, or representative.
   SUSPENDED SOLIDS. Solids measured in mg/l that either float on the surface
of, or are in suspension in, water, wastewater, or other liquids, and which are
largely removable by a laboratory filtration device.
   TO DISCHARGE. Includes to deposit, conduct, drain, emit, throw, run, allow
to seep, or otherwise release or dispose of, or to allow, permit, or suffer any
of these acts of emission.
   TRAP. A device designed to skim, settle, or otherwise remove grease, oil,
sand, flammable wastes, or other harmful substances.
   UNPOLLUTED WASTEWATER. Water containing:
      (1)   No free or emulsified grease or oil;
      (2)   No acids or alkalis;
      (3)   No phenols or other substances producing taste or odor in receiving
water;
      (4)   No toxic or poisonous substances in suspension, colloidal state, or
solution;
      (5)   No noxious or otherwise obnoxious or odorous gases;
      (6)   Not more than an insignificant amount in mg/l each of suspended
solids and BODs, as determined by the State Water Quality Board; and/or
      (7)   Color not exceeding 50 units as measured by Platinum Cobalt method
of determination as specified in Standard Methods.
   WASTE. Rejected, unutilized, or superfluous substance in liquid, gaseous, or
solid form resulting from domestic, agricultural, or industrial activities.
   WASTEWATER FACILITIES. Includes all facilities for collection, pumping,
treating, and disposing of wastewater and industrial wastes.
   WASTEWATER SERVICE CHARGE. The charge on all users of the public sewer
system whose wastes do not exceed in strength the concentration values
established as representative of normal wastewater.
   WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT. Any city-owned facilities, devices used for
receiving, processing, and treating wastewater, industrial waste, and sludges
from the sanitary sewers.
   WATERCOURSE. A natural or human-made channel in which a flow of water
occurs, either continuously or intermittently.
(Prior Code, § 44-117) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-118. DISPOSITION OF FUNDS.
   The funds derived from such fees shall be deposited in the general revenues
of the city to be used for the upkeep, repair, maintenance, and extension of
the sanitary sewage system, and for such other uses as the City Council may
deem fit.
(Prior Code, § 44-118)
§ 44-119. CHECK OR BACK-FLOW VALVES REQUIRED.
   All persons receiving sewer service from the city and having a sewer line
into the basement of their place of residence shall, within 30 days after May
6, 1974, install and maintain in working condition, a check valve in the line,
serving their basement, to prevent any reverse flow of sewage into their
basement from the main sewer line. All installations after the above date shall
have such check valve installed in connection with the sewer line before their
sewer installation will be approved and service furnished by the city.
(Prior Code, § 44-119) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-120. SERVICE OUTSIDE THE CITY.
   The city will accept sewage from persons located outside of the city limits
who are served by a sewer lift station located outside the city limits,
provided the following conditions are met.
   (A)   The users will install their own gathering system and lift station at
their own expense and maintain the gathering system at their own expense.
   (B)   The city will do routine, but not major, maintenance on and operate
the lift station; however, if the pumps, motors, or duplex electrical panel
require rebuilding or replacement, this will not be paid for by the city, but
shall be the responsibility of the users, and the city will discontinue service
until such rebuilding or replacement is completed.
   (C)   Users shall pay a monthly charge as set by the Mayor and City Council
for this service, which also includes acceptance of the sewage by the city,
which charge to be part of, and in addition to the bill for other city
services. If the charges are not paid in full as due, all city services may be
discontinued, as provided in § 44-193.
   (D)   No sewage will be accepted by the city which will damage the city
sewage system. Should nonacceptable sewage be introduced into the lines, then
the entire sewage system shall be disconnected from the city sewage lines until
corrected.
(Prior Code, § 44-120) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§§ 44-121 THROUGH 44-138. RESERVED.
SEWER USE REGULATIONS
§ 44-139. PROHIBITED DISCHARGES.
   (A)   No person may discharge to public sewers any waste which by itself or
by interaction with other wastes may:
      (1)   Injure or interfere with wastewater treatment processes facilities;
      (2)   Constitute a hazard to humans or animals; or
      (3)   Create a hazard in receiving waters of the wastewater treatment
plant effluent.
   (B)   All discharge shall conform to the requirements of this article.
(Prior Code, § 44-139) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-140. CHEMICAL DISCHARGES.
   (A)   No discharge to public sewers may contain:
      (1)   Cyanide greater than five-hundredths mg/l;
      (2)   Fluoride other than contained in the public water supply;
      (3)   Chlorides in concentrations greater than 250 mg/l;
      (4)   Gasoline, benzene, naptha, fuel oil, or other flammable or
explosive liquid, solid, or gas; or
      (5)   Substances causing an excessive COD.
   (B)   No waste or wastewater discharged to public water may contain:
      (1)   Strong acid, iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating
solutions, whether neutralized or not;
      (2)   Fats, wax, grease, or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of
100 mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at
temperatures between 32°F and 150°F (0°C and 60°C);
      (3)   Objectionable or toxic substances, exerting an excessive chlorine
requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite
wastewater at the wastewater treatment works exceeds the limits established by
the approving authority for such materials; or
      (4)   Obnoxious, toxic, or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in
quantities sufficient to violate the provisions of § 44-139.
   (C)   No waste, wastewater, or other substance may be discharged into public
sewers which has a pH lower than five and one-half or higher than nine and one-
half, or any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to
structures, equipment, and/or personnel at the wastewater facilities.
   (D)   All waste, wastewater, or other substance containing phenols, hydrogen
sulfide, or other taste- and odor-producing substances shall conform to
concentration limits established by the approving authority. After treatment of
the composite wastewater, concentration limits may not exceed the requirements
established by state, federal, or other agencies with jurisdiction over
discharges to receiving waters.
(Prior Code, § 44-140) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-141. HEAVY METALS AND TOXIC MATERIALS.
   (A)   No discharge may contain concentration of heavy metals greater than
amounts specified in § 44-140(B).
   (B)   This maximum allowable concentrations of heavy metals in terms of mg/
l, determined on the basis of individual sampling in accordance with the
Standard Methods are:
Arsenic          0.05 mg/l
Barium           5.00 mg/l
Boron            1.00 mg/l
Cadmium          0.05 mg/l
Chromium (total) 0.10 mg/l
Copper           0.10 mg/l
Lead             0.10 mg/l
Manganese        1.00 mg/l
Mercury          0.005 mg/l
Nickel           1.00 mg/l
Selenium         0.05 mg/l
Silver           0.10 mg/l
Zinc             0.30 mg/l
 
   (C)   No other heavy metals or toxic materials may be discharged into public
sewer without a permit from the approving authority specifying conditions of
pretreatment, concentrations, volumes, and other applicable provisions.
   (D)   Prohibited heavy metals and toxic materials include, but are not
limited to:
      (1)   Beryllium;
      (2)   Bismuth;
      (3)   Cobalt;
      (4)   Molybdenum;
      (5)   Uranyl ion;
      (6)   Rhenium;
      (7)   Strontium;
      (8)   Tellurium;
      (9)   Herbicides;
      (10)   Fungicides; and
      (11)   Pesticides.
   (E)   Dilution of waste streams containing toxic materials and metals shall
not be construed to be treatment or disposal of the toxic materials or metals
and shall not be allowed at any point in the sewer system.
(Prior Code, § 44-141) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-142. GARBAGE.
   (A)   No person may discharge garbage into public sewers unless it is
shredded to a degree that all particles can be carried freely under the flow
conditions normally prevailing in public sewers. Particles greater than one-
half inch in any dimension are prohibited.
   (B)   The approving authority is entitled to review and approve the
installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipment with a motor of
three-fourths horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater.
(Prior Code, § 44-142) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-143. STORMWATER AND OTHER UNPOLLUTED DRAINAGE.
   (A)   No person may discharge or cause to be discharged to public sanitary
sewers:
      (1)   Unpolluted stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, or
subsurface drainage;
      (2)   Unpolluted cooling water;
      (3)   Unpolluted industrial process waters; or
      (4)   Other unpolluted drainage.
   (B)   In compliance with the State Water Pollution Control Act (Amendments
of 1972), being 33 U.S.C. §§ 1251 et seq., and other statutes, the approving
authority may designate storm sewers and other water courses into which
unpolluted drainage described in subsection (A) above of this section may be
discharged.
   (C)   Any new conditions from inflow sources into the sanitary sewer
portions of the sewer system shall be prohibited.
   (D)   All new sewers shall be properly designed and constructed in
accordance with the State Health Department requirements.
   (E)   Connections shall be in accordance with the Southern Building Code
Congress International, Inc., Standard Plumbing Code, 1975.
(Prior Code, § 44-143) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-144. HOW TO DISPOSE OF STORMWATER.
   Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such
sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to
a natural outlet approved by the Plumbing Inspector. Industrial cooling water
or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, upon approval of the Plumbing
Inspector, to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet.
(Prior Code, § 44-144) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-145. TEMPERATURE.
   No person may discharge liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than
150°F (65°C), or any substance which causes the temperature of the total
wastewater treatment plant influent to increase at a rate of 10°F or more per
hour, or a combined total increase of plant influent temperature to 110°F.
(Prior Code, § 44-145) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-146. RADIOACTIVE WASTES.
   (A)   No person may discharge radioactive wastes or isotopes into public
sewers without the permission of the approving authority.
   (B)   The approving authority may establish, in compliance with applicable
state and federal regulations, regulations for discharge of radioactive wastes
into public sewers.
(Prior Code, § 44-146) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-147. CHEMICAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   The admission into the public sewers of any of the following waters or
wastes shall be subject to the review and approval of the Plumbing Inspector:
      (1)   Having a five-day BOD greater than 300 parts per million by weight;
      (2)   Containing more than 350 parts per million by weight of suspended
solids;
      (3)   Containing any quantity of substances having the characteristics
described in §§
44-140 through
44-143,
44-145, and
44-146; or
      (4)   Having an average daily flow greater than 2% of the average daily
sewage flow of the city.
   (B)   Where necessary in the opinion of the Plumbing Inspector, the owner
shall provide, at his or her expense, such preliminary treatment as may be
necessary to:
      (1)   Reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to 300 parts per million and
the suspended solids to 350 parts per million;
      (2)   Reduce objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the
maximum limits provided for in §§
44-140 through
44-143,
44-145, and
44-146; and
      (3)   Control the quantities and rates of discharge of such waters or
wastes.
   (C)   Plans, specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to
proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for approval of
the Plumbing Inspector and of the State Water Resources Board, and no
construction of such facilities shall be commenced until the approvals are
obtained in writing.
(Prior Code, § 44-147) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-148. IMPAIRMENT OF FACILITIES.
   (A)   No person may discharge into public sewers any substances capable of
causing:
      (1)   Obstruction to the flow in sewers;
      (2)   Interference with the operation of treatment processed of
facilities; or
      (3)   Excessive loading of treatment facilities.
   (B)   Discharges prohibited by §
44-147(A) include, but are not limited to, materials which exert or cause
concentrations of:
      (1)   Inert suspended solids greater than 250 mg/l, including, but not
limited to:
         (a)   Fuller’s earth;
         (b)   Lime slurries; and
         (c)   Lime residues.
      (2)   Dissolved solids greater than 500 mg/l, including, but not limited
to:
         (a)   Sodium chloride; and
         (b)   Sodium sulfate.
      (3)   Excessive discoloration, including, but not limited to:
         (a)   Dye wastes; and
         (b)   Vegetable tanning solutions.
      (4)   BOD, COD, or clarion demand in excess of normal plant capacity.
   (C)   No person may discharge into public sewers any substance that may:
      (1)   Deposit grease or oil in the sewer lines in such a manner as to
clog the sewers;
      (2)   Overload skimming and grease handling equipment;
      (3)   Pass to the receiving waters without being effectively treated by
normal wastewater treatment processes due to the nonamenability of the
substance to bacterial action; or
      (4)   Deleteriously affect the treatment process due to excessive
quantities.
   (D)   No person may discharge any substance into public sewers which:
      (1)   Is not amenable to treatment or reduction by the processes and
facilities employed; or
      (2)   Is amenable to treatment only to such a degree that the treatment
plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of their agencies having
jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters.
   (E)   The approving authority shall regulate the flow and concentration of
slugs when they may:
      (1)   Impair the treatment process;
      (2)   Cause damage to collection facilities;
      (3)   Incur treatment costs exceeding those for normal wastewater; or
      (4)   Render the waste unfit for stream disposal or industrial use.
   (F)   No person may discharge into public sewers solid or viscous substance
which may violate subsection (A) above of this section if present in sufficient
quantity or size including, but not limited to:
      (1)   Ashes;
      (2)   Cinders;
      (3)   Sand;
      (4)   Mud;
      (5)   Straw;
      (6)   Metal;
      (7)   Shavings;
      (8)   Glass;
      (9)   Rags;
      (10)   Feathers;
      (11)   Tar;
      (12)   Plastics;
      (13)   Wood;
      (14)   Unground garbage;
      (15)   Whole blood;
      (16)   Paunch manure;
      (17)   Hair and fleshings;
      (18)   Entrails;
      (19)   Paper products, either whole or ground by garbage grinders;
      (20)   Slops;
      (21)   Chemical residues;
      (22)   Paint residues; or
      (23)   Bulk solids.
(Prior Code, § 44-148) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-149. INTERCEPTORS.
   (A)   Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the
opinion of the Plumbing Inspector, they are necessary for the proper handling
of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable
wastes, sand, and other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors
shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All
interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the Plumbing Inspector
and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and
inspection.
   (B)   Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious
materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature.
They shall be of substantial construction, watertight, and equipped with easily
removable covers which, when bolted in place, shall be gastight and watertight.
(Prior Code, § 44-149) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-150. OWNER TO MAINTAIN INTERCEPTORS.
   Where installed, all grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be maintained
by the owner, at his or her expense, in continuously efficient operation at all
times.
(Prior Code, § 44-150) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-151. COMPLIANCE WITH EXISTING AUTHORITY.
   (A)   Unless exception is granted by the approving authority, the public
sanitary sewer system shall be used by all persons discharging:
      (1)   Wastewater;
      (2)   Industrial waste; or
      (3)   Polluted liquids.
   (B)   Unless authorized by the State Department of Health, no person may
deposit or discharge any waste included in subsection (A) above of this section
on public or private property into or adjacent to any:
      (1)   Natural outlet;
      (2)   Watercourse;
      (3)   Storm sewer; or
      (4)   Other area within the jurisdiction of the city.
   (C)   The approving authority shall verify prior to discharge that wastes
authorized to be discharged will receive suitable treatment within the
provisions of laws, regulations, ordinances, rules, and orders of federal,
state, and local governments.
(Prior Code, § 44-151) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-152. APPROVING AUTHORITY REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   If discharges or proposed discharges to public sewers may:
      (1)   Deleteriously affect wastewater facilities, processes, equipment,
or receiving waters;
      (2)   Create a hazard to life or health; or
      (3)   Create a public nuisance.
   (B)   The approving authority shall require:
      (1)   Pretreatment to an acceptable condition discharge to the public
sewers;
      (2)   Control over the quantities and rates of discharge to the public
sewers; and
      (3)   Payment to cover the cost of handling and treating the wastes.
   (C)   The approving authority is entitled to determine whether a discharge
or proposed discharge is included under §
44-151(A).
   (D)   The approving authority shall reject wastes when:
      (1)   It determines that a discharge or proposed discharge is included
under §
44-151(A); and
      (2)   The discharger does not meet the requirements of §
44-151(A).
(Prior Code, § 44-152) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-153. APPROVING AUTHORITY REVIEW AND APPROVAL.
   (A)   If pretreatment or control is required, the approving authority shall
review and approve design and installation of equipment and processes.
   (B)   The design and installation of equipment and processes must conform to
all applicable statutes, codes, ordinances, and other laws.
   (C)   Any person responsible for discharges requiring pretreatment, flow-
equalizing, or other facilities shall provide and maintain the facilities in
effective operating condition at his or her own expense.
(Prior Code, § 44-153) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-154. REQUIREMENTS FOR TRAPS.
   (A)   Discharges requiring a trap include:
      (1)   Grease or waste containing grease in excessive amounts;
      (2)   Oil;
      (3)   Sand;
      (4)   Flammable wastes; and
      (5)   Other harmful ingredients.
   (B)   Any person responsible for discharge requiring a trap shall, at his or
her own expense, and as required by the approving authority:
      (1)   Provide equipment and facilities of a type and capacity approved by
the approving authority;
      (2)   Locate the trap in a manner that provides ready and easy
accessibility for cleaning and inspection; and
      (3)   Maintain the trap in effective condition.
(Prior Code, § 44-154) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-155. REQUIREMENTS FOR BUILDING SEWERS; MANHOLE.
   Any person responsible for discharges through a building sewer carrying
industrial wastes shall, at his or her own expense and as required by the
approving authority:
   (A)   Install an accessible and safely located control manhole;
   (B)   Install meters and other appurtenances to facilitate observation,
sampling, and measurement of the wastes; and
   (C)   Maintain the equipment and facilities.
(Prior Code, § 44-155) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-156. SAMPLING AND TESTING.
   (A)   All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters
and wastes to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of
Water and Wastewater, published by the American Public Health Association and
shall be determined at the control manhole provided or upon suitable samples
taken and said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been
required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream
manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building is connected.
Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the
effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of
hazards to life, limb, and property. Cost of sampling of discharge will be paid
by industry, and analysis of samples shall be performed by a qualified
individual or laboratory independent of the industrial user.
   (B)   All tests will comply with the testing requirements of the State
Department of Health and the Environmental Protection Agency. Records of all
tests will be kept on file with the city.
(Prior Code, § 44-156) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-157. POWER TO ENTER PROPERTY.
   (A)   The Superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city
bearing proper credentials and identifications are entitled to enter any public
or private property at any reasonable time for the purpose of enforcing this
article.
   (B)   Anyone acting under this authority shall observe the establishment’s
rules and regulations concerning safety, internal security, and fire
protection.
   (C)   Except when caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain
safe conditions, the city shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to
its property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for
personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out
of the sampling operation.
   (D)   The Superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city
bearing proper credentials and identification are entitled to enter all private
properties through which the city holds a negotiated easement for the purposes
of:
      (1)   Inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, or repair;
      (2)   Maintenance of any portion of the sewerage system lying within the
easements; and
      (3)   Conducting any other authorized activity. All activities shall be
conducted in full accordance with the terms of the negotiated easement
pertaining to the private property involved.
   (E)   No person acting under authority of this provision may inquire into
any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper,
or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind a
source of discharge to the public sewers.
(Prior Code, § 44-157) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-158. AUTHORITY TO DISCONNECT SERVICE.
   (A)   The city may terminate water and wastewater disposal service and
disconnect a customer from the system when:
      (1)   Acids or chemicals damaging to sewer lines or treatment process are
released to the sewer causing rapid deterioration of these structures or
interfering with proper conveyance and treatment of wastewater;
      (2)   A governmental agency informs the city that the wastewater
treatment plant is no longer of a quality permitted, and it is found that the
customer is delivering wastewater to the city’s system that cannot be
sufficiently treated or requires treatment that is not provided by the city as
normal domestic treatment;
      (3)   Discharges wastewater at an uncontrolled, variable rate in
sufficient quantity to cause an imbalance in the wastewater treatment system;
      (4)   Fails to pay monthly bills for water and sanitary sewer services
when due; or
      (5)   Repeats a discharge of prohibited waste to public sewers.
   (B)   If service is discontinued pursuant to subsection (A)(2) above of this
section, the city shall:
      (1)   Disconnect the customer;
      (2)   Supply the customer with the governmental agency’s report and
provide the customer with all pertinent information; and
      (3)   Continue disconnection until such time as the customer provides
additional pretreatment or other facilities designed to remove the
objectionable characteristic from his or her wastes.
(Prior Code, § 44-158) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-159. SPECIAL AGREEMENTS.
   No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any
special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern
whereby any industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted
by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor by the industrial
concern.
(Prior Code, § 44-159) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-160. DAMAGING SEWER SYSTEM.
   No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break,
damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance,
or equipment which is a part of the city sewage works. Any person violating
this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under the charge of
disorderly conduct.
(Prior Code, § 44-160) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-161. NOTICE.
   The city shall serve persons discharging in violation of this article,
except §
44-159, with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a
reasonable time limit for satisfactory compliance.
(Prior Code, § 44-161) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-162. CONTINUING PROHIBITED DISCHARGES.
   No person may continue discharging in violation of this article beyond the
time limit provided by the notice.
(Prior Code, § 44-162) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-163. PENALTY.
   (A)   A person who continues prohibited discharges is guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine of not more than $200
for each act of violation and for each day of violation.
   (B)   In addition to proceeding under authority of §
44-162, the city is entitled to pursue all other criminal and civil remedies to
which it is entitled under authority of statutes or other ordinances against a
person continuing prohibited discharge.
(Prior Code, § 44-163) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-164. FAILURE TO PAY.
   In addition to sanctions provided for by this article, the city is entitled
to exercise sanctions provided for by the other ordinances of the city for
failure to pay the bill for water and sanitary sewer service when due.
(Prior Code, § 44-164) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-165. VIOLATOR RESPONSIBLE.
   Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become
liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned the city by
reason of such violation.
(Prior Code, § 44-165) (Ord. 773, passed 1-6-1987)
§ 44-166. REGARDING INDUSTRIAL USERS.
   At the present time, there are not significant industrial users in the city.
If an industrial user should desire to locate in the city and make use of the
sewerage system, an industrial cost recovery system will be initiated at the
time to compensate for his or her use of the system.
(Prior Code, § 44-166)
§§ 44-167 THROUGH 44-185. RESERVED.
USER CHARGE SYSTEM
§ 44-186. STANDARD FORMULA FOR CALCULATING CUSTOMER CHARGES.
   (A)   All users of the sanitary sewer system shall be charged a fee which is
on file in the City Clerk’s office per month for each 100 cubic feet of metered
water consumption. Users not on a metered water basis, an estimated water
consumption will be made by the Utility Superintendent (who is responsible for
the wastewater treatment and collection system, or his or her authorized
assistant or representative) by comparing the nonmetered user with a metered
user of a similar class.
   (B)   (1)   The charges shall be on a volume basis as the BOD, suspended
solids, and other pollutant concentrations discharged by all users are
approximately equal. Users shall be charged on a volume basis in accordance
with the following formula:
   Cu=Ct/Vt(Vu)+Cb
      (2)   Where:
         (a)   Cu = A user’s charge for operation and maintenance per unit of
time;
         (b)   Ct = Total operation and maintenance (O&M) costs per unit of
time;
         (c)   Vt = Total volume contribution from all users per unit of time;
         (d)   Vu = Volume contribution from a user per unit of time; and
         (e)   Cb = Annual debt service and all cost apportioned equally to
users.
(Prior Code, § 44-186) (Ord. 779, passed 5-4-1987)
§ 44-187. SURCHARGE FOR EXTRA STRENGTH SEWAGE.
   (A)   When the BOD exceeds 225 mg/l, the suspended solids exceeds 225 mg/l,
and other pollutant concentrations from a user exceed the range of
concentration of these pollutants in normal domestic sewage, a surcharge shall
be added to the basic charge, and shall be calculated by the following formula:
   Cs=[Bc(B)+Sc(S)+Pc(P)]Vu
   (B)   Where:
      (1)   Cs = A surcharge for wastewaters of excessive strength;
      (2)   Bc = O&M cost for treatment of a unit of BOD;
      (3)   B = Concentration of biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) from a user
above a base level;
      (4)   Sc = Operation and maintenance (O&M) cost for treatment of a unit
of suspended solids;
      (5)   S = Concentration of suspended solids from a user above a base
level;
      (6)   Pc = O&M cost for treatment of a unit of any pollutant;
      (7)   P = Concentration of any pollutant from a user above a base level;
and
      (8)   Vu = Volume contribution from a user per unit of time.
(Prior Code, § 44-187) (Ord. 779, passed 5-4-1987)
§ 44-188. BIENNIAL REVIEW OF OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE CHARGES.
   (A)   The user charge ordinance shall be reviewed not less than every two
years, regarding the wastewater contribution and maintenance, and the approved
user charge system.
   (B)   The user charges shall be reviewed to accomplish the following:
      (1)   Maintain the proportionate distribution of operation and
maintenance costs among users;
      (2)   Generate sufficient revenue to pay the total operation and
maintenance costs necessary for the proper operation and maintenance (including
replacement) of treatment works; and
      (3)   All excess revenues collected from users shall be applied to the
cost of operation and maintenance attributable to the class for the next year
and rates shall be adjusted accordingly.
(Prior Code, § 44-188) (Ord. 779, passed 5-4-1987)
§ 44-189. SURCHARGE ON TOXIC POLLUTANTS AND EXTRANEOUS FLOWS.
   Each user that discharges any toxic pollutant which causes an increase in
the cost of managing the effluent of the treatment works shall pay for such
increased costs.
(Prior Code, § 44-189) (Ord. 779, passed 5-4-1987)
§ 44-190. DISTRIBUTION OF CHARGES.
   The costs of all operation and maintenance for all extraneous flow not
directly attributable to users such as infiltration/inflow shall be distributed
among users in the same percentage of actual use of water of each user.
(Prior Code, § 44-190) (Ord. 779, passed 5-4-1987)
§ 44-191. NOTICE OF PORTION OF RATES TO COVER WASTEWATER SERVICES.
   Each user must be notified, at least annually, in conjunction with the
regular bill of the rate and that portion of the user charge which is
attributable to the wastewater treatment services.
(Prior Code, § 44-191) (Ord. 779, passed 5-4-1987)
§ 44-192. RECORD-KEEPING SYSTEM.
   A record-keeping system shall be established to document compliance with
federal regulations pertaining to the sewer use ordinance and user charge
ordinance set forth in §§ 44-139 through 44-224.
(Prior Code, § 44-192) (Ord. 779, passed 5-4-1987)
§ 44-193. BILLING AND PENALTIES.
   (A)   Users will be billed on a monthly basis with payment day 15 days after
the date of billing. Sewer users will be billed on the same notice as water
charges and will be designated as a separate entry.
   (B)   Users of the wastewater system not on metered water service will be
billed monthly on an individual notice for wastewater disposal at the rate
established by the Utility Superintendent.
   (C)   Users with delinquent accounts of five days will be notified in
writing by the Utility Superintendent that water or wastewater services will be
terminated unless the account is paid. The Utility Superintendent will utilize
the law enforcement agency to assist as required in the control and management
of the user charge schedule.
(Prior Code, § 44-193) (Ord. 779, passed 5-4-1987)
§§ 44-194 THROUGH 44-224. RESERVED.

GENERALLY
§ 44-225. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   GARBAGE. Every accumulation of animal, poultry, or vegetable matter, the
carcasses of small animals or dead fowl, and all refuse matter from all public
and private establishments and residences. It shall not be construed to mean
sewage, body wastes, and recognized industrial byproducts or wastes.
   RUBBISH. Glass, broken ware, discarded clothing and shoes, trash, tin cans,
bottles, papers, tree limbs, grass and weed cuttings, and such other refuse as
may be termed the natural accumulation of resident families, with all such
RUBBISH properly contained or bundled as prescribed by ordinance.
(Prior Code, § 44-225)
§ 44-226. MANDATORY COLLECTION SERVICE.
   Each residence or business that is within the city limits or that is within
three miles of the city that has a city water meter will be required to pay the
city’s monthly charge for collection and disposition of garbage and rubbish,
except as hereinafter provided.
(Prior Code, § 44-226) (Ord. 804, passed 10-18-1993; Ord. 2007-08, passed 6-18-
2007)
§ 44-227. SERVICE OUTSIDE THE THREE-MILE RADIUS.
   Those residences or businesses that have a city meter and live beyond the
three-mile radius of the city limits shall not be required to pay for charges
for the collection of garbage and rubbish unless the city and the owner of the
water meter both are in agreement thereto.
(Prior Code, § 44-227) (Ord. 804, passed 10-18-1993; Ord. 2007-08, passed 6-18-
2007)
§ 44-228. REQUEST FOR GARBAGE AND RUBBISH SERVICE FROM CITY.
   Customers for garbage and rubbish service by the city shall file an
application for such service with the City Clerk.
(Prior Code, § 44-228)
§ 44-229. EXCEPTIONS TO THE STANDARD CHARGE.
   Upon an annual written request for exemption submitted to the Business
Manager’s office, a committee comprised of the Mayor, Business Manager, and
Chair of the Sanitation Committee will be allowed to make exceptions to §
44-228 if said water meter is used only for agricultural purposes or gardening
purposes.
(Prior Code, § 44-229) (Ord. 804, passed 10-18-1993; Ord. 824, passed 10-6-
1997; Ord. 2006-05, passed 10-16-2006; Ord. 2007-08, passed 6-18-2007)
§ 44-230. APPLICATION TO STATE OR POLITICAL SUBDIVISION.
   The state and political subdivision thereof shall be charged for collection
and disposition of garbage and rubbish pursuant to a separate fee schedule
approved by the City Council.
(Prior Code, § 44-230) (Ord. 2007-08, passed 6-18-2007)
§ 44-231. COLLECTION OF GARBAGE AND RUBBISH BY CITY.
   (A)   Charges and rates for the city’s collection of garbage and rubbish
will be set by the Mayor and City Council. A copy of the current rates shall be
kept on file in the City Clerk’s office.
   (B)   Except as herein otherwise authorized, all refuse accumulated in the
city shall be collected, conveyed, and disposed of by the city, and not by any
other person or business.
   (C)   Actual producers of refuse, or the owners of premises upon which their
own refuse has accumulated, which are used for commercial purposes other than
multiple dwellings, are permitted to personally collect, convey, and dispose of
such refuse, provided such producers or owners comply with the provisions of
this article and with any other governing law or ordinances.
   (D)   All refuse accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed, and
disposed of by the city under the supervision of the city, which shall have the
authority to make regulations concerning the days of collection, type, and
location of waste containers and such other matters pertaining to the
collection, conveyance, and disposal as it shall find necessary, and to change
and modify the same, provided that such regulations are not contrary to the
provisions of the article.
(Prior Code, § 44-231) (Ord. 824, passed 10-6-1997)
§ 44-232. PAYMENT OF MONTHLY CHARGES FOR COLLECTION AND DISPOSITION OF GARBAGE
AND RUBBISH.
   (A)   Billings for garbage and refuse service shall be rendered at the same
time and on the same bills issued for water services, but shall be shown as a
separate item from the charge for water. If garbage and refuse service is
commenced or terminated during a period for which bills will be rendered,
billing shall be prorated on a daily basis.
   (B)   All monthly charges to customers for collection and disposition of
garbage and rubbish, who are not customers for water from the city, shall be
billed by the city in the same manner as water customers. The monthly bill for
such collection and disposition of garbage and rubbish shall carry the same due
date, grace period, and penalties as are carried on the monthly water bills
issued by the city.
   (C)   The garbage and refuse service charge shall be due and payable from
and after the date on the bill on which such charge is shown. Payment shall be
made to the city, but the city shall not accept payment for any garbage and
sewer service charge without payment of the water bill on which said charge is
shown, nor shall the city accept any water bill without payment also of any
garbage and refuse service charge shown thereon.
(Prior Code, § 44-232) (Ord. 804, passed 10-18-1993)
§ 44-233. COLLECTION REQUIREMENTS.
   The following requirements are herewith set up by the city in the collection
of garbage and rubbish.
   (A)   Where alley access is available, residential customers are required to
place trash containers on the alley outside of any yard fence or enclosed
structure.
   (B)   Where alley access is not available, residential customers are
required to place containers no further back than the back line of the dwelling
and outside of any yard fence or enclosed structure.
   (C)   Corner lot customers who do not have alley access may have their
garbage or rubbish picked up from the side street, provided the containers are
placed not further back on the lot than the back line of the dwelling and
outside of any yard fence or enclosed structure.
   (D)   Rocks and dirt shall not be placed in trash containers, and pickup
services will not be provided on these materials.
   (E)   Tree trimmings, hedge clippings, and similar material shall be cut to
lengths not to exceed four feet and separately tied in bundles not more than
two feet thick before being deposited for collection, or be placed in
containers.
   (F)   All grass clippings and yard trimmings shall be placed in a disposable
plastic bag of sufficient strength to contain the contents when lifted. Bags of
grass clippings and yard trimmings shall be placed in the front of each yard
for pick up each Wednesday.
   (G)   Failure to comply with any of these provisions in regards to the
collection of garbage and refuse shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed
$50 per occurrence, per day.
(Prior Code, § 44-233) (Ord. 806, passed 3-21-1994; Ord. 824, passed 10-6-1997)
§§ 44-234 THROUGH 44-259. RESERVED.
RECEPTACLES
§ 44-260. REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Refuse containers.
      (1)   Refuse containers shall be provided by the owner, tenant, lessee,
or occupant of the premises. Containers shall be maintained in good condition.
Any container that does not conform to the provisions of this article or that
may have ragged or sharp edges or any other defect liable to hamper or injure
the person collecting the contents thereof shall be promptly replaced upon
notice. The city shall have the authority to refuse collection services for
failure to comply with this article.
      (2)   Garbage containers shall be made of metal or other approved
material equipped with tightfitting covers and shall be watertight, with a
capacity of not more than 35 gallons. They shall be of a type approved by the
city and kept in clean, neat, and sanitary condition at all times.
      (3)   Rubbish containers shall be of a kind suitable for collection
purposes and shall be of such weight that they can be handled by one person.
   (B)   Storing of refuse.
      (1)   No person shall place any refuse in any street, alley, or other
public place on any private property whether owned by said person or not,
except in proper containers for collection or under express approval granted by
the city. Nor shall any person throw or deposit any refuse in any stream or
other body of water.
      (2)   Any unauthorized accumulation of refuse on any premises is hereby
declared to be a nuisance and is hereby prohibited.
      (3)   No person shall cast, place, sweep, or deposit anywhere within the
city any refuse in such a manner that it may be carried or deposited by the
elements upon any street, sidewalk, alley, sewer, parkway, or other public
place, or into any occupied premises.
(Prior Code, § 44-260) (Ord. 806, passed 3-21-1994; Ord. 824, passed 10-6-1997)
§ 44-261. PLACEMENT OF RECEPTACLES.
   The placing, maintenance, or keeping of any can or container for garbage,
trash, or other refuse upon the portion of any lot dedicated to the use of
streets, commonly known as parking, in any residential area of the city is
hereby prohibited, and declared to be a nuisance.
(Prior Code, § 44-261)
§§ 44-262 THROUGH 44-285. RESERVED.
COLLECTION
§ 44-286. COLLECTION PRACTICES.
   (A)   Frequency of collection. Refuse shall be collected at least twice a
week in residential areas and more often as directed by the city, and shall be
collected from commercial establishments as determined by the city.
   (B)   Limitation of quantity. The city shall authorize the collection of a
reasonable accumulation of refuse of each family during a collection period for
the standard charge and a reasonable accumulation of refuse of hotels,
restaurants, and other businesses and commercial institutions at a fair charge
based upon the average weight or volume. The city shall have the authority to
refuse to collect unreasonable amounts or to make an additional charge for such
amounts.
   (C)   Special refuse problems; contagious disease refuse. The removal of
wearing material, bedding, or other refuse from homes or other places where
highly infectious or contagious diseases have prevailed should be performed
under the supervision and direction of the city. Such refuse shall not be
placed in containers for regular collection.
(Prior Code, § 44-286) (Ord. 824, passed 10-6-1997)
§ 44-287. UNLAWFUL DISPOSALS IN LANDFILL AREA.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to permit, allow, or dispose of sewage
or the refuse from any septic tank, liquefying closet, or chemical closet in
the city-regulated disposal area or any city-regulated landfill.
   (B)   It is unlawful for any person to permit or allow the disposition of
any dead animal in the city regulated disposal area or city regulated landfill,
except that this section shall not prohibit the disposition of dead cats, dogs,
fowl, or other animals the same size or smaller in the sanitary landfill.
(Prior Code, § 44-287)
§ 44-288. DUMP FEES AT LANDFILL.
   The City Council is hereby authorized to set up, by proper resolution, fees
at the sanitary landfill operated by the city covering various types of
vehicles dumping garbage, rubbish, and trash at the sanitary landfill.
(Prior Code, § 44-288) (Ord. 824, passed 10-6-1997)
§ 44-289. CHARGES FOR COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE.
   The garbage and rubbish rate classifications shall be as follows.
   (A)   Charges for trash pickup.
      (1)   Residential.
         (a)   Residents who are inside or within a three-mile radius of the
city limits and who receive city water services will pay a monthly service
charge which is on file in the City Clerk’s office. Trash will be picked up
twice a week with a limit of no more than four containers per customer; or
         (b)   Residents who are outside the three-mile radius of the city
limits and who do not receive city water services will pay a monthly service
charge which is on file in the City Clerk’s office. Trash will be picked up
once a week with a limit of no more than one two-yard container or eight
regular containers per customer.
      (2)   Commercial. Commercial businesses that are inside or within a
three-mile radius of the city limits and that receive city water services will
pay a monthly service charge which is on file in the City Clerk’s office. Trash
will be picked up twice a week with a limit of no more than eight containers
per customer.
   (B)   Charges for dumpsters. Charges for dumpsters provided by the city for
commercial businesses shall be on file in the City Clerk’s office.
(Prior Code, § 44-289) (Ord. 806, passed 3-21-1994; Ord. 824, passed 10-6-1997)

RECORD OF THE ORDINANCE
§ 1. PRESENTATION.
   Whereas, heretofore, on March 1, 1971, the City Council, in regular session,
had presented to it and therefore did consider a resolution of the Planning
Commission recommending the adoption of “City of Alva, Oklahoma: Subdivision
Regulation, November 15, 1970.”
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 1) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 2. BOOKLET.
   Whereas, the city, with consulting assistance, has compiled said regulation
into booklet form bearing the above title and it is the determination of the
Council to hereby adopt said regulation for the city, and to give them the
force of the law.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 2) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 3. PUBLIC EXAMINATION.
   There shall be filed in the office of the City Clerk three conformed, true,
and complete copies of said regulations, available to all members of the public
for examination and inspection.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 3) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 4. REPEALER.
   All regulations, ordinances, orders, resolutions, or parts thereof in
conflict with these subdivision regulations, or inconsistent therewith, are
hereby repealed to the extent necessary to give these regulations full force
and effect.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 4) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 5. EMERGENCY CLAUSE.
   (A)   An emergency is hereby declared to exist by reason of which it is
deemed necessary for the immediate preservation of the public health, safety,
best interests, and general welfare that this ordinance shall take effect and
be in full force and effect immediately upon its passage and approval,
according to law.
   (B)   Passed and approved March 15, 1971: Subdivision Ordinance for the City
of Alva, Oklahoma, an ordinance establishing regulations for the subdividing
and platting or land; providing for submitting plats for approval; describing
procedures; setting forth plat requirements, subdivision design standards, and
improvement requirements; providing for administration; providing penalties for
violation hereof; repealing all other ordinances or parts of ordinances in
conflict herewith to the extent of such conflict; and declaring an emergency.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 5) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
INTRODUCTION
§ 1.10. TITLE.
   The title of this appendix shall be the Alva Subdivision Ordinance. This
appendix is referred to hereinafter as “these regulations.”
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 1.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 1.20. PURPOSES AND AUTHORITY.
   These regulations are enacted in order to promote the health, safety,
morals, and general welfare of present and future residents of the locality and
to bring about the coordinated, efficient, and economical development of the
locality as authorized by 11 O.S. §§ 43-101 et seq., and subsequent amendments
thereto.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 1.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 1.30. JURISDICTION.
   These regulations shall apply to subdividing, as defined herein. The
territorial jurisdiction of these regulations shall be as established by law
and as may be established by agreement with respect to other territories. Such
jurisdiction as of the effective date hereof is the territory within the
boundaries of the locality.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 1.30) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 1.40. COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   From the effective date hereof, all subdividing within the territorial
jurisdiction hereof shall be in compliance with these regulations. All plans,
plats, or replats of land laid out in lots or plats, and the streets, alleys,
or other portions of the same, intended to be dedicated to public or private
use, within the corporate limits of the locality, shall first be submitted to
the Planning Commission for its approval or rejection, and before such plans,
plats, or replats shall be entitled to record in the office of the County
Clerk, they shall be approved by the City Council. The disapproval of any such
plan, plat, or replat by the City Council shall be deemed a refusal of the
proposed dedication shown thereon. The City Council may reverse or modify any
determination made by the Planning Commission under these regulations.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 1.40) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
PROCEDURE: GENERAL
§ 10.10. PROCEDURE.
   To obtain approval of a proposed subdivision, the subdivider shall prepare
and submit to the Planning Commission a sketch plat, a preliminary plat, and a
final plat of the tract or parcel of land proposed to be subdivided, except as
provided in §
15.40 and in §§
30.10 through
30.50.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 10.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 10.20. CONFORMANCE TO COMPREHENSIVE PLAN.
   Every subdivision platted under these regulations shall conform to the
Comprehensive Plan, unless said plan is in conflict with an ordinance, in which
case, the latter shall prevail.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 10.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 10.30. SUITABILITY OF THE LAND.
   Land in FF or FW zoning districts shall not be platted for uses not
permitted in such districts. Any land deemed by the Planning Commission to be
topographically unsuitable for residential use shall not be platted for
residential occupancy, nor shall such land be platted for any other use which
may continue such conditions or increase danger to health, safety, life, or
property, unless steps approved by the Planning Commission are taken to
diminish the above mentioned hazards to a level deemed acceptable by the
Planning Commission.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 10.30) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
PROCEDURE: SKETCH PLAT
§ 15.10. PURPOSE OF SKETCH PLAT PROCEDURE.
   The purpose of sketch plat procedure is to allow the subdivider, inspecting
officer, and Planning Commission to review design and improvement problems
prior to preparation of the preliminary plat.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 15.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 15.20. SUBMITTAL OF SKETCH PLAT.
   The sketch plat shall be prepared in accordance with §§
35.10 through
35.70 and submitted to the inspecting officer at least seven days prior to the
Planning Commission meeting at which consideration is requested. The inspecting
officer shall enter the date of receipt on the plat.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 15.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 15.30. ACTION ON SKETCH PLAT.
   The Planning Commission shall give tentative approval, approve
conditionally, or disapprove the sketch plat within 45 days of its presentation
by the subdivider, but any approval shall be revocable. If the sketch plat be
disapproved or approved conditionally, the reasons for such action shall be
stated in writing, a copy of which, signed by the Chair of the Planning
Commission, shall be attached to one copy of the plat and transmitted to the
subdivider. The reasons for disapproval or conditional approval shall refer
specifically to those parts of these regulations or the Comprehensive Plan with
which the plat does not conform. On conditionally approving a plat, the
Planning Commission may require submission of a revised sketch plat. If no
action be taken by the Planning Commission within the stated time, the plat
shall be deemed to have been approved.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 15.30) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 15.40. WAIVER OF SKETCH PLAT REQUIREMENT.
   The Planning Commission may, on written application by the subdivider, waive
the requirement of a sketch plat, where the Commission determines that a sketch
plat is not necessary for adequate consideration of a proposed subdivision.
Such application shall include reasons for the requested waiver and state that
the subdivider has conferred with the inspecting officer on design and
improvement problems of the proposed subdivision.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 15.40) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
PROCEDURE: PRELIMINARY APPROVAL
§ 20.10. SUBMITTAL OF PRELIMINARY PLAT.
   (A)   After the Planning Commission has approved the sketch plat, or has
waived the requirement of a sketch plat, the subdivider may proceed with
preparation of the preliminary plat, in accordance with §§
35.10 through
35.70. After he or she has prepared the preliminary plat, he or she may take
either of the following actions.
      (1)   He or she may present the preliminary plat and preliminary plat
checklist to the Planning Commission and obtain approval thereof before
proceeding with preparation of the improvement plans.
      (2)   He or she may present the improvement plans to the Planning
Commission at the time the preliminary plat and preliminary plat checklist are
presented.
   (B)   All documents relating to the preliminary plat shall be presented to
the inspecting officer at least 15 days prior to the Planning Commission
meeting at which initial consideration of said documents is requested. The
inspecting officer shall enter the date of receipt on the material submitted.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 20.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 20.20. RESERVATION OF LAND FOR PUBLIC FACILITIES OR PUBLIC UTILITIES.
   Whenever a subdivider proposes to subdivide land which includes, or appears
to include, all or part of the proposed site for a public facility or public
utility as designated in the Comprehensive Plan, the Planning Commission shall,
before approving the preliminary plat of said subdivision, submit said plat to
the public body responsible for acquiring the land for said site. If said
public body determines that the site for the public facility or public utility
should be located within the boundaries of the proposed subdivision, then the
City Council may require the subdivider to reserve for public acquisition said
land and shall designate the boundaries of said land. Such reservation shall be
for a period to be determined by the City Council, but shall not be for a
period of more than six months from the date of submittal of the preliminary
plat. Upon receipt of a preliminary plat where a site for a public facility or
public utility may be involved, the Planning Commission shall immediately
transmit a copy of said plat to the public body responsible for acquiring the
land for said site.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 20.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 20.30. PLANNING COMMISSION ACTION ON PRELIMINARY PLAT.
   (A)   When subdivider submits both preliminary plat and improvement plans.
      (1)   After the subdivider submits to the Planning Commission the
preliminary plat, preliminary plat checklist, and improvement plans, the
Planning Commission shall, within 45 days, approve, approve conditionally, or
disapprove the plat and plans, but any approval shall be revocable.
      (2)   If the Planning Commission finds that said plat and improvement
plans meet all the requirements of these regulations, it shall approve the
preliminary plat and improvement plans by placing a stamp of approval upon each
copy of said plat and plans. Such stamp of approval shall bear the signature of
the Chair and Secretary of the Planning Commission and shall provide that the
approval given thereby does not constitute approval for purposes of recording.
      (3)   If the preliminary plat is disapproved or approved conditionally,
the reasons for such action shall be stated in writing, a copy of which, signed
by the Chair of the Planning Commission, shall be attached to one copy of the
plat and transmitted to the subdivider. The reasons for disapproval or
conditional approval shall refer specifically to those parts of these
regulations or the Comprehensive Plan with which the plat does not conform. On
conditionally approving a plat, the Planning Commission may require submission
of a revised preliminary plat, which shall be processed in the same manner as
an original preliminary plat.
      (4)   If no action is taken by the Planning Commission within the stated
time, the plat shall be deemed to have been approved by the Planning
Commission.
(20.30.10)
   (B)   When subdivider presents only the preliminary plat. Whenever the
subdivider presents to the Planning Commission a preliminary plat and
preliminary plat checklist, without improvement plans, the Planning Commission
may conditionally approve the preliminary plat, subject to Planning Commission
approval of the improvement plans, within 90 days following the preliminary
plat approval.
(20.30.20)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 20.30) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 20.40. TRANSMITTAL OF PRELIMINARY PLAT TO CITY COUNCIL.
   After the preliminary plat and improvement plans have been approved or
approved conditionally by the Planning Commission, the Planning Commission
shall, within seven days, transmit said plat and plans, together with its
recommendations thereon, to the City Council for its consideration. If the
Planning Commission does not approve, conditionally approve, or disapprove the
preliminary plat within 45 days from the date of receipt thereof, then upon
request by the City Council or the subdivider and, within seven days from such
request, the Planning Commission shall transmit to the City Council the
preliminary plat and all records relating thereto.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 20.40) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 20.50. CITY COUNCIL ACTION ON PRELIMINARY PLAT.
   The City Council shall approve or disapprove the preliminary plat and
improvement plans, as transmitted by the Planning Commission, within 15 days
from the date of receipt thereof. Approval shall be shown by a stamp of
approval bearing the signature of the Mayor and stating that the approval given
thereby does not constitute approval for the purposes of recording.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 20.50) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 20.60. DISTRIBUTION OF COPIES OF PRELIMINARY PLAT.
   After City Council approval of the preliminary plat and improvement plans,
one copy of said plat and plans shall be transmitted to the subdivider, and
three copies shall be transmitted to the office of the inspecting officer. One
copy of said plat and plans shall be filed in the office of the inspecting
officer.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 20.60) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
PROCEDURE: FINAL APPROVAL
§ 25.10. PREPARATION AND SUBMITTAL OF FINAL PLAT.
   (A)   Receipt of a preliminary plat and improvement plans, both of which
have been approved by the City Council, shall constitute authorization of the
City Council for the subdivider to proceed with staking of streets and roads
and preparation of the final plat, which plat shall be prepared by a land
surveyor registered in the state, in accordance with §§
35.10 through
35.70.
   (B)   The final plat and improvement plans shall be submitted to the
inspecting officer at least 15 days prior to the date of the Planning
Commission meeting at which consideration of said documents is requested. The
inspecting officer shall enter the date of receipt on the material submitted.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 25.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 25.20. COMPLETION OF IMPROVEMENTS.
   After City Council approval of the preliminary plat and improvement plans,
and prior to submitting the final plat to the Planning Commission, the
subdivider shall:
   (A)   Complete all improvements in accordance with the approved improvement
plans; or
   (B)   Deposit with the City Clerk an acceptable surety bond in the amount of
100% of the estimated total cost of the required improvements, as determined by
the engineer, guaranteeing that the subdivision will be developed in accordance
with the requirements of these regulations.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 25.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 25.30. SUBMITTAL OF IMPROVEMENT PLANS.
   At the time the final plat is submitted to the Planning Commission, the
subdivider shall take one of the following courses of action.
   (A)   If the subdivider elects to deposit the surety bond as specified in §
25.20, he or she shall submit plans for all improvements required under these
regulations, such plans to bear the approval of the engineer. Upon completion
of a portion of the construction of the required improvements, the City Council
may release a portion of the surety bond in the amount of the costs of the
constructed improvements, as estimated by the engineer. Before any portion of
the surety bond may be released, the engineer shall approve the “as built”
plans and specifications and the construction for that portion of the
improvements for which the subdivider has requested release of the surety bond.
   (B)   If the subdivider elects to complete all improvements as specified in
§
25.20, he or she shall submit the “as built” specifications and “as built”
original tracings of all improvements. If the engineer finds that the “as
built” plans and specifications comply with these regulations and that the
actual construction is as shown in said plans and specifications, he or she
shall endorse his or her approval thereon.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 25.30) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 25.40. PLANNING COMMISSION ACTION ON FINAL PLAT.
   (A)   After the subdivider submits to the Planning Commission the final plat
and final plat checklist, the Planning Commission shall, within 45 days,
approve, approve conditionally, or disapprove the plat.
   (B)   If the Planning Commission finds that said plat meets all the
requirements of these regulations, it shall approve the plat by placing a stamp
of approval upon each copy of said plat. Such stamp of approval shall bear the
signature of the Chair and Secretary of the Planning Commission.
   (C)   If the plat is disapproved or approved conditionally, the reasons for
such action shall be stated in writing, a copy of which, signed by the Chair of
the Planning Commission, shall be attached to one copy of the plat and
transmitted to the subdivider. The reasons for disapproval or conditional
approval shall refer specifically to those parts of these regulations or the
Comprehensive Plan with which the plat does not conform. On conditionally
approving a plat, the Planning Commission may require submission of a revised
final plat, which shall be processed in the same manner as an original final
plat.
   (D)   If no action is taken by the Planning Commission within the stated
time, the plat shall be deemed to have been approved by the Planning
Commission.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 25.40) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 25.50. TRANSMITTAL OF FINAL PLAT TO CITY COUNCIL.
   After the plat has been approved or approved conditionally by the Planning
Commission, the Planning Commission shall, within seven days, transmit said
plat, together with its recommendations thereon, to the City Council for its
consideration. If the Planning Commission does not approve, conditionally
approve, or disapprove the final plat within 45 days from the date of receipt
thereof, then upon request by the City Council or the subdivider and within
seven days from such request, the Planning Commission shall transmit to the
City Council the final plat and all records relating thereto.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 25.50) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 25.60. CITY COUNCIL ACTION ON FINAL PLAT.
   The City Council shall approve or disapprove the final plat, as transmitted
by the Planning Commission, within 15 days from the date of receipt thereof.
Approval shall be shown by a stamp of approval bearing the signature of the
Mayor. Before the City Council may approve the final plat, a copy of the
improvement plans approved by the engineer, as provided in §
25.40, shall be submitted to the City Council by the Planning Commission. Until
the public dedications and the required improvements or a surety bond therefor
have been accepted by the City Council, the final plat shall not be eligible to
be approved. Action by the City Council shall include approval and acceptance
of public ways, service and utility easements, and other land dedicated to
public use.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 25.60) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 25.70. TIME LIMIT ON SUBMITTAL OF FINAL PLAT.
   If a final plat for all or part of the property covered by a preliminary
plat is not submitted to the Planning Commission for approval within one year
after the date the preliminary plat was approved by the City Council, the
preliminary plat shall be considered as having been abandoned, unless, on
written application, the Planning Commission approves an extension of time,
each such extension to be for a stated period not to exceed six months.
Approval by the City Council of the final plat of a portion of the property
covered by an approved preliminary plat shall serve to extend the life of the
remainder of the preliminary plat for a period of six months from the date of
City Council approval of such final plat.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 25.70) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 25.80. RECORDING OF FINAL PLAT AND DISTRIBUTION OF COPIES.
   After City Council approval of the final plat, the Planning Commission shall
have the original thereof recorded, at the expense of the subdivider, and shall
transmit one copy thereof to the subdivider. One copy shall be retained in the
office of the engineer. If, prior to the recording of an approved final plat,
the subdivider requests its return, the inspecting officer shall void the
approvals thereon and return the plat to the subdivider.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 25.80) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
PROCEDURE: LIMITED REPLATS
§ 30.10. DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY BY THE CITY COUNCIL.
   The City Council hereby delegates to the Planning Commission authority to
approve limited replats, as defined herein, on behalf of the City Council.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 30.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 30.20. APPROVAL BY PLANNING COMMISSION AGENT.
   The Planning Commission may empower the engineer or other city
administrative officer to approve by endorsement, on behalf of the Planning
Commission, limited replats that meet all of the requirements for limited
replats set forth in these regulations.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 30.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 30.25. CERTIFYING OF DELEGATION.
   No delegation of authority by the City Council to the Planning Commission or
by the Planning Commission to an agent, as provided in §§
30.10 and
30.20, shall be effective until certified in writing by the Mayor to the County
Clerk, and once certified, such delegation shall remain in effect until the
termination thereof is certified in writing by the Mayor to the County Clerk.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 30.25) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 30.30. REFERRAL TO PLANNING COMMISSION.
   Whenever a subdivider desires to create a limited replat, he or she shall
present the replat to the designated agent of the Planning Commission. If the
said agent disapproves the replat because it does not meet all the requirements
set forth in these regulations for limited replats, the said agent shall refer
the replat to the Planning Commission for consideration.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 30.30) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 30.40. REPORT TO PLANNING COMMISSION.
   All limited replats approved by the agent of the Planning Commission shall
be reported to the Planning Commission at its next regularly scheduled meeting.
After approval of the limited replat by the Planning Commission or its agent,
the recording thereof and distribution of copies shall be as provided for final
plats in §
25.80.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 30.40) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 30.50. REPORT TO CITY COUNCIL.
   All limited replats approved by the Planning Commission or approved by the
Planning Commission’s agent on behalf of the Planning Commission shall be
reported by the Planning Commission to the City Council at its next regularly
scheduled meeting.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 30.50) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
PLAT AND IMPROVEMENT PLAN REQUIREMENTS
§ 35.10. FORM OF PLAT: SKETCH PLAT.
   Sketch plats shall be legibly drawn on sheets of convenient size and shall
contain information required by §
35.50.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 35.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 35.20. FORM OF PLAT: PRELIMINARY PLAT.
   The preliminary plat shall be drawn on sheets not larger than 36 inches by
48 inches at a scale of one inch to 200 feet, 100 feet, or 50 feet, and shall
contain information required by §
35.50.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 35.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 35.30. FORM OF PLAT: FINAL PLAT.
   (A)   The final plat shall be drawn in India ink on sheets of tracing cloth
24 inches by 36 inches, at a scale determined as follows.
 
Width of Narrowest Lot           Scale (feet per inch)
Less than 165 feet               100 or 50
165 feet, but less than 330 feet 200, 100, or 50
330 feet and over                400, 200, 100, or 50
 
   (B)   The final plat shall contain the information required by §
35.50.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 35.30) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 35.40. FORM OF PLAT: LIMITED REPLAT.
   (A)   Minor limited replat. In the case of a limited replat where not more
than two contiguous lots are divided and where not more than three lots or
parcels result from their division, a map shall not be required, and the
division may be described by metes and bounds. In such case, if the subdivider
elects not to submit a map, the information required by §
35.50 shall be typed in black or lettered in black ink on sheets of white paper
eight and one-half inches wide and 11 or 14 inches long, with a margin of at
least one inch left blank on all four sides. If a map is submitted, the
provisions of subsection (B) below shall apply.
(35.40.10)
   (B)   Other limited replats. In the case of limited replats that do not
qualify under subsection (A) above, a map of the proposed plat shall be
provided. It shall be drawn in India ink at a scale of one inch to 200 feet,
100 feet, or 50 feet on sheets of tracing cloth, 24 by 36 inches, eight and
one-half by 11 inches, or eight and one-half by 14 inches. If 24 by 36 inches,
it shall have border lines, as provided in §
35.50. If on eight and one-half by 11 or eight and one-half by 14 inch sheets,
a margin of at least one inch shall be left on all four sides.
(35.40.20)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 35.40) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)

1. Whenever a letter appears in a column headed by the name of a plat and
opposite an item in the “required information” column, then the information
described in the item shall be shown on the plat at the time the plat is
submitted to the Planning Commission or its agent.
   (B)   Information to be shown on condominium plats shall be as set forth for
preliminary plats and final plats in Table 1, as appropriate, together with the
additional information set forth in Table 2.
   (C)   Table 1, information to be shown on plats:

                   F             4.9 Building setback lines with dimensions.
                                 4.10 Accurate outlines and descriptions of any areas to be dedicated or
                   F             reserved for public use or acquisition, with the purposes indicated thereon;
                                 and of any areas to be reserved by deed covenant for common uses of all
                                 property owners in the subdivision.
                   F             4.11 Accurate locations and descriptions of all subdivision monuments.
       P           F             5.1 Restrictive covenants, if any.
                   F             5.2 Reference to any separate instruments, including restrictive covenants,
                                 which directly affect the land in the subdivision.
                                 5.3 Owner’s certificate: a certificate signed by the owner(s) to the effect
                   F             that he or she owns the land, that he or she has caused the land to be
                                 surveyed and divided, and that he or she makes the dedications indicated on
                                 the plat.
                                 5.4 Mortgagee’s certificate: a certificate signed by the mortgagee(s), if
                   F             any, to the effect that he or she consents to the plat and the dedication and
                                 restrictions shown on or referred to on the plat.
                                 5.5 Surveyor’s certificate: certificate signed and sealed by a registered
                                 land surveyor to the effect that (1) the plat represents a survey made by him
                                 or her, (2) the plat is a correct representation of all exterior boundaries
                   F             of the land surveyed and the subdivision of it, (3) all monuments indicated
                                 on the plat actually exist and their location, size, and material are
                                 correctly shown, and (4) the requirements of these regulations and Oklahoma
                                 Statutes relating to subdividing and surveying have been complied with.
                         L       5.6 Surveyor’s certificate (see 5.5), if map required.

                                 are no unpaid taxes due and payable at the time of plat approval and no
                   F             unpaid special assessments, whether or not due and payable at the time of
