                                 outstanding taxes and special assessments have been paid on all property
                                 dedicated to public use.

                   F     L       other designated official or agent of the Planning Commission to the effect
                                 that the plat was approved by the Planning Commission.
                                 5.9 City Council certificate: a certificate signed by the Mayor or other
                   F     L       designated official or agent of the city to the effect that (1) the plat was
                                 approved by the City Commission and (2) streets and other lands and interests
                                 dedicated to the city are accepted by the city.

                   F     L       inch from each of the other edges; all information, including all plat lines,
                                 lettering, signatures, and seals, shall be within the border lines. Border
                                 lines shall not be required on letter size or legal size limited replats.
 
   (D)   Table 2, Additional information to be shown on condominium plats:
1. Vertical and plane datum. The plat shall be in three dimensions relating
   vertical control to sea level datum.
   Plan dimensions and areas. Dimensions on the condominium plat shall be in
2. feet and inches to conform with architects’ drawings. Area of the site and
   floor area of each apartment and of all common areas shall be shown in
   square feet.
3. Bench marks. Two permanent bench marks shall be set on or near the building
   at the ground level for future reference in locating units in the plat.
   Elevations. Vertical position or positions, if more than one plane exists,
   or if a portion is at a different slope, of the plane of each floor or
4. ceiling in any space unit shall be referenced to its elevation above sea
   level datum and shown on the face of the plat as floor elevation
   ____________, ceiling elevation ____________. A note shall appear on the
   plat denoting reference plane for elevations.
   Descriptions. Each floor plan of the permanent structure shall be shown, as
   well as basement and roof levels and area of plot plan. The dimensions and
   ties shown for each parcel must be definite enough with respect to both
5. vertical and horizontal control so that the boundaries of each apartment may
   be accurately located by the use of standard survey methods. There shall be
   described the general common elements of the building, and, in proper cases,
   the limited common elements restricted to a given number of apartments and
   designating those apartments.
   Unit lines. All unit or apartment property lines shall be the interior
6. surfaces of the perimeter walls, floors, ceilings, windows, and doors
   thereof.
7. Unit numbers and names. Apartment numbers and plat unit numbers shall be the
   same. The plat name and apartment building name shall be the same.
   Certifications. The condominium plat shall contain all of the certifications
   and approvals required for any other plat. Dedications of public areas and
   facilities and the grant to apartment owners of private easements in common
8. areas and facilities shall be shown. There shall be an approval by the
   inspecting officer indicating that the building plans have been approved by
   his or her Department and a certification by an architect or a licensed
   engineer that the plat is in agreement with the building plan.
   Percentage of unit interest. The proportion of undivided interest shall be
   shown on the plat as well as in the declaration and shall be expressed in
9. decimal form. Any change in proportion of interest shall be filed for record
   with the County Clerk, and the County Clerk shall make a notation on the
   margin of the plat of such amendment, the date thereof, and the recording
   reference numbers.
 
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 35.50) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)

§ 35.70. IMPROVEMENT PLANS AND RELATED INFORMATION.
   Where improvements are required for a proposed subdivision, the following
documents shall be submitted to the Planning Commission:
   (A)   Detailed construction plans and specifications for water lines,
including locations and descriptions of mains, valves, and hydrants;
   (B)   Detailed construction plans, profiles, and specifications for sanitary
sewers and storm drainage facilities, including locations and descriptions of
pipes, manholes, lift stations, and other facilities;
   (C)   The plan and profile of each proposed street in the subdivision, with
grade indicated, drawn to a scale of one inch equals 40 feet or 50 feet
horizontal, and one inch equals four feet or five feet vertical, on standard
plan and profile sheets. Profiles shall show accurately the profile of the
street or alley along the street centerline and location of sidewalks;
   (D)   Street paving plans and specifications; and
   (E)   The estimated cost of:
      (1)   Grading and filling;
      (2)   Storm drainage facilities;
      (3)   Sanitary sewers;
      (4)   Water lines, valves, and fire hydrants;
      (5)   Paving, curbs, gutters, and sidewalks;
      (6)   Street signs; and
      (7)   Any other improvements required by these regulations.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 35.70) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
SUBDIVISION DESIGN STANDARDS
§ 40.10. GENERAL.
   All plats shall be prepared in conformance to these standards.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 40.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 40.20. PLANNED DEVELOPMENT DISTRICTS.
   Where a plan for a planned development district has been approved in
accordance with the provisions of the Alva Zoning Ordinance, the subdivision
plat for such development shall conform to such plan, other provisions of these
subdivision regulations to the contrary notwithstanding.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 40.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 40.30. STREETS.
   (A)   Relationship to adjoining street system. The arrangement of streets in
new subdivisions shall provide for continuation of the principal existing
streets in adjoining areas (or their proper projection where adjoining land is
not subdivided) insofar as they may be deemed necessary by the Planning
Commission for public requirements. The width of such streets in new
subdivisions shall not be less than the minimum street widths established
herein. The street and alley arrangement must be such as to cause no hardship
to owners of adjoining property when they plat their own land and seek to
provide for convenient access to it.
(40.30.10)
   (B)   Relationship to railroads. When the area to be subdivided adjoins a
railroad right-of-way for a considerable distance, a street should be dedicated
approximately parallel to the side of such right-of-way and, in determining the
distance of such parallel street from the right-of-way of the railroad or
parkway, consideration should be given to the distance required for approach
grades for future grade separations.
(40.30.20)
   (C)   Horizontal alignment. Where any street deflects an angle of ten
degrees or more, the minimum radii of centerline curvature and minimum lengths
of reverse curves shall be as follows, where not specified in the Comprehensive
Plan.
Type of Street Radius, Minimum (feet) Tangent, Minimum (feet)
Type of Street                Radius, Minimum (feet) Tangent, Minimum (feet)
Collector street              270                    200
Cul-de-sac                    75                     100
Loop street                   50                     100
Major thoroughfares:
 Having right-of-way width of 500                    200
 115 feet or less
 Having right-of-way width of As specified by the State Department of Highways
 more than 115 feet
Other local streets           140                    100
 
(40.30.30)
   (D)   Street intersections.
      (1)   There shall be a minimum of 600 feet between intersections on major
thoroughfares.
      (2)   Street jogs shall be avoided. There shall be a minimum of 125 feet
between the centerlines of street intersections.
      (3)   Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as
possible, and no intersection shall be at an angle less than 70 degrees.
Detailed designs of intersections may be required.
(40.30.35)
   (E)   Vertical alignment.
      (1)   Thoroughfares having a right-of-way width of more than 115 feet:
Profile grades shall be connected by vertical curves of a minimum length
equivalent to 20 times the algebraic difference between the rates of grade,
expressed in feet per 100; and
      (2)   All other thoroughfares: vertical curves shall be equivalent to ten
times such difference.
(40.30.40)
   (F)   Visibility requirements. Minimum vertical visibility (measured between
two points four feet above pavement level) and minimum horizontal visibility
(measured on centerline) shall be as follows.
 
Type of Street                         Minimum Visibility (feet)
                                       Vertical Horizontal
Collector street or major thoroughfare
having a right-of-way of 115 feet or   500      300
less
Local street                           200      200
Major thoroughfare having a right-of-  As specified by the State Department of
way of more than 115 feet              Highways
 
(40.30.50)
   (G)   Right-of-way widths.
      (1)   Streets shown in the Comprehensive Plan.
         (a)   The right-of-way widths of major streets and highways shown in
the Comprehensive Plan shall be as set forth in such plan. In the case of a
thoroughfare (including any associated frontage road) whose half right-of-way,
as measured from the centerline of the arterial portion thereof, exceeds 65
feet, the requirement of dedication shall be limited to 65 feet, except as
provided in subsection (G)(1)(b) below hereof, and any additional right-of-way
required by the plan shall be reserved by the subdivider for a period to be
determined by the Planning Commission, but not more than six months from the
date of submittal of the final plat, pending possible acquisition by an agency
of government. If, at the expiration of such period, no agency has acquired
such additional right-of-way or has initiated action to acquire it, the
subdivider shall be free to dispose of it for purposes consistent with
applicable zoning and subdivision regulations.
         (b)   Where a thoroughfare is designated in the Comprehensive Plan as
having fully or partially controlled access, and the subdivider elects to
establish a frontage road rather than back or side the lots on the
thoroughfare, full right-of-way shall be dedicated for the frontage road, even
though the total width of such dedication and the then existing half right-of-
way may exceed 65 feet.
      (2)   Streets not shown in the Comprehensive Plan. The right-of-way
widths of streets not shown in the Comprehensive Plan shall be as follows.
         (a)   Right-of-way widths of streets for which classifications in
terms of Plate 1 of the Comprehensive Plan have been determined by the Planning
Commission shall be in accordance with Plate 1.
         (b)   Right-of-way widths of all other streets shall be in accordance
with class 11 on said Plate 1.
(40.30.60)
   (H)   Cul-de-sacs and stub streets.
      (1)   Cul-de-sacs. Cul-de-sacs shall be avoided wherever possible. Where
provided, a cul-de-sac shall not exceed 500 feet in length and shall be
terminated in a turnaround having a property line radius of not less than 50
feet.
      (2)   Stub streets. Where a dead-end street is dedicated for the purpose
of providing future access to adjacent property, its length shall not exceed
500 feet; where any lot has its principal access on such street, the street
shall be terminated in an acceptable temporary turnaround or backaround.
(40.30.70)
   (I)   Access control. Where a subdivision contains or abuts a thoroughfare
designated as having fully controlled access or partially controlled access in
the Comprehensive Plan, the plat shall provide for such control for the purpose
of reducing traffic hazards by eliminating conflict between local traffic
entering and leaving driveways and through traffic. Where a plat includes lots
which directly abut such a thoroughfare, rather than a frontage road, the
Planning Commission may require the subdivider, by appropriate instrument
deemed sufficient by the city article, to relinquish the right of access to the
thoroughfare from such lots.
(40.30.80)
   (J)   Street names. Street names shall be shown; they shall provide for
continuation of the names of existing streets wherever appropriate; they shall
not duplicate the names of streets elsewhere in the city and vicinity. Street
names shall be subject to the approval of the Planning Commission.
(40.30.90)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 40.30) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 40.35. ALLEYS.
   (A)   Where required or permitted. Alleys shall be provided along the rear
lines of lots intended for commercial or industrial use, except in the case of
developments such as shopping centers and industrial parks where access to
individual establishments will be over common space on the lot. Alleys shall
not be provided for lots intended for residential use, unless the subdivider
produces evidence satisfactory to the Planning Commission of the need therefor.
   (B)   Width. The right-of-way width of an alley serving commercial or
industrial properties shall be 24 feet, and that of one serving residential
properties shall be 20 feet.
   (C)   Alignment. Alley intersections and sharp changes in alignment shall be
avoided, but, where necessary, corners shall be rounded at a ten-foot radius or
cut off with an equivalent chord.
   (D)   Dead-ends. Dead-end alleys shall be avoided where possible, but if
unavoidable, shall be provided with adequate turnaround or backaround
facilities, as determined by the Planning Commission.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 40.35) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 40.40. BLOCKS.
   (A)   General. The lengths, widths, and shapes of blocks shall be determined
with due regard to:
      (1)   Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs
of the types of use contemplated;
      (2)   Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions;
      (3)   Needs for convenient access, circulation, control, and safety of
street traffic; and
      (4)   Limitations and opportunities of topography.
   (B)   Length. Residential blocks shall not be more than 1,300 feet in
length, except as the Planning Commission determines to be necessary to secure
efficient use of land or to achieve desired features of the street system;
measurement of block length shall be between property lines.
   (C)   Crosswalks. In any block over 700 feet long, the Planning Commission
may require the subdivider to dedicate and construct a public crosswalk across
the block. Such crosswalk shall have a minimum right-of-way width of ten feet,
of which at least five feet shall be paved.
   (D)   Width. Residential blocks shall be wide enough to provide two tiers of
lots of minimum depth, except where lots back upon a controlled-access
thoroughfare.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 40.40) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 40.50. LOTS.
   (A)   General. The area, width, depth, shape, and orientation of lots shall
be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of
development and use contemplated.
(40.50.10)
   (B)   Areas and dimensions.
      (1)   Zoning. Except as provided in subsection (B)(2) below, minimum lot
areas and dimensions shall be as established in the zoning ordinance, including
the approved plans of planned development districts.
      (2)   Areas platted in small lots. In areas which, at the effective date
of these regulations were substantially platted with lots having areas or
widths less than those required by the zoning ordinance, the Planning
Commission may permit the platting or replatting of lots conforming generally
in area and width to existing lots in the immediate vicinity, but the areas
shall not be reduced below 4,500 square feet or the widths below 50 feet,
except in the case of lots in a townhouse plat.
      (3)   Areas without public water and sewer. Where any lot is proposed to
be served by a well and/or an individual sewage disposal system, the minimum
dimensions of each lot shall be as determined by the Health Department. The
Health Department may require the subdivider to provide acceptable percolation
tests for lots to be served by individual sewage disposal systems, except that
no such lot shall have an area of less than 20,000 square feet.
      (4)   Corner lots. Corner lots shall be increased in width sufficiently
to allow for side street building lines established under §
40.60, front yards established by the zoning ordinance, and building setback
lines established by ordinance.
      (5)   Ratio of depth to width. The ratio of depth to width of a lot in a
residential district shall not exceed three-to-one. Said ratio for lots in
other districts shall not exceed ten-to-one, but this provision shall not
operate to require any lot to be wider than 250 feet.
(40.50.20)
   (C)   Shapes of lots.
      (1)   Replatting. Lots which are sufficiently large to make possible
replatting in the future shall be of such shape as to facilitate replatting.
      (2)   Side lot lines. Side lot lines shall be substantially at right
angles or radial to street lines.
(40.50.30)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 40.50) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 40.60. BUILDING SETBACK LINES.
   (A)   Where a building setback line is shown on a plat, it shall not be in
front of any building setback line established by ordinance.
   (B)   Where a planned development district has been established, any
building setback line on a plat shall conform to any such line established for
such district.
   (C)   Except in the case of a planned development district, where a building
setback line is shown along any block face on a plat, such line:
      (1)   Shall not permit the front yard of any part of such block face to
be less than 60% of the front yard required under zoning; and
      (2)   Shall not reduce the average depth of front yard along such block
face below the front yard required under zoning.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 40.60) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 40.70. EASEMENTS AND DEDICATIONS FOR PUBLIC USE.
   (A)   Easements and dedications in general. No dedication for a drainage
easement or a street or other public use shall be shown on a plat unless the
City Council determines to accept such dedication.
(40.70.10)
   (B)   Easements: drainage. When a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse,
drainage way, channel, stream, or creek, the subdivider shall provide a storm
water easement or drainage right-of-way of sufficient width for such purpose
and for maintenance, wherever the Planning Commission finds such easement
desirable.
(40.70.20)
   (C)   Easements: utility. Where alleys are not provided or may not be used
for that purpose, easements not less than seven and one-half feet in width
shall be provided at the rear of each lot for poles, wires, conduits, storm
sewers, sanitary sewers, gas lines, water mains and lines, and other utility
purposes. In no case shall the combined widths of the easements on both sides
of a rear lot line be less than 15 feet. Additional easements shall be provided
where required by the Planning Commission.
(40.70.30)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 40.70) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
SUBDIVISION IMPROVEMENT REQUIREMENTS
§ 50.10. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
   The subdivider is put on notice that, within the subdivision, he or she
shall, at his or her own expense, pave all streets, and install sidewalks,
street signs, storm drainage improvements, sanitary sewerage facilities, and
water facilities, as required by these regulations, except as may be provided
by other ordinances of the city.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 50.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 50.20. STREETS AND DRAINAGE: GENERAL.
   The subdivider shall improve or agree to improve all streets, highways,
alleys, and other ways, and provide drainage improvements, all in such manner
as is necessary for the general use of lot owners in the subdivision and to
meet local traffic and drainage needs.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 50.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 50.25. STREET IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   Where required. Street grading and paving shall be required for:
      (1)   All streets to be opened by dedication in the subdivision, but
where a frontage road is provided, the improvement requirement shall apply only
to such frontage road and not to the through portion of the street;
      (2)   All streets to be dedicated for the purpose of providing the second
half of a then existing half-street; and
      (3)   All streets to be dedicated for frontage roads, including those
abutting or adjacent to then existing streets.
(50.25.10)
   (B)   Where not required. Street grading and paving shall not be required
for:
      (1)   Widening of then existing streets, except as provided in subsection
(A) above; or
      (2)   Then existing streets.
(50.25.20)
   (C)   Specifications. All roadways shall be paved and curbs and gutters
shall be installed according to the following specifications.
      (1)   Street grades.
         (a)   No street shall have a finished grade of less than 0.5%.
         (b)   Street grades for major thoroughfares shall not exceed 5%.
         (c)   Street grades for all other classes of thoroughfares shall not
exceed 8%.
      (2)   Pavement widths. Where grading and paving are required, the width
of the paving shall be as follows.
         (a)   Paving widths of the following thoroughfares shall be in
accordance with the appropriate cross-sections on Plate 1, “Typical
Thoroughfare Cross-Sections,” in the Comprehensive Plan:
            1.   Thoroughfares designated as major streets or highways on the
Comprehensive Plan map;
            2.   Other thoroughfares whose classifications in terms of Plate 1
have been determined by the Planning Commission; and
            3.   Thoroughfares not classified under subsections (C)(2)(a) and
(C)(2)(b) of this section, which thoroughfares are hereby designated as class
11.
         (b)   The width of alley paving shall be 24 feet, except in the case
of narrower existing alleys whose right-of-way is not to be widened, where the
paving width shall be the width of the right-of-way.
         (c)   Where a paving width of more than 40 feet is required, the
subdivider shall not be responsible for paving more than 40 feet of such width.
The subdivider shall be responsible for providing the curb and gutter,
regardless of the width of paving.
         (d)   The pavement widths set forth in this subsection (C)(2) apply
only where the subdivision abuts both sides of an existing or proposed street.
Where a subdivision abuts only one side of a street, then only one-half of the
pavement width is required.
      (3)   Curb radii.
         (a)   Street intersections involving major thoroughfares shall have a
minimum street corner radius of 30 feet at the curb line.
         (b)   Radius of the outer curb in a cul-de-sac turnaround shall be not
less than 40 feet at the curb line. Radius of the inner curb shall be such that
the width of pavement from back of curb to back of curb shall not be less than
27 feet.
         (c)   Radii of curbs at street corners, other than on major
thoroughfares, shall not be less than 25 feet.
      (4)   Pavement types.
         (a)   Pavement types for pavements having a maximum surface width of
30 feet, face-to-face of curb, shall be either Portland cement concrete or
asphaltic concrete as specified below:
            1.   Portland cement concrete pavement five inches thick laid on a
subgrade compacted to 95% Standard Proctor density, with a moisture content at
slightly above optimum; concrete to be 3,500 psi, six sack mix. The pavement
shall be laid on a minimum of two-inch sand cushion; or
            2.   Asphaltic concrete (hot mix, hot laid) pavement two inches
thick on a six-inch stabilized gravel or crushed stone base course, with six-
inch subgrade compacted to 95% Standard Proctor density. The above asphaltic
concrete street shall have a Portland cement concrete curb and 18-inch concrete
gutter.
         (b)   Pavement types for pavements having a width of more than 30
feet, face-to-face of curb, shall be either:
            1.   Portland cement concrete, as specified above for pavements
having a maximum width of 30 feet; or
            2.   Asphaltic concrete pavement, as specified above for pavements
having a maximum width of 30 feet, except that the pavement shall be four
inches thick.
         (c)   Detailed plans, specifications, and mode of application shall be
on file in the office of the Engineer for inspection or use by any persons
concerned with such types of pavement.
      (5)   Curbs. Curbs shall be of an upright design of not less than six
inches in height in all applications, except driveway entrances.
(50.25.30)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 50.25) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971; Ord. 739, passed
8-21-1978)
§ 50.30. SIDEWALKS.
   (A)   Sidewalks may be provided by the subdivider along all streets in each
subdivision.
   (B)   All sidewalks shall be a minimum width of 42 inches and be at a
distance of one foot from the property line.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 50.30) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 50.35. STREET SIGNS.
   Street signs shall be installed in accordance with specifications on file in
the office of the city engineer.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 50.35) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971; Ord. 739, passed
8-21-1978)
§ 50.40. STORM DRAINAGE.
   (A)   General requirement. All land development shall be related to the
surrounding drainage pattern, with provisions made for proper storm drainage
facilities.
(50.40.10)
   (B)   Minimum runoff. Minimum runoff shall be determined by the Rational
Method, or an equivalent formula with conventional runoff factors, using as a
minimum a rainfall rate of two and one-half inches per hour.
(50.40.20)
   (C)   Water in stub streets and cul-de-sacs. In all instances, provisions
shall be made for adequate storm drainage and drainage structures to prevent
water from standing in the ends of stub streets of cul-de-sacs.
(50.40.30)
   (D)   Diversion of water from natural course. Diversion of storm flow shall
be avoided, if at all possible. If storm water is to be diverted from its
natural course, the construction plans shall include:
      (1)   A sketch showing the existing waterway and the location of the
proposed channel change;
      (2)   Profile of existing watercourse; and
      (3)   Provisions for sodding or paving to prevent soil erosion and
silting in open watercourses.
(50.40.40)
   (E)   Emergency overflow. Where an underground drainage system is installed,
emergency surface drainage overflows shall be provided to prevent possible
flooding in the event of failure of the underground drainage system.
(50.40.50)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 50.40) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 50.50. WATER SUPPLY.
   The developer shall install water lines to serve each lot in the
subdivision. Where connection to a community water system or public water
supply is not to be made immediately, plans shall be prepared for future
installation of a water distribution system to serve each lot, and those parts
of such system which will be in the paved portion of streets and alleys shall
be installed before the streets or alleys are paved. Plans for water systems
shall conform in all respects to the Standards for the Design of Public Water
Systems of the State Department of Health.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 50.50) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 50.60. SANITARY SEWERAGE.
   Sanitary sewers shall be installed to serve each lot in the subdivision when
connections are to be made immediately to a community disposal system or a
public sewer system. Where such connection to said system is not to be made
immediately, plans shall be prepared for future development and installation of
a sewerage system to serve each lot, and those parts of such system which will
be in the paved portion of streets and alleys shall be installed before the
streets or alleys are paved. Plans for sewer systems shall conform in all
respects to the Standards for Water Pollution Control Facilities of the State
Department of Health.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 50.60) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 50.70. SURVEY MONUMENTS.
   (A)   Concrete monuments, the specifications of which are set forth in this
section, shall be set in each subdivision. At least two reference ties shall be
established in the most permanent manner possible, to the exterior corners of
the part finally platted. The markers and ties shall be shown on each final
plat of all subdivisions. The monuments shall be placed normally on block
corners or points of curve and shall be no more than 1,000 feet apart.
   (B)   The monuments shall be constructed of reinforced concrete (3,000 psi
in 28 days) and have no less than two No. 3 deformed bars in them, evenly
spaced. The monuments shall be six inches in diameter and 36 inches in length.
Each monument shall have a cross case in the top center or a copper rod
extending one-fourth inch above the concrete. All such monuments may be precast
or cast in the hole.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 50.70) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 50.80. UNDERGROUND WIRES AND CABLES.
   Wires and cables providing local utility and similar services (including,
but not limited to, electric, telephone, cable television, and street lighting)
in residential subdivisions shall be placed underground.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 50.80) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
VARIANCES
§ 60.10. VARIANCES AUTHORIZED.
   Whenever the tract to be subdivided is of such unusual size, shape, or is
surrounded by such development or unusual conditions that the strict
application of the requirements contained in these regulations would result in
substantial hardship or inequity, the Planning Commission may vary or modify,
except as otherwise provided herein, such requirements of design, but not of
procedure or improvements, that the subdivider may develop his or her property
in a reasonable manner, but so, at the same time, the public welfare and
interests of the city are protected, and the general intent and spirit of these
regulations and of the Comprehensive Plan are preserved.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 60.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 60.20. VARIANCE PROCEDURE.
   A variance may be granted upon written request of the subdivider or his or
her agent, stating the reason(s) for each requested modification. Approval of a
variance shall require the favorable vote of a majority of all the members of
the Planning Commission. No variance shall be granted unless the reasons
therefor are entered in the minutes of the Planning Commission.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 60.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
§ 70.10. ADMINISTRATION.
   The engineer shall be responsible for administering the parts of these
regulations relating to subdivision improvements, and the inspecting officer
shall be responsible for administering all other parts of these regulations.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 70.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 70.20. PLATS COMMITTEE.
   (A)   Appointment. The Chair of the Planning Commission may appoint a Plats
Committee consisting of representatives of public agencies and public utility
companies. In lieu of appointing members, the Chair may request said agencies
and companies to designate representatives and alternates to serve on the
Committee.
   (B)   Organization. The inspecting officer shall serve as Chair of the Plats
Committee, shall appoint the Secretary of the Committee, shall call meetings of
the Committee, and shall provide the members thereof with copies of plats and
other necessary information.
   (C)   Function. The function of the Plats Committee shall be to provide a
means for review of plats by interested agencies and utility companies and for
advising the Planning Commission on plats. In making recommendations on plats,
the members of the Committee shall act in their individual capacities, and the
Committee as a whole shall not make recommendations on plats.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 70.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 70.30. AREAS FOR USE IN COMMON.
   Whenever a plat provides for the dedication of property to be held or used
in common by the owners of other property described by such plat, such plat
shall not receive final approval until the city article certifies that the
subdivider has taken all necessary steps to ensure:
   (A)   The establishment of a property owners’ association or other means for
adequately maintaining the common property; and
   (B)   Provision made for disposition of the common property in the event of
dissolution of the association.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 70.30) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 70.40. PLANNED DEVELOPMENT DISTRICTS.
   Any final plat of property in a planned development district established
pursuant to the zoning ordinance shall not be given final approval until the
effective date of the final approval of the plan for such district.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 70.40) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 70.50. FEES.
   (A)   General. The following fees shall be paid on the filing of any
application and prior to the processing thereof:
      (1)   Sketch plat: no fee;
      (2)   Preliminary plat: $10;
      (3)   Final plat:
         (a)   Basic fee: $10;
         (b)   Additional fee per lot: $1; and
         (c)   Additional fee per lot over ten lots: $0.10.
      (4)   Limited replat:
         (a)   Where not more than two lots are divided into not more than
three lots: $2; and
         (b)   All others: $5.
      (5)   Plats and replats whose sole purpose is to dedicate land to the
public: no fee.
   (B)   Plats in planned development districts. For each subdivision in a
planned development district, there shall be paid fees as set forth in
subsection (A) above of this section, in addition to the fees established for
planned development districts in the zoning ordinance.
   (C)   Calculation and payment of fees. The inspecting officer shall
calculate the fee for each application. Each fee shall be paid to the City
Clerk, who shall issue a receipt stating the purpose of the payment, which
receipt must be filed with the application as evidence of payment.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 70.50) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 70.60. PERMITS WITHHELD ON UNAPPROVED PLATS.
   The inspecting officer shall not issue a building permit for any structure
on any lot in a subdivision for which the plat has not been approved and
recorded in the manner prescribed herein; provided however, that this section
shall not apply to a lot in a recorded plat if, at the time of recording, the
plat was not required by law to be approved.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 70.60) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 70.70. VIOLATION AND PENALTY.
   A violation of these regulations shall be deemed a misdemeanor and shall be
punishable by fine or by imprisonment, or both.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 70.70) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
AMENDMENTS AND RULES
§ 80.10. AMENDMENTS.
   These regulations may be amended from time to time by the City Council.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 80.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 80.20. RULES.
   The Planning Commission may adopt and amend rules for the administering of
these regulations, provided they are not in conflict therewith.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 80.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
INTERPRETATION AND DEFINITIONS
§ 90.10. REFERENCES.
   References herein to articles, sections, subsections, and paragraphs are to
those parts of these regulations, unless the context indicates otherwise.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.20. CONSTRUCTION.
   For the purpose of this ordinance, the language set forth herein shall be
interpreted in accordance with the following rules of construction.
   (A)   Words used in the singular number include the plural, and words used
in the plural include the singular.
   (B)   Words used in the present tense include the future tense.
   (C)   The word PERSON includes a firm, partnership, or corporation.
   (D)   The word LOT includes the words PLOT, PARCEL, or TRACT.
   (E)   The word SHALL is always mandatory and not merely directory.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.40. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this appendix, certain terms are defined in §§
90.41 through
90.66.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.40) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.41. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “A.”
   ALLEY. A public thoroughfare of narrow width which affords only a secondary
means of access to abutting property.
(90.41.10)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.41) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.42. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “B.”
   BLOCK. An area of land within a subdivision, bounded entirely by streets or
highways, except alleys, or by boundaries of the subdivision.
(90.42.10)
   BUILDING SETBACK LINE. A line established parallel or nearly parallel to the
center of an existing or proposed street or highway, indicating the minimum
distance from such centerline that a building or other structure may be
erected.
(90.42.20)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.42) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.43. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “C.”
   CITY. The City of Alva, Oklahoma.
(90.43.10)
   CITY COUNCIL. The governing body of the city.
(90.43.20)
   COMMON AREA. A portion of a subdivision, lot, or structure used in common by
two or more owners or tenants of other portions of such subdivision, lot, or
structure.
(90.43.30)
   COMPREHENSIVE PLAN. The Comprehensive Plan of the city.
(90.43.40)
   CONDOMINIUM. Ownership in common with others of a parcel of land and certain
parts of a building thereon which would normally be used by all the occupants,
such as yards, foundations, basements, floors, walls, hallways, stairways,
elevators, and all other related common elements, together with individual
ownership in fee of a particular unit or apartment in such building.
(90.43.50)
   COUNTY. Woods County, Oklahoma.
(90.43.60)
   CUL-DE-SAC. A dead-end street which is within a subdivision and which is not
planned or proposed to be extended.
(90.43.70)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.43) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.45. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “E.”
   EASEMENT. A grant by a property owner to the public, a corporation, or a
person for the use of all or part of a parcel of land for specific purposes.
(90.45.10)
   ENGINEER. The engineer of the city or the person designated by the City
Council to serve in that capacity, except when the context otherwise indicates.
(90.45.20)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.45) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.46. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “F.”
   FRONTAGE ROAD. A street which is contiguous to a street having partially or
full controlled access and which provides access thereto from abutting
properties.
(90.46.10)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.46) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.48. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “H.”
   HEALTH DEPARTMENT. The Health Department of the county.
(90.48.10)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.48) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.49. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “I.”
   INSPECTING OFFICER. The officer designated by the City Council to administer
this ordinance.
(90.49.10)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.49) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.52. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “L.”
   LOCALITY. The city.
(90.52.10)
   LOT. A parcel of land intended to be treated as a unit for transfer of
ownership or for development.
(90.52.20)
   LOT AREA. The total area included within the boundaries of a lot, measured
in a horizontal plane. In the case of a lot abutting an alley, LOT AREA shall
include one-half of the area of such alley, but not more than ten feet of alley
width shall be included in lot area.
(90.52.30)
   LOT LINES. The lines bounding a lot.
(90.52.40)
   LOT LINE, FRONT. A lot line that is also a street line.
(90.52.50)
   LOT LINE, REAR. The lot line opposite the front lot line. In the case of a
corner lot, the shorter of such lines.
(90.52.60)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.52) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.53. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “M.”
   MAJOR STREET OR HIGHWAY. A street so designated in the Comprehensive Plan; a
major thoroughfare.
(90.53.10)
   MAYOR. The Mayor of the city.
(90.53.20)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.53) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.56. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “P.”
   PLANNED DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT. A district of that name established under the
zoning ordinance.
(90.56.10)
   PLANNING COMMISSION. The City Planning Commission.
(90.56.20)
   PLAT. A map, chart, or written representation indicating the subdivision or
resubdivision of land which, in final form, is intended to be filed of record.
(90.56.30)
   PLAT, FINAL. A finished plat showing completely and accurately all
information and certification necessary for approval under these regulations.
(90.56.35)
   PLAT, PRELIMINARY. A plat showing the proposed layout of a subdivision in
sufficient detail to indicate its feasibility, but not in final form for
recording and the details not completely computed.
(90.56.40)
   PLAT, SKETCH. A plat showing in general the area to be subdivided, the
street layout, lots, and blocks, and the general nature of improvements.
(90.56.50)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.56) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.58. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “R.”
   REPLAT. A plat showing the resubdividing of all or part of a subdivision
whose plat has previously been recorded.
(90.58.10)
   REPLAT, LIMITED. A replat which is limited to all or part of one block and
which does not involve or necessitate any change in an easement or public
right-of-way.
(90.58.20)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.58) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.59. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “S.”
   STREET. Any public or private right-of-way, highway, road, land, square,
court, or way set aside as a permanent right-of-way for street purposes, 30
feet or more in width if it existed at the time of the enactment of these
regulations, and any public or private way 50 feet or more in width if created
after the enactment of these regulations.
(90.59.30)
   STREET, COLLECTOR. A street which collects traffic from local streets and
carries it to one or more major thoroughfares of other COLLECTOR STREETS.
(90.59.40)
   STREET LINE. The boundary line between a street and abutting property.
(90.59.50)
   STREET, LOCAL. A street intended primarily to provide access to abutting
property and carrying little or no through traffic; ordinarily a street which
is not a major thoroughfare or a collector street is a LOCAL STREET.
(90.59.60)
   STREET, STUB. A dead-end street in a subdivision which extends to the
boundary thereof and is intended to be extended outside the subdivision.
(90.59.70)
   SUBDIVIDER. Any person, individual, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, estate, or trust, or any other group or combination acting as a
unit dividing or proposing to divide land so as to constitute a subdivision as
herein defined; the term includes any agent of the subdivider.
(90.59.75)
   SUBDIVISION. Any division of land into two or more lots, parcels, tracts, or
areas, any one of which, after division, has an area of ten acres or less, or
any division of land involving the vacation or dedication or right-of-way or
alignment of an existing or proposed street or highway or public utility
easement, or the resubdivision of land heretofore subdivided and, when
appropriate to the context, the land subdivider.
(90.59.80)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.59) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.60. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “T.”
   TOWNHOUSE. One of a series of three or more attached dwelling units,
separated from one another by continuous vertical party walls without openings
from basement floor to roof.
(90.60.10)
   TOWNHOUSE DEVELOPMENT. A tract of land on which there is built or is
proposed to be built three or more townhouses, including the sites of the
townhouses and all common spaces.
(90.60.15)
   TOWNHOUSE PLAT. A plat for a townhouse development.
(90.60.20)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.60) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 90.66. TERMS BEGINNING WITH “Z.”
   ZONING ORDINANCE. The zoning ordinance of the city.
(90.66.10)
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 90.66) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
LEGAL STATUS PROVISIONS
§ 95.10. MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS.
   In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this appendix
shall be held to be minimum requirements, adopted for the promotion of the
public health, safety, morals, or general welfare.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 95.10) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 95.20. REPEAL OF CONFLICTING REGULATIONS.
   All regulations, ordinances, orders, resolutions, or parts thereof in
conflict with these subdivision regulations, or inconsistent therewith, are
hereby repealed to the extent necessary to give these regulations full force
and effect.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 95.20) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 95.30. SEPARABILITY.
   In case any portion of this ordinance shall be held by a court to be invalid
or unconstitutional, the remainder of this appendix shall not thereby be
invalid, but shall remain in full force.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 95.30) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 95.40. WHEN EFFECTIVE.
   An emergency is hereby declared to exist by reason of which it is deemed
necessary for the immediate preservation of the public health, safety, best
interests, and general welfare that this appendix shall take effect and be in
full force and effect immediately upon its passage and approval, according to
law.
(Prior Code, Appendix A, § 95.40) (Ord. 703, passed 3-15-1971)

INTRODUCTION
§ 1.10. TITLE.
   (A)   The title of this appendix shall be the Alva Zoning Ordinance.
   (B)   This appendix is hereby declared to be enacted for the preservation
and promotion of the public health, welfare, and safety, and for the
preservation and promotion of the convenience, good order, tranquility,
happiness, best interests, and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city,
and of the general public, and to facilitate and encourage the orderly growth
and expansion of this municipality, as authorized by 11 O.S. §§ 43-101 et seq.
(Prior Code, Appendix B, § 1.10) (Ord. 702, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 1.30. APPROVING REGULATIONS; FORBIDDING VIOLATIONS.
   Zoning regulations and restrictions as herein set forth are hereby approved
and established. No building or other structure shall be erected, structurally
altered, converted, enlarged, reconstructed, or placed, nor shall any land or
structure be used for any purpose, except in conformity to the regulations
herein prescribed.
(Prior Code, Appendix B, § 1.30) (Ord. 702, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 1.40. FORBIDDING ENCROACHMENT.
   The minimum lot areas, yards, and other open spaces, including the intensity
of use provisions contained in this appendix for each and every structure
existing at the time of passage of this appendix, or for any structure
hereafter erected, structurally altered, or placed, shall not be encroached
upon or treated as meeting the lot area, yard, open space, or intensity of use
requirements of any other structure.
(Prior Code, Appendix B, § 1.40) (Ord. 702, passed 3-15-1971)
DISTRICT PROVISIONS: GENERAL
§ 10.10. ZONING DISTRICTS.
   (A)   In order to classify, regulate, and restrict the location of trades
and industries, and the location of buildings designed for specific uses; to
regulate and limit the height and bulk of buildings hereafter erected or
altered; to regulate and limit the intensity of the uses of lot areas and to
regulate and determine the area of yards, courts, and other open spaces within
and surrounding such buildings, the city is hereby divided into the following
classes of districts:
      (1)   A districts (agricultural districts);
      (2)   R districts (residential districts), comprised of:
         (a)   RG10 district: general residential low density district;
         (b)   RG8 district: general residential medium density district;
         (c)   RG6 district: general residential high density district;
         (d)   RM10 district: mobile home park residential low density
district;
         (e)   RM8 district: mobile home park residential medium density
district; and
         (f)   RM6 district: mobile home park residential high density
district.
      (3)   P district (parking district);
      (4)   O district (office district);
      (5)   C districts (commercial districts), comprised of:
         (a)   CN district: neighborhood commercial district;
         (b)   CI district: intensive commercial district;
         (c)   CS district: commercial service district; and
         (d)   CG district: general commercial district.
      (6)   M districts (industrial districts), comprised of:
         (a)   ML district: light industrial district; and
         (b)   MH district: heavy industrial district.
      (7)   F districts (flood districts), comprised of:
         (a)   FW district: floodway district; and
         (b)   FF district: flood fringe district.
      (8)   PD districts (planned development districts).
(10.10.10)
   (B)   The use, height, and area regulations are uniform in each class of
district, subject to the following provisions.
      (1)   Regulations of the F districts are superimposed on portions of the
A, R, P, O, C, and M districts.
      (2)   Regulations of the PD districts are uniform within each such
district, but may vary from one PD district to another.
(10.10.20)
(Prior Code, Appendix B, § 10.10) (Ord. 702, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 10.20. ZONING MAP.
   (A)   The locations, area, and boundaries of the zoning districts
established pursuant to this appendix are indicated on the zoning map of the
city, which map is attached to and made a part of this appendix, and said map,
with all notations, legends, and references thereon shall be as much a part of
this appendix as though set forth fully herein. Said map is on file in the
office of the City Clerk, in the City Hall.
(10.20.10)
   (B)   All territory which may hereafter be annexed to the city shall
automatically be classed as lying and being in the A agricultural district as
above defined, until such classification shall have been changed by an
amendment to this appendix, as hereinafter provided or as provided by law.
(10.20.20)
   (C)   Where uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of any of the
aforesaid districts as shown on the zoning map, the following rules shall
apply.
      (1)   Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately following
the centerlines of streets or highways, street lines, or highway right-of-way
lines, such centerlines, street lines, or highway right-of-way lines shall be
construed to be such boundaries.
      (2)   Where district boundaries are so indicated that they approximately
follow the lot lines, such lot lines shall be construed to be said boundaries.
      (3)   Where district boundaries are so indicated that they are
approximately parallel to the centerlines or street lines of streets, or the
centerlines or right-of-way lines of highways, such district boundaries shall
be construed as being parallel thereto and at such scaled distance therefrom as
indicated on the zoning map.
      (4)   Where the boundary of a district line follows a railroad line, such
boundary shall be determined to be the centerline of the main tract, unless
otherwise clearly indicated on the zoning map.
(10.20.30)
(Prior Code, Appendix B, § 10.20) (Ord. 702, passed 3-15-1971)
AGRICULTURAL, RESIDENTIAL, PARKING, AND OFFICE DISTRICTS
§ 20.10. PURPOSES OF AGRICULTURAL, RESIDENTIAL, PARKING, AND OFFICE DISTRICTS.
   (A)   Purposes of the A district. The A district is intended to provide
areas primarily for agricultural and related uses and to protect such uses from
unplanned, premature, scattered urban type development, pending proper timing
for the providing of major thoroughfares, utilities, and other public
facilities.
(20.10.10)
   (B)   Purposes of the R district. The R districts are intended to protect
the residential character of areas so designated by:
      (1)   Excluding therefrom principal commercial and industrial activities;
      (2)   To encourage a suitable environment for family life by permitting
appropriate neighborhood facilities, such as churches, schools, and
playgrounds;
      (3)   To permit certain institutions and utility facilities considered
necessary in or compatible with residential neighborhoods;
      (4)   To preserve openness of the living areas and to avoid overcrowding
by requiring certain minimum yards, open spaces, and site areas, and maximum
bulk of structures;
      (5)   To provide for access of light and air to windows, and for privacy,
so far as possible, by controls over the spacing and height of buildings and
other structures;
      (6)   To make available areas suitable for a variety of dwelling types
and densities to permit a wide range of individual choice;
      (7)   To assure the provision of adequate off-street parking space to
provide for the parking needs of the permitted uses;
      (8)   To protect residential areas against hazardous, offensive, or
objectionable influences; and
      (9)   To protect residential areas against heavy traffic and against
through traffic of all kinds.
(20.10.20)
   (C)   Purposes of the P district. The P district is intended to facilitate
the providing of accessory off-street parking facilities in locations where
more intensive commercial or industrial development is not appropriate.
(20.10.30)
   (D)   Purposes of the O district. The O district is intended primarily to
facilitate the locating of physicians’ and dentists’ offices and uses
compatible therewith in close proximity to residential areas, especially in the
vicinity of hospitals, and to protect and maintain existing development of this
type.
(20.10.40)
(Prior Code, Appendix B, § 20.10) (Ord. 702, passed 3-15-1971)

COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS
§ 30.10. PURPOSES OF COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS.
   (A)   Purposes of the CN district. The CN district is designed to provide
for local shopping and includes convenience stores and personal service
establishments which cater to frequently recurring needs. The district
regulations are designed to promote convenient shopping and the stability of
retail development by encouraging continuous retail frontage and by excluding
local service establishments which tend to break such continuity and to limit
uses or characteristics of operation which encourage traffic from outside the
immediate neighborhood.
(30.10.10)
   (B)   Purposes of the CI district. The CI district is designed primarily to
provide a concentrated central core of intensive retailing and personal
services of all kinds, satisfying the personal and household needs of the
residents of the entire urban area and outlying trade area; and areas
accommodating central administrative, business, financial, general, and
professional offices and related services, satisfying the needs of the
residents, businesses, industries, and other enterprises of the urban area and
the trade area. The district regulations are designed to promote convenient
shopping and the stability of retail development by encouraging continuous
retail frontage.
(30.10.20)
   (C)   Purposes of the CS district. The CS district is designed primarily to
provide for certain high intensity commercial and light industrial activities
which need a central location, but which either do not require a location in
the core of a central business district, or are not compatible with the
principal uses of the core district.
(30.10.30)
   (D)   Purposes of the CG district. The CG district is designed primarily to
accommodate existing developments of mixed commercial, light industrial, and
residential uses which are already well established, providing a degree of
protection to adjacent residential areas; and accommodate certain commercial
and light industrial uses which are compatible with one another but are
inappropriate in certain other commercial or industrial districts.
(30.10.40)
   (E)   Purpose of the ML district. The purpose of the ML district is to
provide areas for manufacturing and other industrial uses of types which
ordinarily have only minor or moderate adverse effects on other uses in the
vicinity thereof.
(30.10.50)
   (F)   Purpose of the MH district. The purpose of the MH district is to
provide areas for manufacturing and other industrial uses which may have
heavier than moderate adverse effects on other uses in the vicinity thereof.
(30.10.60)
(Prior Code, Appendix B, § 30.10) (Ord. 702, passed 3-15-1971)

§ 30.30. CONDITIONS APPLYING TO PERMITTED USES.
   In Table 1, where the words “subject to,” followed by a number, appear after
the name of a use, such use shall be subject to the conditions set forth in the
indicated section.

§ 30.40. OFF-STREET LOADING AND PARKING REQUIRED.
   (A)   Off-street loading facilities shall be provided for certain uses
permitted in commercial and industrial districts, as provided in § 60.30.
   (B)   Off-street parking facilities shall be provided for uses permitted in
commercial and industrial districts, as provided in § 60.40.
(Prior Code, § 30.40) (Ord. 702, passed 3-15-1971)
§ 30.50. BULK AND AREA REGULATIONS IN COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS.
   (A)   Requirements; modifications. Every permitted use in a commercial or
industrial district shall be subject to the requirements set forth in this
article and to the modifications thereof set forth in §§
60.01 through
60.90.
(30.50.10)
   (B)   Yards.
      (1)   Minimum required yards in commercial and industrial districts shall
be as set forth in Table 2 of this article.
      (2)   Table 2, required yards in commercial and industrial districts:
District                               Yards (feet), Minimum
Front Yards                            Interior Yards
Along Property Lines Abutting Property Not Along Property Lines Abutting
in an R, P, or O District*             Property in an R, P, or O District
District                            Yards (feet), Minimum
